Heading: V
Content: By PAMELA MAY Beginning September 1, Dr. Wen dell Smith, former head of the De
    partment of Psychology, assumed his new responsibilities as Provost of the
    University. This position is one of chief academic officer after President
    Charles Watts III. Dr. Smith will be concerned with all areas of academic
    life, including academic programs, admissions and the in dividual deans. Dr.
    Smith recognized revelance " as one of the major concerns now in the
    academic program. This topic has been the focus of much debate on many
    campuses recently, and Dr. Smith stated the first step is to define what is
    meant by " relevance." and next to determine the issues." In his obligations
    to the students. Dr. Smith stated that his task is one of " bringing
    academic pro grams closer to their lives and experience." To improve the
    climate between students, administrators and fac ulty will be another
    concern of Dr. Smith. In connection with this, Dr. Smith noted the proposed
    Uni versity Senate, now under faculty consideration, is a possibility for "
    an excellent forum for discussing endless ideas of education, a forum where
    ideas may flow between administrators, faculty and stu dents, allowing for
    open discus sion." Another area to be handled will be to re-define the role
    of the deans, and perhaps to increase their authority so that they may serve
    their function better. The University has been with-

Heading: Freshmen Programs
Content: By NANCY GRDEN The Freshman Week Program for the Class of 1974 is now under way,
    with a few modifications of last year's program. Traditionally, Freshman
    Week began on a Saturday, but because classes are not starting until Fri
    day, the program began Monday. New innovations for this year include hall
    group meetings be fore the introductory sessions with " feedback"  meetings
    following the essions. The Assembly for the Class of 1974 Tuesday morning
    in- i lead of during the evening of the rst day, the showing of the film

Heading: If
Content: High School" , the WVBU " spe- 1" , and more varied and inter-

Heading: 1|L
Content: 

Heading: l
Content: ig: walking tours of Lewisburg, ampus, and riding tours, of the urrounding
    communities. her new innovation to the program is the opportunity for
    freshmen in groups of 3 or 4 stu dents to eat dinner in the home of a
    Lewisburg family. Other changes include " Games" Wednesday night, which is
    rather similar to the introductory ses sion. the reflection and meditation
    periods in which there is no struc tured worship service, and the group
    meetings this Saturday to discuss the classroom experience after the
    freshmen have been ex posed to one day of it. The idea of breaking the fresh
    man class up into many smaller groups was initiated the year be fore last so
    that the entire orienta tion experience would be more meaningful to the
    freshmen. Also initiated that year was the idea of the freshmen taking part
    in the program instead of just listening to lectures. One deletion of last
    year's pro gram is the English Qualifying exam, given by the English De
    partment, for those freshmen enter ing the honors program. out a permanent
    Provost for eight een months, during which time Professor Lester Kieft of
    the De partment of Chemistry acted as interim Provost. Dr. Smith was
    appointed an Aug ust 14. He brings with him an acquaintance with the
    institution which will aid him in his new post; he received his bachelor's
    and master's degrees from the University and has had a long as sociation as
    a member of the De partment of Psychology. Replacing Dr. Smith as head of
    the Psychology Department will be Dr. Douglas Candland.

Heading: In The Future
Content: Because of the holiday next Monday THE BUCKNELLIAN will not be published Tuesday
    of next week. The newspaper will begin regular Tuesday, Friday publication
    on Friday, September 11. By SUSAN PRESTON The University's Student Affairs
    Staff has released a new set of guidelines with regard to the use drugs on
    campus. Recognizing the possible detrimental effects of drugs, the staff
    assembled these sidelines which will be consulted any staff member who is
    con fronted by a student involved with drugs. The Student Affairs Staff
    hopes to discourage the use of illegal drugs and eliminate their miuse by
    students in two ways: " By assisting, through counsel ing the possible
    dangers of drug usage available to students through a multi-faceted drug
    education program;"  and " By assisting, thhrough counsel ing, students who
    wish to discon tinue their involvement or who de sire assistance in
    determining whether to become involved." Group 5 of the new University
    Regulations Relating to Conduct states that a person who violates a state or
    federal law on Univer sity property when such a violation has a detrimental
    effect on the University and/or its members will subject the person to Uni
    versity disciplinary action. An in dividual is directly responsible for
    obeying state and federal laws. Group 1 of the same regulations further
    states that " Behavior which infringes on the rights of others, endangers
    their well-being or safe ty, or results in personal injury to others. .
    .will subject a person to University action." The Preamble of the
    regulations states that the University must re lease information to the
    appro priate authorities when civil or criminal law has been violated on

Heading: Sophomores Sleep on Fifth Trax
Content: 

Heading: Men Students Face Housing Shortage
Content: By RAY SCHLES1NGER Until University administrators can come up. with a solution
    to the housing shortage on campus, about 35 to 75 sophomore men will be
    living in makeshift quarters this semester. The situation resulting from a
    large freshman class is further complicated by behind-schedule construction
    of the new Sigma Mu fraternity house and the new wing of the Tan Kappa
    Epsilon house, and also by the vacancy of the Phi Lambda Theta house. In
    addition, some off-campus housing was closed over the summer by state
    officials. All women have housing, as well as all freshmen. Those men with
    out permanent rooming assign ments are those whose priority numbers were
    highest last May. Virtually all singles for men have been converted into
    doubles mainly in the A wing of Swartz Hall. The lounge in the D wing of
    Swartz will be renovated into triples shortly, but they will still be oc
    cupied before the beds are install ed. Approximately 35 sophomores will be
    assigned to the bunk room space on the fifth floor of Trax Hall. Floor
    Manager Chip Crider explained that the former male guest room has a capacity
    for 40 students. Officials have promised that this would only be a temp
    orary measure. Each student gets a mattress in a bunk bed and a locker which
    can not be locked The floor offers a small study area, two shower heads, two
    sinks, and two toilets. Crider said. " Noise carries quite a bit here, so
    the guys will have to make their own rules to keep quiet." Residence
    department offilials were in conference around the clock starting Monday on
    a solution for the problem, and were not available for comment. The new wing
    at TKE was ready for occupancy for 15 men yester day, although the rooms
    were un finished. A brother said that the fraternity members will paint the
    rooms. Contractors are expected to finish the party room by Sept. 12 .
    Construction of the SAM house has been delayed for three weeks over the
    summer, and 18 men will move in on Sept. 20. By today, however, these men
    had no speci fic room assignments. The University is balking at pur chasing
    the PLT house because reconditioning costs will be high. Vice President John
    Zeller has said that if no other housing is located, the University will
    rent or purchase trailers and put them on the west side of Route 15. campus
    when such a request is made by those authorities or when danger to life
    and/or property is imminent. Keeping in mind these University regulations,
    the Student Affairs Staff has adopted a set of eight guidelines to use when
    confronted with the use of drugs by students. The application of these guide
    lines will be flexible and no pro cedure will be automatically im plemented.
    Each case will be look ed at individually. A staff member will use his own
    judgement and in itiative and may discuss a case in which he is in doubt.
    Each case should be dealt with " individually in a manner which seems to be
    in the best interests of those in volved as well as the University-
    community and society at large. ' The new drug policy also states that " in
    recognition of the differ ences in the potential for personal harm
    represented by misuse of various drugs, the concern for and involvement with
    students will necessarily vary as the drug ques tion varies." The concern
    for a student taking drugs will vary according to whether the student
    occasionally takes drugs, takes them frequent ly for social reasons, takes
    drugs to help with his personal problems, or encourages others to take
    drugs. When a staff member knows that a student possesses, uses or dis
    tributes drugs he will interview- the (Continued on Page 2)

Heading: New Residence Hall Directors

Heading: Urge Campus Communication
Content: By ERIC RIESS "We are in the business of doing what we can for people to allow
    them to sort of do their own thing." With this premise Miss Judith A. Judy
    is beginning her first year as director of Univer sity Residence Halls. Miss
    Judy replaces Miss Suzanne K. Herman, who has been named Assistant Dean of
    Studants at Lafayette College, She went on to add that, " the biggest
    obstacle to this end seems to be artificial barriers that arise between the
    students and their resident as sistants (R. A.'s) and between the R. A.'s
    and the professionals or administrators." Miss Judy emphasized that com
    munication is ti>>e only way that "the necpessary"  feeling of trust and
    countenance can be establish ed between students, R. A.'s and
    administrators. The new director formerly served as a residence hall
    director at Illinois State University in Nodmal, 111. and will work closely
    with Leonard P. Smolen who was named associate director when the Office of
    University Residence halls was created last year. When asked about the
    difficul ties she has encountered in her new job, Miss Judy stated, " de
    spite of the switch to coed living and the fact that some sophomore men will
    be living in makeshift quarters, we haven't had any ma jor difficulties. My
    major problem has been getting myself adjusted to the surroundings and
    meeting the people that I'll be working with." In reference to the
    guildlines for h an d lin g student problems, recent- (Continued on Page 2)
    A bequest of nearly $2 million has been received by the Uni versity from the
    estate of Mrs. Roy

Heading: G.
Content: Bostwick of Pittsburgh, who died in December, 1967. This sum includes $650,000
    which is to be used to construct a build ing which will be a memorial to
    Mrs. Bostwick's late husband, a Pittsburgh attorney and former chairman of
    the Board of Trustees, and $200,00 which has been des ignated for the Roy
    Grier Bostwick Student Assistance Fund to provide loans for Pennsylvania
    students. The residue of Mrs. Bostwick's estate, amounting to nearly $11
    million, is to be made a part of the University's endowment fund. The terms
    of Mrs. Bostwick's will were made known by Clyde A. Armstrong, a prominent
    Pittsburgh attorney and executor of the es tate. The University also
    announced that it has received a grant of $62,596 from the U.S. Office of
    Education for a research project entitled " Behavioral Protocols in Language
    Development: Reading." The goal of the project is to as semble films which
    carefully re cord the behavior of children as they progress through various
    stages of competence in reading. The grant to Bucknell is one of 11 awarded
    to prominent institutions throughout the country. The direc tor of each of
    the 11 projects has the responsibility for developing sets of films which
    record the in tellectual, emotional, and physical reactions of students as
    they deal with a variety of learning tasks in the schools. It is expected
    that the films pro duced by the various institutions will form the nucleus
    of a technical film library which will be made available to teacher
    preparation institutions and to teachers in the public schools. The
    University's project is the sole one being undertaken in the area af
    reading. The film will be produced at the University's Audio- Visual Center,
    and Dr. Hugh F . McKeegan, associate professor of elucation and director of
    the cen ter, and Richard E. Cassel, also of the center, will serve as consul
    tants to the project.

Heading: Peters Collapses
Content: 

Heading: At Tennis Match
Content: Henry 'Hank' Peters head tennis coach collapsed and died while conducting a
    tennis tournament at the University August 15. The sixty-two year old Peters
    a native of Carbondale, Pennsylvania. He had attended Bucknell Junior
    College in Wilkes Barre and coached both the basketball and baseball teams
    while there. In 1939 he graduated from the University with a Bachelor of
    Arts degree in History and two years later he graduated from Penn State with
    a Masters Degree in Physical Education. One year later he received a masters
    Degree in history from this University. After serving as a chief petty
    officer during the second World War, he returned to the University to assume
    the role of head tennis coach. Two years later he joined the University's
    physical education staff as an associate professor. Peters' tennis teams had
    a com bined record of 158 wins and 129 defeats including a 14-0 perfect
    slate in 1970 to win the MAC crown for the second consecutive year. Peters
    is survived by his wife the former Margaret G. Williams. nmmmhrvmmm m. nii I
    i MM h MMMHNMHNMBHHIMIIMMIII tKHem w '*' . !

Heading: Ewing, Duque Fill Vacant Posts
Content: Bushanan " Buck" Ewing, III, a a 1965 Bucknell graduate, has been named
    assistant director of ad missions at the University. Recipient of bachelor
    of arts and bachelor of science In chemical en gineering degree from this
    Uni versity, Ewing received a master of business administration degree from
    Boston University this year. Announcement of his appoint ment was made by
    Fritz R. Wal ling, director of admissions. He served two years as a First
    Lieutenant with the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers beginning in November 1965,
    was a project en gineer with The Badger Co. in Cambridge, Mass, from
    February to September 1968 before entering Boston University, and was a mar
    keting research assistant with the United Fruit Co. in Boston in the summer
    of 1969. As an undergraduate at Bucknell Mr. Ewing was enrolled in a special
    five-year program combin ing degrees in arts and engineer ing. He was a
    member of Phi Delta Epsilon, national journalism fra ternity, and the
    student chapter of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers. Ewing
    replaces Ponathan

Heading: C
Content: Davis on the Bucknell admissions staff. Mr. Davis plans to do grad uate studies
    at Syracuse Univer sity. Mrs. Gale Stillman Duque, a lecturer in English at
    Bucknell, has also been named foreign student advisor at the University.
    Recipient of a bachelor of arts degree from the University of Ro chester in
    1958 and a master of arts degree from New ork Uni versity in 1968, Mrs.
    Duque has served as a lecturer in English here since February 1969. Her
    field of special interest is teaching English as a second lan guage and she
    received her mas ter's degree in this area. Prior to beginning studies for
    her master's degree she served seven years as a professional work er with
    the Girl Scouts of America in Rochester, N.Y. and Monmouth County, New
    Jersey, and one year as a teacher of English in Helsinki. Finland. She is
    currently a mem ber of the International Selections i

Heading: Footnotes
Content: By PAUL J. J. PA YACK THE REVOLT OF THE MASSES By Jose Oretga y Gasset 190
    pages. New York: Norton. 1957. Paperback. $1.50. When in 1831 Count Alexis
    de Toqueville visited America, he particularly noted what he later termed "
    the tyranny of the majority." One hundred years later Ortega y Gasset, a
    Spaniard, labeled that same tendency as inherent in the emergent mass-man.
    To be sure, his view of the masses was both perceptive and pes simistic. To
    phrase it precisely, he considered the masses revolt ing. According to
    Ortega, the mass is that statistical ideal, the average man, Mr. John Q.
    Public. Ortega adds, " The mass is all that which sets no value on itself."
    Considering that the world is derived from the German meaning barley-cake,
    this is rather difficult to refute. Ortega continues that the mass-man is he
    who feels himself " just like everybody,"  who believes " to be different is
    to be indecent" (cf. La Foule of Le Bon). Ortega contends that the rise of
    this mass is primarily due to certain philosophical discoveries, namely, the
    rights of man: Every human being, by the fact of birth . . . possessed
    certain fundamental political rights . . ." This led to a most unnatural
    situation in which the weak are allowed existence by the strong Accordingly,
    this idea was gradually modified to the point at w'hieh being cross-wise
    became synonomous with being queer. The mass-man understood his rights, but
    not the delicate interplay of ideas which assured those of others. De
    Toqueville was proved correct. Mass rule became a new form of despotism. It
    should be noted that some maintain that the Constitution's original victory
    over tyranny simply guaranteed the personal liberties. The business of
    ruling was to be left to those proficient in governmental technique, as
    determined by the mass, but not ruled by the mass itself. The reason being
    that governmental technique would continually become more complex and
    increas ingly specialized. Ortega has also been supported by the argument of
    environ mentalists: Although mass-rule is now the most preferable form of
    government, it is by no means the ultimate. This being so because it is
    based on an unscientific conception of man, one which trusts in his inherent
    wisdom and goodness, entirely discounting the effects of the world in which
    he lives. The question can now be raised as to where in our society can this
    mass-man be found -- in Bircher's garb, at the Elk's -C.lub or under the
    epaulets of the revolution? The tell-tale sign of this man, his lowest
    common denominator, is the fact that he knows that he is right <<remember,
    you don't have to think to know). Therefore the answer is all three; take
    your pick. It may be comforting to note that Ortega concedes that, given the
    proper direction, the mass will not only be saved from itself but aspire
    toward that best of all possible worlds. In the end, a hint of optimism may
    lie in the title, Revolt of the Massed Ortega maintains that the world is
    undergoing a revolt rather than a rebellion. The difference is hardly
    minute, since a rebel lion is a destruction of the old, whereas a revolution
    is the con struction of the new. Maybe this is where our salvation lies.

Heading: Guidelines
Content: (Continued from Page 1) student or refer him to an appro priate body. The staff
    member's first con cern is for the individual's wel fare and the
    implications of his actions might have on others. To decide an appropriate
    course of action, the staff member will ques tion the individual about his
    in volvement with drugs, to determine to what extent he is involved and why
    and to discover if the student understands the legal liabilities and
    possible harmful effects of the drug. The University will advise the student
    misusing drugs to discon tinue their use. The University will provide
    assistance to help the stu dent become uninvolved with drugs. If he will not
    or cannot dis continue his misusage volutarily, the staff will recommend his
    medi cal withdrawal or initiate judicial action, according to the circum
    stances of the ease. The guidelines also state that " the Student Affairs
    Staff is not ex pected to act as law enforcement officers or as
    investigators. How- evers, staff members must coop- orate with a legitimate
    request from duly constituted authorities." Finally, the document says that
    if a student is charged by law en forcing agencies of violating the laws
    regarding drags the Uni versity will conduct its own investi gation. If it
    is determined that the interests of the academic com munity are involved,
    the University " may take action independently of civil authorities."

Heading: OFFICIAL STUDENT NEWSPAPER SERVING THE BUCKNELL COMMUNITY
Content: Established 1897. Published twice weekly during the college year. Member of
    Associated Collegiate Press. Annual subscription, $7.00, payable in ad
    vance. Entered as second class matter on September 21, 1922, at the post
    office at Lewisburg, Pa. under the act of March 3, 1879.

Heading: BUCKNELL UNIVERSITY. LEWISBURG. PENNSYLVANIA

Heading: New University Senate
Content: 

Heading: ABS Discusses E
Content: -- ,, -- ,, . wpnvwT loct nirrVit tn solicit candi- Men by Monday and a prelirm
    By ERIC RIESS The University faculty will meet in special session Monday at
    7:30 p.m. in Coleman Hall Auditorium to discuss a new proposal for the
    reorganization of the University's governance procedure. The proposal
    entitled, Proposal For A University Senate, was pre pared over the summer
    months by a  special faculty committee ap pointed last May. Dr. John A. Pe
    eler, professor of Political science, Dr. Ralph Spielman, professor of
    sociology, Dr. Edward Stiano, pro fessor of Computer Science and Dr. Charles
    Walker, professor o f elec trical engineering were appointed at the final
    University faculty meeting last year. At that meeting the faculty de feated
    another model for a Uni versity Senate prepared by a fa culty governance
    Committee. That proposal was the subject of debate in the faculty since it
    was released last February. After the first Senate model failed to receive
    the necessary two- thirds majority by an 80-54 vote the faculty decided to
    continue their attempt to restructure the govern ance by appointing the new
    com mittee. In a cover letter with the new proposal, Dr. Spielman, speaking
    for the committee says, " You will note that the proposal is not, a mere
    compromise of old positions but includes innovations that make it a new
    proposition requiring a new judgement. . ." In a personal interview Dr.
    Speil- man emphasised this view saying, " this is not a rehash of the old
    Senate model, it is new, and must be considered in that light." Along with
    the proposal for the Senate are recommendations for necessary revisions in
    the structure of the faculty committee system. These suggestions are not
    part of the proposal but are necessary to provide for the smooth function
    ing of the Senate if it is adopted. Spielman commented, " this is only a
    proposal that we are pre senting to the faculty. We hope to encourage debate
    to improve the document wherever possible, be fore final action is taken. By
    SUSAN PRESTON The upcoming elections of living unit representatives and
    sugges tions of concentration for the com ing year were the topics of Wednes
    day night's Association of Bucknell Students meeting. Craig Eby, ABS vice-
    president, began the meeting by explaining the election procedure to the
    pres ent members, who visited upper- class hall groups and fraternity houses
    last night to solicit candi dates. Each living unit i.e. dormitory or
    fraternity house, will elect a certain number of representatives based on
    the number of students in that unit, to serve on the ABS for one year.
    Students interested in running will contact the Resi dent Director of their
    dorm or the Dean of Student Affairs Office of the Assistant Dean of
    Fraternity

Heading: Experimental College Organizes Plans;
Content: 

Heading: Interim Board Forms Future Activities
Content: By JAN WILLIAMS The Interim Board of the Ex perimental College today announc ed
    its plans for the future of the Experimental College in letters sent to the
    entire university com munity. The letters state plans for holding another
    Experimental Col lege this January, and for the for mation of an official
    Experimental College Board. The January Experimental Col lege will be
    generally conducted along the same lines as was the first Experimental
    College last January. However, the Interim Board stresses that this is not
    an exact replica of the first Experi mental College, since the nature of a
    college of this sort depends " entirely on its members." A meeting of all
    students and faculty interested in being mem bers of the January
    Experimental College will be held September 20 in Coleman 102A at 8:00 p.m.
    Members of the university com munity can read the prospects for the January
    Experimental College, in the reserve room or student lounge of the library
    or by con tacting any member of the Interim Board. The Experimental College
    Board is being created to officially take over all future planning and ac
    tivities concerning the Experi mental College here. Four faculty members and
    four students will be chosen for the Board.

Heading: H H

Heading: Sweet Memories
Content: By TERRY ELLIS Tomorrow the Class of 1971 will have one of its last chances to
    re live the past during " Old Sweet Shop Day." Only seniors will actually re
    member " The thrill of . . * the first Sweet Shop date,"  as quoted by their
    freshman directory, but the remainder of the campus will have a unique
    opportunity to attach their own interpretation upon a past tradition. The
    Sweet Shop was, until 1968, the campus hangout, although fi nancially
    independent of the Uni versity. It featured an escape from the cafeterias
    through regular meal plans and a variety of foods. One specialty, the
    Clydeburger, was named after the Sweet Shop owner, Clyde Kirkland, who
    retired in 1968. At that time, the brothers of Theta Delta Chi purchased The
    Sweet Shop for their house and have since revived its old tradi tions to
    raise money for various charities. This year, in conjunction with Phi Mu
    Sorority, TDX has chosen the medical ship U.S.S. Hope as their charity with
    profits and do nations going toward this fund. From 11 a.m. until 1 a.m.
    students may order such items as pizzas, hoagies, Clydeburgers, and sun daes
    while listening to 'oldies from the jukebox' as they revive the past in
    order to help the present during Old Sweet Shop Day. order to better serve
    those stu dents who seek to concentrate in areas which transcend depart
    mental lines," according to the committee prologue to the recom mendation.
    In order to take part in the pro gram, the student must consult first with
    the chairman of the de partment where he will be taking the most courses as
    well as the other department chairman involv ed to develope a proposal. The
    proposal will consist of a topic statement, a detailed list of courses to be
    taken, a statement of reason by the student, and a statement by the
    cooperating fac ulty members that they have re viewed and approved the
    students program. The proposal will then be taken before a committee on
    Interdepart mental Majors, composed of elect ed faculty members. The commit
    tee will review all proposals, as well as provide advice for continu ation
    and evaluation of the pro gram. The committee will report to the Curriculum
    committee every two years. In other orders of business the Arts and Science
    faculty author ized the creation of a m ajor in classics. Previously the
    classics department could only offer de grees in Latin or Greek. Now the
    department will offer a classics major with the possibility of con
    centration in Greek, Latin, or classical civilization. The faculty also
    provided for the organization of a freshman advisor seminar committee,
    composed of three faculty members and two students. The committee will take
    over or ganization of the freshman advisor seminar program instituted this
    year. All members of the com mittee will be elected by methods established
    by the ABS or Faculty. In a final move the faculty voted to reorganize the
    structure of the Curriculum Committee. Students must submit an ap plication
    of their own creation, ex pressing their reaction to the idea of the
    Experimental College and their views on the future of Experi mental College.
    Both students and professors must be interviewed by several members of the
    Interim Board. All applicants should familiarize themselves with the
    evaluation of the first Experimental College, en titled Structures of
    Learning:

Heading: Senior Class Plans
Content: 

Heading: Reunion Gift Drive
Content: By LAURIE BUTCHER The past two years heve seen a change in scope of the
    traditional senior class gift here. Instead of simply collecting money to
    buy benches or a mem orial gateway, the Classes of '69 and '70 plegded
    yearly contribu tions to a fund which would be in vested by a committee
    formed of members of their respective clas ses. At their 10th reunion, the
    clas ses will vote on what they feel is an appropriate use for what, at that
    time, will be a considerable sum for the University. Jeff Sengstack Senior
    Class Pres ident is organizing the Class of '71 Reunion Gift Drive in a
    manner similar to the two previous drives. (Continued on Page 5)

Heading: Center Construction
Content: 

Heading: Progresses Rapidly
Content: By NANCY GRDEN The construction of three build ings on and near the University
    campus has progressed rapidly over the summer. The University Center is
    scheduled for completion in September 1971, with the new Sigma Alpha house
    and the added wing on the Tau Kappa Epsilon house scheduled for use in the
    next few weeks. According to Walter C. Geiger, chief engineer of the
    construction of the Center, the construction of the building is about on
    schedule. The brick and stone work on the front of the building which faces
    Seventh Street House, is 100% completed. Within the next two weeks, the
    finished roof wall be constructed. The concrete work for the fft^rs has been
    done, and the instaif on of heating, electri cal conduk ir conditioning
    units, and other X facilities in now in progress. The kitchen^, *ies are
    sched uled to arrive around October 1, and they will be installed through
    November. Also, by the << id  of November, the external brickwork should be
    finished. The driveway is up to its per manent elevation in order to tie in
    with the entrances to the building. The sidewalk is presently lower than the
    driveway, but it will later be raised to its permanent level. The final
    grading is not done, but some of the work on the rough grading has been
    started. The added wing of the TKE house and the new SAM house are both
    scheduled for use by the end of September. All of the facilities in TKE's
    new wing are installed, except for the enlarged party room downstairs, which
    is scheduled for completion by September 19. Landscaping will ha done at a
    later date. There are 45 brothers now living in the house, 15 of which live
    in the new wing. SAM expects to sleep 16 of its brothers in the house before
    the end of the month. Several weeks later the dining facilities should be in
    readiness, and the recreation facilities should be completed three of weeks
    later, in November.

    vance. Entered as second class matter on September 21, 1922, at the post
    office at Lewisburg, Pa. under the act of March 3>> 1879.

Heading: THE BUCKNELLIAN PLATFORM
Content: To review any issue and take a stand we deem to the best interest of the
    University, to treat every issue with the responsibility that Is accorded us
    in a free society to be constructively critical when necessary as well as
    laudatory when appropriate, and to print the news with accuracy and in
    tegrity. Editorials appearing on this page reflect the majority opinion of
    tha editorial board and that of the editors. Signed columns present the
    views only of the authors. All letters should be addressed to the Editor,
    and must be received no later than Saturday noon for publication in the
    Tuesday edition and Wednes day noon for publication in the Friday edition.
    AU letters must be signed and typed double-spaced: however, names may be
    withheld upon request. The Editor reserves the right to choose aU letters
    for publication, and to edit any letter chosen for reasons of space
    restrictions, grammatical change and offensive language. Office: Fochl
    Printing Co., 22S Market Street, 822-4221 Consultant: Brad Tufts. 824-1221

Heading: : POLITICS 7 0
Content: 

Heading: A Campaign in the Spring
Content: -By JACK SCHMIDT; jjgaa!

Heading: Letters to the Editor
Content: It had been a long, hot June day. As I got out of my car early that evening, I
    felt myself wanting to sprint into headquarters to see how we had done. But
    I held myself back, walking slowly, thinking back over the past few weeks'
    hoping for the best . . , Lew Kaden had announced his candidacy for the
    Democratic nom ination for the United States Representative of the Fifteenth
    Congres sional District in New Jersey in the early spring. He had graduated
    from Harvard Law School, been legislative assistant to the late Senator
    Robert F. Kennedy, and had recently been working with labor mediator
    Theodore Kheel. He had spent most of his time oltside of Middlesex County
    since graduating from Perth Amboy High School and was thus relatively
    unknown in the area. He was given little chance of beating the incumbent,
    Representative Ed Patten, since Patten had the backing of the strong
    Democratic organization. Kaden's chances for nomination looked bleak when
    President Nixon announced that United States troops had invaded Cambodia in
    late April. University strikes swept the nation soon after the Kent State
    killings, and Rutgers and Princeton students began to look closer at the
    Middle sex County race. Patten told students at Rutgers that he was against
    the invasion, but, when speaking to the Sayreville V. F. W., said that he
    backed the President. He was playing politics. Kaden had consistently been
    calling for immediate withdrawal from Vietnam, and he condemned the
    Cambodian action in the strongest terms. The growing political concern among
    students moved many to begin working for this very dark horse. In early May,
    at least sixty Princeton students would daily make the thirty minute drive
    north on Route 1 to New Brunswick and the now growing Kaden headquarters.
    Everyday, they would canvass an other portion of the district, and everyday
    their spirits rose a bit more. It seemed that people were beginning to
    listen, and that a grass-roots campaign might just have a chance of
    succeeding. People began realiz ing that they were going to have a real
    choice between candidates, and it seemed that many voters would even go to
    the polls to make that choice. As the weeks went by, the student ranks
    swelled. Rutgers and Doug lass students began to work at nine and would
    finish in the late evening. Students from other schools, whose homes were in
    the district, began working soon after unpacking their bags. High school
    students manned the twenty phones, calling strange homes, trying to get out
    the vote on June 2. House wives were calling friends, and soon the search
    began for poll watchers and baby sitters. And we thought we had a real
    chance. We even began to talk about getting together again in the fall for
    the general elections. On primary day two busloads of volunteers arrived for
    the day from New York, all veterans of past Lindsay campaigns, and now
    working for candidates with names like Eikenberry and Abzug, and for state
    senators I can't even remember. They had all given up a day for a man they
    had hardly ever heard of but had been told was on " the right side." " New
    Jersey Must Do Better Lew KADEN for CONGRESS" . . . But as I rounded the
    corner that night I looked anxiously at some f am iliar faces, I could see
    that we had lost. And we had lost badly, by a two to one margin, winning
    only three towns in the whole district. Although we had received as many
    votes as we had thought we had needed for a win, the heaviest voter turn-out
    in ten years had swelled the Patten vote. In canvassing the entire districe,
    we had at least sparked interest in many more voters although we had not
    actually con vinced them to vote for our candidate. People had decided to
    vote for the incumbent, but for the first time, they had been forced to
    confront Issues in a primary election. Although Lew had lost badly, his
    student workers had done well in their own right. Most people were
    interested in what we had had to say, and were quite surprised that we were
    giving up so much of our personal time to work for something we believed in
    We were really work ing for a cause, rather than a candidate; we were
    working for peace through democratic means. We were going out and talking
    with people, telling them their vote really did count, and asking them to
    listen to what we believed in and what our candidates stood for. Although we
    didn't win, we were listened to, not despised and shouted down. The people
    all hand an opportunity to vote in this election, those who took advantage
    of their right chose to vote for the incumbent by a large margin. But the
    power was there for all those who wanted to use it. Wc worn a small victory
    in that we had begun to work at a personal level. If we hadn't won, we at
    least had brought an unknown peace candidate and his views much closer to
    the people he was seeking to represent. People had begun to listen. If
    change is to come in this nation, it must come on a personal level. The
    campaign showed that a new idea and a new candidate has a real chance if
    people are willing to work for what they believe. We didn't win, but we were
    heard and listened to. And we'll be back.

    thought it was of significance and should be printed. To the Editor:
    Recently I was invited to help mmmMmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm organize the new
    Bucknell fund drive in this area. On the same day several Bucknell students
    pub lished a letter in the Corning news paper. It reported: " The faculty of
    Bucknell Uni versity voted to 'suspend normal academic functions to enable
    the

Heading: From the Editor's Desk
Content: .By PAUL OSHER. An experimental, " write your own"  insert will be newly
    featured in The Bucknellian this semester. On the assumption that there are
    groups of people who feel that the " establishment"  newspaper cannot meet
    their needs, The Bucknellian is seeking to afford them an opportunity to
    create their own. The cost of a two-page insert, The Bucknellian's newspaper
    facilities and expertise will all be available to an interested group once a
    month. Groups that make application for these services will be asked to
    present The Bucknellian a general outline of their proposed project by the
    middle of each month. As this is an experiment in the people's fre edom of
    the press the priorities for consideration of competing proposals will be
    established and published when proposals are in-hand. The deadline for
    submitting proposals for the first experimental pub lication is September
    18. Those interested are asked to contact Paul Osher at 1263 or at The
    Bucknellian office, 523-4221.

Heading: THE SIDESH OW -
Content: 

Heading: Tradition
Content: -By DAVID WEINBERGER;

Heading: PAGE TWO
Content: 

Heading: THE BUCKNELLIAN
Content: SEPTEMBER 11, 1970 Many of you are Freshmen, too young and too immature to under
    stand the meaning of a breakdown of tradition, but you can trust your elder
    upperclassmen when they tell you it is happening to you here and now. The
    Freshmen are running around like mold in an old cheese store. And it's time
    something was done about it. First of all, and most of all, the women must
    be moved from Roberts Hall. It brings a soft tear to the hard eye to think
    of all those girls showering under faucets that once spiritized such B. U.
    football greats as Russel Muscle and Roger Crashlodger. It brings moisture
    to the lips to think of all those women running around the halls of that
    esteemed building with their soft little bodies clad in less material than
    needed to make the stars on the colonial flag (God bless it!). This is what
    we mean by " lack of tradition" . One's identity is all of one's past
    actions. Although he is nasty today, for example, his identity is not nasty
    because in the past he has been more often nice than rotten. In the same
    way, the identity of a people or college de pends on its past. The identity
    of Roberts Hall is male and can never be female. Oh, sure it can be
    temporarily inhabited by females, but so can jockey shorts and jockey shorts
    !will forever be male (it is comforting to know that some things just never
    change. But meanwhile, an identity crisis is being forced on our buildings.
    What is Roberts Hall to think? Was Roberts ever consulted? No, a lynch mob
    of crazed students and administrators castrated it. Bear in mind that this
    was no Myra Breckinridge sex operation but a brutal and savage ripping at
    the very masculinity of established institutions. Perhaps this will give
    some clue as to why our buildings are acting so sluggishly. The corridors
    seem to squeak a little mare, the faucets dribble instead of gush. Some
    might say that this is due to nothing more than advancing age, but any
    competent doctor will tell you that the Will to Live is the most important
    component of our survival kits. Take that away and a leaf turns to brown, a
    grape into a rasin. A word about these two phenomena is necessary. The
    leaves turn brown in autum to maintain their free will in the face of their
    realization that the winter will inevitably come anyway and will turn them
    brown. The grapes, however, have for the past few years conscientiously re
    fused to turn into grapes to support the grape boycott. The grapes knew that
    if they turned into rasins many would eat them, not aware that California
    rasins were also being boycotted, and so the path of grapes was clear.
    You'll never find a strike-breaker grape. This year, now that the strike is
    over, we can expect to see many tired grapes relinquish their grips on
    juiciness and head into that bowl of bran flakes waiting for us all. And
    that should be a lesson to us all. If only we had the !wisdom of (Continued
    on Page 3) members of the University com munity to engage in activities ad
    dressed to our national crisis.' The faculty and the student leaders of the
    strike emphasized that it was a strike

Heading: WITH
Content: the University rather than against it . . .  . The student resolution calls for:
    im mediate withdrawal of U. S. troops from Cambodia and Laos, perma nent
    cessation of bombing of North Vietnam, and withdrawal of troops from
    Southeast Asia by Decem ber." It is not difficult to find students who
    believe themselves superior in wisdom and knowledge to the Com mander-in-
    Chief, his cabinet of ficers, and the high ranking pro fessionals charged
    with America's security. The gravity with which adolescents undertake to
    provide instant solutions to international problems baffling the most experi
    enced of men, becom es a source of humor to themselves when they grow older.
    (At 17 I published an article entitled " The Riddle of the Universe," which
    dissipated the riddle in 1,000 words-) But maturity -- or at least post-
    adolescense -- is expected of fa culty members. For them to " su spend
    normal academic functions to enable the members of the Uni versity community
    to engage in ac tivities addressed to our national crisis,"  is as arrogant
    in attitude as it is pompus and sophomoric in language. This is the behavior
    of a pseudo intellectual lynch mob enforcing conformity by strangling
    dissent. It silences dissenters by ignoring the very existence of their
    point of view. It extinguishes the right of a student even to be non-
    involved -- to attend classes instead of playing international politics. It
    says with the brutal directness of a totali tarian " people's" (slave)
    state: " Not only may you not disagree; you MUST AGREE!" In condoning such
    faculty action, Bucknell abdicates its function as an institution of
    enlightenment and becomes an instrument of crowd tyranny. While it continues
    thus to distort the purpose for which it was founded, I must refuse to raise
    money for -- or to give money to -- an Alma Mater of which I have be come
    ashamed. ROBERT L. LYON, 1929 6 Belleau St. Corning, N. Y. 14830

Heading: University Receives
Content: 

Heading: USA Biolog) Grant
Content: The University's department of biology has been awarded a $6,700 grant by the
    National Science Foundation for the purchase of in structional scientific
    equipment. The grant, which will be adminis tered by Dr. Jack E. Harclerode,
    associate professor of biology and chairman of the department, and Dr.
    Richard J. Ellis, assistant pro fessor of biology, must be matched by the
    University. The funds from the grant will be used to purchase equipment for
    several courses in both animal and plant physiology. The major items include
    a differential respirometer, a recording spectrophometer, a fraction
    collector, and spectroradio- meter. Saturday at the Evangelical Com munity
    Hospital in Lewisburg. Gold, who was 71, retired in 1969 after almost half a
    century as a member of the University faculty. He came to the University in
    1920 as an instructor in mathematics, two years after receiving his bachelor
    of science degree in math ematics with the distinction of cum laude. In 1921
    he received his master of arts degree from the University, he did post
    graduate study at the University of Chicago. In 1967 he was one of three
    professors who re ceived the Lindback Award for dis tinguished teaching and
    in the same year was honored with the MacDuffee Award for distinguished
    service to Phi Mu Epsilon national honorary mathematics fraternity. The
    class of 1968 also saluted him when they dedicated their edition of L'Agenda
    to him. Last June Dr. Gold was given one of the University's highest alumni
    awards, the Alumni Chair for Eminent and Meritorious Ser vice and
    Demonstrated Loyalty to the University. Professor Gold is survived by his
    wife the former S. Marie Ul rich; three children David H. of Danville,
    William D. of Lewisburg and Mrs. Albert Kazary of Doyles- town, Pa. 14 grand
    children and four greatgrandchildren. Friends who wish to honor his memory
    are asked to make contri butions to the Heart Fund. PTofessor Sprague was a
    re cipient of a bachelor of arts degree from Tulane University in 1916 and a
    master of arts degree from the University of Wisconsin in 1919. He waSS an
    instructor at Wisconsin from 1917 until 1924 when he came here. He was
    promoted to associate professor of romance languages in 1926 and to
    professor of Spanish in 1949. He retired in 1960 after 36 years on the
    University faculty. Professor Sprague is survived by his two sons, Robert M.
    of Wethers field Conn, and Walter A. of York, and a brother Roy A. of
    Waukeska, Wis., and five grand children. A memorial service will be held
    tonight at 7:30 p.m. at the First Baptist Church in Lewisburg. Friends who
    wish to honor his memory are invited to make con tributions to the
    Evangelical Com munity Hospital building fund. Meditation Chapel Vaughan
    Lit. Aud. Friday, September 11 6:30 p.m. Jewish Services 8:00 p.m. Hilltop:
    " Grand Illusion" Saturday, September 12 8:30 a.m. Inhalation Therapy
    Technicians Test Visual Aids Aud. 9:00 a.m. Computer Center Orientation
    Program Freshmen Data Engineering 228 12:00 Noon International House Picnic
    Cowan 8:00 p.m. Class of 1971 and 1973 Film: " Who's Afraid of Virginia W
    oolf?" Vaughan Lit. Aud. Sunday, September 13 10:30 a.m. Chapel: The Rev.
    Mr. James E. Gardner Rooke Chapel 4:00 p.m. Catholic Mass Rooke Chapel 8:30
    p.m. " Bucknellian"  Organizational Meeting Coleman Hall 102A Monday,

Heading: Several Expensive Items Reported Missing;
Content: 

Heading: Zeller Sees Personal Insurance as Remedy
Content: 

Heading: The Sideshow
Content: By DAVID WEINBERGER By CHARLES MUSSMAN Many student's belongings were stolen
    from the dormitory storage rooms this summer. In the Swartz 'D' wing storage
    room alone there were two portable typewriters, an electric typewriter, a
    braille type writer, and a speaker system stolen. According to Miss Judith

Heading: M.
Content: Judy, Director of University Residence Halls, the full extent of the losses is
    still not known, be cause students have not reported their losses to the
    University as yet. When asked about the security precautions taken to
    prevent theft from  the rooms, Miss Judy replied that the rooms are always
    kept locked. In some cases however, the Physical Plant, the custodians, the
    counselors, and members of the administration all carry master k eys' that
    will unlock the rooms. She went on to state that the Uni versity carries no
    type of insurance on the belongings stored over the summer by students, and
    that it cannot accept financial responsi bility for any losses. Mr. John F.
    Zeller, Vice Pres ident ol Business and Finance, stated that cases of theft
    are in creasing all over the campus. Last May several cars in Swartz park
    ing lot were broken into, and the various dorms are constantly hav ing
    furniture, mattresses and equip ment stolen from them. Both the music
    department and the audio visual aids laboratory have had ex pensive
    instruments and equipment taken. Mr. Zeller estimated that $15,000 is stolen
    annualy from the University. When asked about precautions students might
    take to prevent heavy financial loss in cases of theft, Mr. Zeller said that
    he be lieved the best way to protect ones self was to purchase some form of
    homeowner's or personal belong ing's insurance. He also urged all students
    to be watching for any in stances where theft is expected or suspected and
    report any unusual occurrances to the Physical Plant. 1-- << *

Heading: LriviaJ
Content: (Continued from Page 2) the leaf or themoral courage of the grape. Ah, then we
    would be able to return the woment to the Sem. Put sex back into the cellar
    is our cry. If this was the only complaint we would be happy. But no. Now
    the women run around all night without even the hint of a curfew. If God had
    wanted us to stay up late he would have given us headlights, or made the sun
    go down a good deal after sunset. Cut less from the discipline of tradition,
    we can expect the class of 1974 to bum out in about 1973. The first gray
    hair frazzles are be ginning to appear. Only if we act now can we help. Let
    us buckle down to our responsibilities and leave the fun for the future.
    Trivial returns next week: that's the column that, each week, ex poses the
    little-known facts about the University. Please don't be come a little-known
    reader in the process. Dig up some facts and send all unearthed trivialities
    to Box B-729 as soon as possible, c/o Trivial. Its life depends upon it.

Heading: SEPTEMBER 11, 1970
Content: 

Heading: THE BUCKNELLIAN
Content: 

Heading: PAGE THREE
Content: 

Heading: Sophs Suffer from Space Shortage
Content: 

Heading: Interview Dramatizes 'Close' Conditions of Fifth Trax
Content: By DAVID HAMMER Feature(r) Editor's Note: The fol lowing interview was conducted
    with four 'temporary' residents on the fifth floor of Trax Hall. Basical ly,
    the living conditions of those residents consist of two large rooms, housing
    students in bunkbeds (a situation similar to a barracks). Only two bathroom
    facilities exist, and closet space amounts to small locker space. It is in
    these crowded rooms that W, X, Y, and Z offered their views on their
    condition. It can be pointed out that the par ticipants' answers were honest
    and quite serious, and anyone doubting what one called the " absurd"  liv
    ing quarters herein described is extended an invitation to the Fifth Trax "
    Penthouse"  to discover the truth for himself. BUCK NELLI AN: Perhaps an in
    itial description of your predica ment here would be in order. W: It's a bad
    situation. Basically, there are thirty-five guys here; all but two are
    sophomores (those two are seniors). X : I'm in an upper bunk, and there's no
    screen in the window nearby. It may sound silly, but there are lights out
    the window which are on all night, and there must be 200 million flies, dead
    or otherwise, on the pillows, beds -- all over. W: There are two bathrooms,
    but one of them has no windows or ventilation whatsoever. And there are only
    two showers for the lot of us. Y: No blinds exist and there are lights
    outside the windows; it's just impossible to sleep most of the time. Coupled
    with the heat, the situation is unbearable. B: Where do you have a chance to
    study in close quarters such as these? W: With this many guys together,

Content: 

Heading: R I D E S
Content: 

Heading: Horses leave every
Content: 

Heading: evening 6:30, Monday
Content: 

Heading: through Thursday
Content: 

Heading: Call 523-0413

Heading: LIGGETTS
Content: 

Heading: RIDING STABLE
Content: there's no chance for studying here, as you can see. I go to the library. We
    have a couple of ath letes who have to get to bed early so, again, our
    chances are limited here. B: Could any place be reserved for studying until
    your conditions improve. Y : We asked our head resident if we could reserve
    desks at the library or in other campus build ings, and he said he'd try to
    find out. W: The room we're supposed to study in is filled with trunks. Part
    of the problem with studying is that you have to have the proper enviomment
    for it; and that en vironment includes rest at night, which we really don't
    often get. B. What 'human' problems come to mind relative to this mass
    grouping of people. Y : A lot of guys have 8 o'clocks and it's an almost
    impossible sit uation when half the room has to leave at the same time. It's
    not only bad for those who have to sleep, but the facilities, described
    earlier, don't really allow for everyone leaving at once. Some guys have to
    use closets in the next room, too, which doesn't help matters any. W: One
    thing is that there's been no stealing and everyone seems to get along,
    maybe because we're all in the same situation. Z: But, since nothing's
    locked, theft could develope -- not necesg- sarily on the part of those
    here, but anyone could really walk in any time, when you think about it.
    We've had people sleeping here who don't belong here, so access is
    relatively easy. We won't get to lock anything, either, because you can't
    make twenty keys for every body. It's not practical. B. Have those in
    'authority' been any consolation to you Y: Our - head resident, Turner,
    doesn't have many answers, but he certainly tries to find them for us. In
    that way, he's been our biggest aid here. W: Our head resident is doing OK,
    but I think Len (Smolen) or

Heading: 212-454-8800
Content: someone should've come up who knew how things were, and simply explain what's
    going to happen. Y : I agree. We'd like some an swers. Z: You can't really
    blame him (Smolen) for the situation, but some news on our predicament would
    be welcome from someone who may know what's happening W: We've had to find
    things out by way of a grapevine. B: Do you blame anyone in par ticular for
    the lack of housing on this campus and your cramped sit uation? W: How can
    you? They (the Ad missions office) have to protect themselves. They probably
    just didn't figure on so many people accepting the invitation to the Uni
    versity. And I don't think it's just to place blame on anyone. More freshmen
    came than they bargain ed for. You could almost say that they did a good
    job, considering. But, I will admit that, with my suitcases completely
    packed be cause of a lack of space here, I'm not totally overjoyed with this
    deal. Y : It seems like a laissez-faire attitude is being adopted -- noth
    ing's happening and it seems that no one is doing anything to help the
    situation. W: We've tried to see Len (Smo len) during freshman week, but I
    guess he was involved with Micro labs. When we've tried to see him he's been
    in meetings. Y : But you'd think our situation would be considered just as
    im perative, wouldn't you? B: What are your chances of leaving here soon
    and, if so, how will the departure be achieved? W: We're not sure about any
    thing, really. X : We've been told that the juniors and seniors who have
    rooms already are going to be 'wooed' into trailers across Route 15. B: What
    if they opt to retain their rooms? X: Then, We'll be moved out into the
    trailers, according to the priority list. Those who move out first would be
    those who had lower room numbers in the draw ing last spring. W: But we
    really don't know ex actly what will happen should the juniors and seniors
    refuse the trailers. I might add that we've been told that there are double
    rooms with only one resident now, and seven of us were supposedly going to
    be moved out, but we still have no word on that. 24 HOUR WRECKER

Heading: S-E-R-V-I-C-E
Content: 

Heading: BAKER'S
Content: 

Heading: BODY SHOP
Content: 

Heading: 1722 Market Street
Content: 

Heading: Lewisburg, Pa.
Content: 

Heading: Phone 523-9342
Content: B: Do you feel that you, as sophomores, were singled out for the consequences of
    this shortage? In other words, would you rather have been freshmen assigned
    to Ffith Trax as opposed to your selves? W: They had to give the fresh man
    'good' rooms in Kress and Trax, or they (the freshmen) would be totally
    disillusioned. But you'd think that, for a school that costs $3350 a year,
    we'd all get a better deal. I wouldn't normally expect this of the school.
    B: Are you paying the same boarding costs as other upperclass men? Y: No.
    The longer you stay here, the less you pay; but we weren't told any other
    facts. B: When were you told of your new residence? Was it early in the
    summer? Could you prepare for it? Y : I found out on August 25, because I
    was here and I asked. W: Well, we had to be here the third <of September),
    so I think I found out a week or so before. B: Didn't you receive any
    letters concerning the impending situa tion? Y: We were notified throughout
    the summer of the lack of rooms but were not told where we would eventually
    be placed. W: This must be the first time it's ever happened here -- thi:
    much of a shortage. We feel that an obligation hasn't been fulfilled. After
    all, we've been here a yea: already, but it still seems like we've made no
    progress. It's worse this year than last -- just look. People over there
    (points to Vaughan and Marts) ought to take a few business courses. B: It
    seems that the men this year were worse off than the wo men residents. Do
    you feel that this could have been remedied in any way? W: I can't
    understand why girl's singles in the B-wing of Swartz Hall were not made
    into doubles, as were the men's singles in A- wing of that hall. Then maybe
    there would be more space for us. One thing's for sure; we'll be ready for
    the army. We feel like we're in it now. And I'm  serious. * * * (Editor's
    Note: This interview was conducted on Monday, Sept ember 7, and speaks to
    the con ditions as they stood at that time.)

Heading: Footnotes
Content: Py PAUL J. J. PAYACK THE SCIENCE FICTION HALL OF FAME By Isaac Asimov et al.
    Edited by Robert Silverberg. 558 pages. Garden City: Double day. $6.95.
    According to Isaac Asimov, the American phenomenon of scientific fiction has
    developed through three stages. The first emerged an 1926 when Hugo
    Gernsback founded Amazing Stories. This was the first publication devoted to
    the genre. At the time readers were sparse and writers scarce; so when
    Gernsback was not reprinting Wells and Verne, he was depending upon the
    talents of enthusiastic, yet inexperienced writers. The result was an
    inundation of voyages extraordinaries, exotic adventures with little hard
    science. The second stage evolved slowly out of the first as writers gained
    experience and readers sophistication. By 1938, when John Campbell assumed
    the editorship of AS, technical exactitude was demanded. Years before the
    fact, the faithful learned of atomic energy. Naturally Asimov labels this
    the technological stage. The present stage of development (1950-) has
    managed to re tain the technical sophistication of the previous stage while
    em phasizing the sociological implications of the future (humanoid's
    relation to the humanoid). Now, if you're interested in studying this
    evolutionary trend in depth, The Science Fiction Hall of Fame is an
    excellent place to begin. The quality of the selections, if you accept the
    subtitle, is not only great, but The Greatest Science Fiction Stories of All
    Time. This rather bold assertion is made by the Science Fiction Writers of
    America (who also did the writing). As anyone familiar with the genre knows,
    every year this group distributes Nebula Awards for the best work falling in
    each of four categories: novel, novella, novelet (stretching the point), and
    short story. Since the Association was not in existence before the mid-60's
    (and hence no awards), it was decided to confer similar honors on the best
    of what was previously written. Names were nominated, votes voted and the
    Tesult for the under 15,000 word category was The Hall of Fame, ergo its
    claim to greatness. Pacing the vote, the all-time greatest is Asimov's
    Nightfall, the story of the end of a world. And then there's Martian
    Odessey, by Stanley G. Weinbaum. Following is Keye's classical standard (and
    recent motion picture, Charly), Flowers for Algernon; after that,
    Microcosmic God by Theodore Sturgeon. Of the better known authors, Robert
    Heinlein, Arthur C. Clarke and John Campbell placed highly. In all, there
    are 26 stories by 26 writers; so in that conglomeration you ought to find a
    few to your liking. And in the process you'll learn of and about silicon
    life, the Neoterics, God's nine billion names, Martian phenomenology, and
    how, by decipher ing a few lines from Alice in Wonderland, two kids escape
    reality.

Heading: 501 MARKET STREET

Heading: LEWISBURG, PA.
Content: 

Heading: Volunteer Services Re-organized
Content: 

Heading: CA Undergoes Expansion
Content: 

Heading: Happenings o f Note
Content: By NICKI DREW The volunteer program  of " Con cern through Action"  underwent a
    double change this summer. Not only has dt expanded the number of
    opportunities open to potential volunteers, it has made plans for a new
    concept in " volunteerism." In past years the University's volunteer
    services have been lim ited to a sm all group of institu tions, such as
    Laurelton and Selins- grove Hospitals. These program s all involved a number
    of students whose task was simply that of a friend to one individual
    patient. This year, in addition to these opportunities, the Volunteer Serv
    ices is offering a greater variety of placements, with a wide range of
    required tim e, experience, and committment. Included among these positions
    are: drivers who transport volun teers, observers in hospital social service
    agencies, companions for lonely patients, and eventually ap prentice case
    workers under the Child W elfare County Council. Along with this expansion
    of op portunity, the Volunteer Services hopes to establish a functioning
    campus - community & volunteer agency which would satisfy much of the
    community's needs as well as offering the student a chance for self-fulfillm
    ent. Under this plan, a full-tim e office would be used where people on and
    off campus could find positions and institutions could find volunteers. The
    eventual hope is that the ag ency, under the guidance of a board composed of
    students, fac ulty, and mem bers of the com munity, would be able to begin
    com pletely independent programs. In addition to the expansion of the
    program 's opportunities, the Volunteer Services is attempting to change the
    level of the Volun teer work itself. Instead of basing the program on "
    friendship" , as has been the custom  in the past, the leaders of the
    Volunteer Serv ices, Mike Derm an and Joan Ger- rity, are trying to make the
    pro gram more professional in its ap proach and thus more effective. For the
    first time, students will have the opportunity to work closely with
    professional psycholo gists and sociologists. In addition, the jobs open to
    them will be more challenging and will require more skill and dedication.
    The result will be a more serious and professional type of program which
    will not only benefit the patient, but also will give the Student a real
    flavor of social work. This added expertise will bring with it added
    responsibility, ac cording to the program's two lead ers. To be effective,
    the volun teers must work with their client regularly and continually evalu-
    ate ar.d improve their techniques. " Being a volunteer" , in the words of
    Mike Derm an, " should not be thought of as just another activity because
    you are dealing with people who need your help." Both leaders emphasized
    that although the volunteer work in the past has 'been excellent, there is
    room for improvement, and that is the basis for the changes and ex pansions
    which are now taking place. " Good volunteerism just isn't that easy,"  says
    Mike Derman. " There's more to to it than just an hour and a half of being
    your self with an underprivileged per son. You have to be aware of the
    person you are trying to help and what you can do for him."

Heading: ABS Notes
Content: Any upperclass student desiring to run for a post as an ABS Living Unit
    Representative must give his name to the resident director of his dormitory;
    Gerry Commerford, Assistant Dean of Fraternity Men; or the Dean of Student
    Affairs Of fice. Also include telephone and box numbers and living unit,
    i.e. dormitory or fraternity house. The deadline for submitting names is
    Monday, September 14 at 12 noon. * * * Any student desiring to be ap pointed
    to the Board of Review of Academic Responsibility must pick up an interest
    sheet at the Dean of Student Affairs Office. It must be returned by
    Wednesday, September 16 at 4:30 p.m. Any questions about the duties of this
    office, call Sue Preston, 3270.

Heading: ABS Plans
Content: (Continued from Page 1) ilar to the one held last year. A point was made that
    faculty members enjoyed the informal, personal relationship they experi
    enced with students during Strike week last year and would like the students
    to help create the same atmosphere agaain. They would also like to see the
    ABS take more initiative in proposing what areas should be investigated by
    the Uni versity community. Also to com e under ABS con sideration this year
    will be the black studies program, ROTC, the budgets of athletic and music
    de partments, the student general fee, the dining hall situation, rising Bi
    son prices, inter-dormitory com munication and goverance, and the newly
    revised Senate proposal. At its next meeting, the Congress will elect a new
    recording secre tary and two members to serve on the Board of Review of
    Academic Responsibility. They will also re view the new judicial procedure
    document. The procedure is await ing ABS approval before its im plementation
    by Dr. Charles H. Watts III, University president.

Heading: Flu Program
Content: The University is once again, providing " flu"  shots for all in terested
    students, faculty, admin istration, and employees. The Medical Service urges
    all to take advantage of this service. The complete program will involve two
    injections given at two to three weeks intervals. The program will begin
    Sept ember 15th at the Ziegler Dispen sary from 9-11 a.m. and 1-4 p.m.,
    Tuesday through Friday. Kindly adhere to the hours listed. . Persons
    allergic to eggs are not advised to take the injections.

Heading: Beethoven's Fourth
Content: As part of the University music department's participation in the international
    observance oi the 200th anniversary of Beethoven's birth, Professor William
    D. McRae will present a lecture-recital in Vaughan Literature auditorium at
    8:1 pun., Tuesday.

Heading: Senior Gift
Content: (Continued from  Page 1) He said, " It will be a significant gift used in a
    relevant, important w ay." He suggested the funds could be used to form a
    communications Department, to pay the salaries of professors in a Black
    Studies pro gram, or for scholarships. Sengstack emphasized, " the class
    gift is one of the few opportunities available to students (or alumni) to
    have a voice, a direct influence on their school. In helping with the drive
    students can both work for the entire class and see that some thing they
    want will happen." Seniors are needed to organize the campaign, which is
    conducted in collaboration with the Depart ment of Development. " Each vol
    unteer must be committed to the drive, but it will not take a great deal of
    time,"  according to Jeff, who hopes to see half the class working on the
    campaign event ually. Interested persons should contact Sengstack at B194.

    the dialogue-sermon " Not the Resurrection Again!"  A coffee hour will
    follow. The Chapel Committee will also meet this Sunday at 4 p.m. in the
    meditation room. New members are welcomed.

Heading: Thundering Herd Hastens

Heading: Toward Long Hard Season
Content: 

Heading: P R E S S  B O X
Content: -B y DAN M ILLER; By BOB WENDEL As the University begins a new year, the average
    college student immediately has thoughts of the " big gam e,"  but judging
    from  this year's football schedule, that game probably w ill never occur.
    One football rating organization has chosen the BU Bisons to lose nine of
    its ten games, with the one remaining contest, against Temple on September
    19 in the season's opener, to be a " toss-up." Although pegged to lose nine
    gam es, the point spreads in these contests are not large, making way for
    som e really exciting battles. The biggest reason for the sea son's rather
    dim outlook can be contributed to the schedule. Pren- der's squad has two
    gam es with tough Southern teams: Davidson and The Citadel. The Citadel, a m
    ilitary school, has had good football for a number of years, and is a
    possible confer ence champion. No one will ever forget the Wit tenberg game,
    played here last year for Parent's Weekend. This year's opponent from  the
    Ohio con ference is Baldwdn-Wallace instead, which is the team  which yearly
    fights it out with Wittenberg for their conference title. Although the MAC
    no longer ex ists as a football conference, the schedule has retained the
    usual MAC rivals. Heading the list are Delaware and Lehigh, both of whom
    beat the Thundering Herd last year, and figure to be stronger this year.
    Finishing up the schedule is Rutgers, which just recently has becom e a sm
    all Eastern power house. With all this power lined up against the Herd, it
    would seem quite a task for the Bisons to put up a good showing. However,
    Coach Fred Prender is optim istic. " The guys are in the best pos sible
    shape they could be in phys ically. My staff and I are now working on the
    mental readiness of the club." " We feel we have a much better ball team
    than at this time last year, and we've had very few  in juries." The three
    boys who have been injured are all sophomores and all have had leg problem
    s. Roy Churchman and Rich Zentd both required operations on their knees, and
    will be out for the season. Gerry Solomon should be back in the line-up
    shortly. How well the team  will actually do still remains to be seen.
    Praac- tice this year has 'been lim ited due to early matriculation, and the
    50 man squad is sm aller than last years. However, Coach Prender feels that
    he has, " the nucleus of a very good football team ; they are big ger,
    quicker, m ore dedicated, and m ore mature than last year's squad. If we get
    a few breaks, and stay healthy, we are going to upset a few  team s."
    Concerning this years probable starters, G reg Doviak w ill once again be
    assuming the quarterback position, with Don Giacom elli and John Newman at
    the halfback spots. On defense, four fam iliar names are indicative of a
    strong return ing attack. Tarras Qnishencko and C. B. M ansfield will be
    holding down two of the linebacker spots, while Gene Depew on the line and
    Gene Lucarelli at safety round out the quartet. Last evening, in a closed
    scrim m age, the Bisons showed a rather potent offensive attack, as they
    scored four times. Two of the tal lies cam e on long pass plays, while the
    other two were short runs. Looking extrem ely tough on of fense were end,
    Bob Ciperson, and fullback Mitch Farhstein. What will occur this season
    still remains to 'be seen, but if Coach Prem ier's optimism is any indica
    tion, 1970 stacks up to be a very interesting year, win or lose.

Heading: Wrestling
Content: All those interested in intercol legiate wrestling meet at 8:00 P. M., Monday,
    September 14 in class room  201, Davis Gymnasium. Those interested in acting
    in the capacity of a manager are also welcom e. The football season is now
    upon us and the Thundering Herd finds itself without an athletic confer
    ence. The Middle Atlantic Confer ence University division has been disbanded
    and BU joins the ranks of the independent football powers. GDI if you
    prefer. * * Ib is means of course that BU thus lodges into a category with
    Notre Dame and Rho Alpha Mu, two other m ajor independents. * One wonders in
    this same vein whether The Herd will follow the lead of the Fighting Irish
    and de murely wait 30-odd years before accepting a bowl bid. We feel certain
    that when and if the opportunity presented itfcelf for the Bison gridmen to
    journey to a post season tilt, the sophistication of the BU organization
    would be put to the test. * * For exam ple, the mangy m ascot that stumbles
    around the friendly confines of M emorial Stadium will have to be replaced
    by the real thing (although the last Bison in Buffalo Valley was shot in
    1800 thus precluding the possibility of obtain-
