Heading: Pennsylvania's Fiscal Situation
Content: 

Heading: Threatens Student Scholarships
Content: 

Heading: Underground Movie Series
Content: 

Heading: Scheduled by Senior Class
Content: By CATHLEEN EVANS "Confrontation at Kent State," to be shown for no admission
    this Sat urday at 8:00 p.m., will be the first of seven "underground" movies
    of fered by the Class of 1971. It is a documentary made by students and
    professors as a "public service," containing interviews with local Kent
    citizens who approved of the Guard's actions, a still photo dis play of the
    events of May 4, 1970, and interviews with student, faculty and Guard
    participants. "Brand X" (March 4), reviewed in the New York Times as "a
    tacky, vulgar, dirty, somewhat dull, often hilarious movie" which shows the
    absurdity of today's media, "pretends to be a series of tele vision
    commercials, panel shows, dramas and news broadcasts." It stars Taylor Mead,
    who "by simple breathing, is an affront to all vested interests," with spot
    appearances by Sally Kirkland, Frank Cavestani, Abbie Hoffman and Sam
    Shepard. "It's the application of Fellini to content." "Contemporary
    community stand ards" will be put to the test with the showing of "Coming
    Apart' (March 10), a film which is "very blunty singularly preoccupied with
    naked bodies and uses to which those bodies can be put by libidin ous human
    beings." Probably a take-off from "David Holman's Diary," the movie stars
    Rip Torn as a psychiatrist "coming apart" from reality and Sally Kirkland as
    his mistress. A critic for life com ments, "While it may or not have been
    made in the spirit of art, it has the effect of art--and very troubling art
    at that." Jean Luc-Godard's film "Sym pathy for the Devil" (1 plus 1 (April
    10) stars the Rolling Stones de veloping the music of "Beggars Banquet" to
    bizarre scenes and off-scene voices quoting Le Roi Jones, Stokley
    Carmichael, Eld- ridge Cleaver, Hitler, etc, as a comment on Black Power and
    the state-of-the-revolution. By ROBERT WENDEL Recently, in the "state of the
    state" message presented by Pen nsylvania's Gov.-elect Milton Shapp, mention
    was made of the possible elimination of state aid to students attending
    institutions of higher ed ucation, effective this semester. Although
    superficially of little consequence, since the legislature is the one who
    doles out the money, the statements have initiated a great deal of
    speculation on the part of students and universities alike. The problem is
    compounded by the fact that last year the state was four months delinquent
    in pay ing the recipient institutions, and the present outright admission of
    financial hardship has caused some out of state schools to simply de mand
    that those Pennsylvania stu dents affected pay out of their own pocket or
    risk being dropped from the school's registration lists. Even within the
    state the lack of funds is causing some difficulty. Penn State is especially
    hard hit, and before the funds actually be come available, it is very
    possible that a loss approaching one million dollars could be realized by
    State. This loss will come in the form of interest due on the money that
    will necessarily have to be borrowed in order to keep the schools open. As
    regards this University, Dean John C. Hayward emphasized that as far as the
    Bursar's office is concerned, all students have been credited with their
    PHEAA money, under the assumption that the state will come through with the
    funds. However, there are some obvious problems lurking around the comer
    (Continued on Page 4)

Heading: ABS Backs Motion,
Content: 

Heading: Urges \o Parietals
Content: By PAMELA MAY In its Wednesday meeting the As sociation of Bucknell Students pas
    sed a motion by Bob Nachshin con cerning visitation hours in the resi dence
    halls. It reads: "Until such time as the coed liv ing situation is evaluated
    by the Dean of Student Affairs' Office: "The ABS requests that Presi dent
    Watts immediately eliminate the University's Parietal Hour re strictions and
    that, during the period preceding the completion of the Dean's evaluation,
    each Living Unit be empowered to determine its own visitation policy." In
    his rationale, Nachshin stated he found the present situation "un
    believable" when "other schools comparable to us--intellectually,
    academically -- have managed to have twenty-four hour open dorms and it's
    worked very, very well." (Continued on Page 4) <<#########I-- #########>> >>

Heading: Apartheid and Polaroid
Content: 

Heading: It is generally recognized that the
Content: 

Heading: military is engaged in antisocial activi
Content: 

Heading: ties. However, it is most important to
Content: 

Heading: note that most large-scale, non-military,
Content: 

Heading: industry does as much to inhibit social
Content: 

Heading: progress. Only very recently has indus
Content: 

Heading: try developed an attitude of "environ
Content: 

Heading: mental protection." Of course, many
Content: 

Heading: corporations, while extolling the bene
Content: 

Heading: fits of controlling pollution, still con
Content: 

Heading: tinue to pollute and to fight the Environ
Content: 

Heading: mental Protection Agency. There are
Content: 

Heading: also other forms of antisocial behavior
Content: 

Heading: in which big business engages.
Content: 

Heading: Polaroid Corporation manufactures
Content: 

Heading: instant color identification systems. A
Content: 

Heading: present model, ID-2, takes two photo
Content: 

Heading: graphs: one of a person and one of an
Content: 

Heading: identification document, and in sixty
Content: 

Heading: seconds ejects a plastic ID card. This
Content: 

Heading: system is now being used in South
Content: 

Heading: Africa to produce fifteen million pass
Content: 

Heading: books. All blacks in the society must
Content: 

Heading: carry these identification papers at all
Content: 

Heading: times or be subject to arrest and prosecu
Content: 

Heading: tion.
Content: 

Heading: Although Polaroid has registered
Content: 

Heading: the demands of black workers who are
Content: 

Heading: urging the discontinuation of ID-2 sales
Content: 

Heading: to South Africa, Polaroid is still trying
Content: 

Heading: to maintain a liberal corporate image.
Content: 

Heading: On January 12 of this year full page
Content: 

Heading: ads were taken out at great expense in
Content: 

Heading: several major papers including: New
Content: 

Heading: York Times, Wall Street Journal, and
Content: 

Heading: Washington Post as well as in twenty
Content: 

Heading: black newspapers. The ad, entitled "An
Content: 

Heading: Experiment in South Africa," reported
Content: 

Heading: that the company was trying to help
Content: 

Heading: South African blacks. Since even the
Content: 

Heading: Polaroid Corporation must abide by the
Content: 

Heading: Apartheid policies, this claim is doubt
Content: 

Heading: ful. And, while Polaroid reports having
Content: 

Heading: stopped sales of ID-2 to South Africa,
Content: 

Heading: in actuality it sells the system to its
Content: 

Heading: distributor, Frank and Hirsch Company,
Content: 

Heading: which, in turn, sells ID-2 to South
Content: 

Heading: Africa.
Content: 

Heading: Science and technology are misused
Content: 

Heading: in many ways. The exploitation of poor
Content: 

Heading: nations and minority groups as well as
Content: 

Heading: the environment can be ended. However,
Content: 

Heading: strong public action is needed. One of
Content: 

Heading: the most powerful weapons the consumer
Content: 

Heading: has is his money. Unless firms are hit
Content: 

Heading: where it hurts, antisocial behavior will
Content: 

Heading: continue to proliferate in industry simply
Content: 

Heading: because it is profitable.
Content: 

Heading: The black workers of the Polaroid
Content: 

Heading: Corporation have called for a worldwide
Content: 

Heading: boycott of Polaroid products to force the
Content: 

Heading: company to discontinue its sales of ID-2
Content: 

Heading: to South Africa. We urge support of this
Content: 

Heading: boycott.
Content:

Heading: GUEST COLUMN
Content: 

Heading: Jan Plan Faults
Content: 

Heading: -By CHARLES MUSSMAN-
Content: 

Heading: This year, as last year, a certain proportion of students spent Jan
Content: 

Heading: uary doing a project which was most probably interesting, satisfying,
Content: 

Heading: educational (whatever that means), and enjoyable. A greater proportion
Content: 

Heading: of students spent the time vacationing, working, or finishing up the
Content: 

Heading: courses they had left over from last semester. Those students who were
Content: 

Heading: "officially registered" for projects and completed them satisfactorily
Content: 

Heading: (so what can be unsatisfactory about a trip to Europe?) will have a
Content: 

Heading: permanent record of their achievements placed on their transcripts (to
Content: 

Heading: impress employers, graduate schools, and friends and neighbors).
Content: 

Heading: Those students who loafed, finished up work that should have been
Content: 

Heading: completed last semester, or had a heavy round of prospective graduate
Content: 

Heading: schools or summer employers to visit will have no such record of their
Content: 

Heading: actions during January on their transcripts. As most faculty and stu
Content: 

Heading: dents would agree, this is only fair. However, because of the bureau
Content: 

Heading: cratic nature of the way "official" Jan Plans are processed and recorded,
Content: 

Heading: some students do not get a fair chance to have their transcripts em
Content: 

Heading: bellished. Here are two hypothetical examples of what can and probably
Content: 

Heading: does happen.
Content: 

Heading: In November a student registeres for the project in photography. He
Content: 

Heading: decides to buy a fairly expensive Japanese camera--from a company
Content: 

Heading: in Japan. He orders the camera early in December, but when he arrives
Content: 

Heading: in January the camera is somewhere between Osaka and Lewisburg.
Content: 

Heading: After waiting a few days, this student decides that since he is here he
Content: 

Heading: might as well spend his time profitably while waiting for the camera,
Content: 

Heading: and so he decides to sit in on a computer programming course. At the
Content: 

Heading: end of January (when the camera arrives) this student knows BASIC
Content: 

Heading: (a computer language) but gets an "unsatisfactory" in his photography
Content: 

Heading: Jan Plan. He goes and explains'his predicament to the registar fully
Content: 

Heading: expecting everything to be OK. However, as most of you have already
Content: 

Heading: guessed, he cannot get the computer course recorded on his transcript,
Content: 

Heading: because he was not "officially registered" for that course.
Content: 

Heading: Meanwhile, another student is sitting at home "vacationing." What
Content: 

Heading: should arrive at his home but the Special Introductory Offer of the Book
Content: 

Heading: of the Month Club: a ten volume set of the Story of Civilization by Prof.
Content: 

Heading: Will Durant and his wife. So, having nothing special to do, this student
Content: 

Heading: starts reading Our Oriental Heritage (the first volume; 1000-plus pages)
Content: 

Heading: to see what it's like. In two weeks he's finished that and gone on to H ie
Content: 

Heading: Life of Greece, which he also finishes. The student returns to campus
Content: 

Heading: and during a conversation with his advisor happens to mention what he
Content: 

Heading: did over January. The professor is intrigued, and asks the student why
Content: 

Heading: he didn't make that his January Program.
Content: 

Heading: Of course, in neither of these cases could the student get any credit
Content: 

Heading: for his work during January. It seem s too bad that there can't be some
Content: 

Heading: sort of Jan Plan registration and evaluation "after the fact" for those
Content: 

Heading: in special circumstances who feel that their intercession was spent in
Content: 

Heading: a profitable endeavor.
Content: 

Heading: :THE SIDESHOW :
Content: 

Heading: Vacation at Home
Content: 

Heading: -By DAVID WEINBERGER;
Content: 

Heading: with person after person suggest
Content: 

Heading: ing organized plans which would
Content: 

Heading: express the concern of the entire
Content: 

Heading: University, while I'm sure the Uni
Content: 

Heading: versity, as a whole, is not con
Content: 

Heading: cerned. The winning idea, which
Content: 

Heading: was suhmitted with only half-serious
Content: 

Heading: intentions, but which was loudly
Content: 

Heading: accepted when people realized it
Content: 

Heading: was getting late and they'd better
Content: 

Heading: decide something in a hurry, was
Content: 

Heading: to have 300 people march on the
Content: 

Heading: Federal Building, armed with their
Content: 

Heading: prepared statement to the press,
Content: 

Heading: in the hopes of getting arrested.
Content: 

Heading: Of course, the best idea of the
Content: 

Heading: evening was completely overlooked
Content: 

Heading: and ignored (and this is the second
Content: 

Heading: point to which I referred). That
Content: 

Heading: idea, a very old one, was for all
Content: 

Heading: males to send back their draft
Content: 

Heading: cards -- an action which, to me,
Content: 

Heading: shows more courage and more con
Content: 

Heading: cern than being arrested with 299
Content: 

Heading: other people for loitering.
Content: 

Heading: But, lest we forget the tone of
Content: 

Heading: this meeting, we must realize that
Content: 

Heading: 300 people being arrested together
Content: 

Heading: is much more glamorous than 300
Content: 

Heading: individuals separately sending back
Content: 

Heading: their draft cards. Besides, if you
Content: 

Heading: put yourself in a group of 300
Content: 

Heading: people who are supposed to be
Content: 

Heading: concerned, you actually might start
Content: 

Heading: believing it about yourself, too.
Content: 

Heading: George Lane '72
Content: 

Heading: Dispensary
Content: 

Heading: To the Editor:
Content: 

Heading: This letter is in regard to a re
Content: 

Heading: cent emergency situation which
Content: 

Heading: was ignored by the BuckneU Dis
Content: 

Heading: pensary.
Content: 

Heading: At six o'clock Sunday morning,
Content: 

Heading: January 17, 1971, a call was made
Content: 

Heading: to the infirmary requesting the
Content: 

Heading: name of an oral surgeon in the
Content: 

Heading: area. This caU was made after the
Content: 

Heading: student's doctor at home had been
Content: 

Heading: notified and had stressed the need
Content: 

Heading: for immediate emergency treat
Content: 

Heading: ment. Treatment was needed for
Content: 

Heading: bleeding of the mouth foUowing
Content: 

Heading: oral surgery, and at the time the
Content: 

Heading: caU was placed, the student had
Content: 

Heading: been bleeding excessively for four
Content: 

Heading: hours.
Content: 

Heading: The reaction of the person on
Content: 

Heading: duty at the infirmary was less than
Content: 

Heading: satisfactory; first, by her insis
Content: 

Heading: tence that the student would not
Content: 

Heading: be able to receive any help on Sun
Content: 

Heading: day, and secondly because, as she
Content: 

Heading: stated, she was in bed. Her only
Content: 

Heading: help was to name a dentist in
Content: 

Heading: Lewisburg.
Content: 

Heading: A call to Evangelical Hospital
Content: 

Heading: was reacted to sinularily. The stu
Content: 

Heading: dent's next action was to caU Gei-
Content: 

Heading: singer Medical Center in Danville
Content: 

Heading: where fortunately emergency treat
Content: 

Heading: ment was immediately and cheer
Content: 

Heading: fully administered.
Content: 

Heading: This letter is to inform the Buck-
Content: 

Heading: nell community that the services of
Content: 

Heading: the BuckneU Dispensary are in
Content: 

Heading: adequate for the students' needs.
Content: 

Heading: It is also an appeal to the adminis
Content: 

Heading: tration for action to be taken at
Content: 

Heading: once to rectify the situation where-
Content: 

Heading: (Continued on Page 3)
Content: 

Heading: !Lenny passed the wine over. Lenny, with short hair and a bushy
Content: 

Heading: beard, is into cheap wine instead of drugs. He has also stopped writing
Content: 

Heading: poetry about anything except poUtics. Billy clubs and Uberation are
Content: 

Heading: broken up into lines by every punctuation mark, and Lenny calls them
Content: 

Heading: poems.
Content: 

Heading: When Lenny and I went to high school together, Lenny used to write
Content: 

Heading: sloppy, sentimental poetry. He was the romantic, and I was the hard
Content: 

Heading: bitten reaUst. We would argue not about whether or not we would have
Content: 

Heading: a fast against the War, but rather over why we should have the fast. He
Content: 

Heading: was in favor of it because it would spiritually renew us; I was in favor of
Content: 

Heading: it because it would prompt support of our other actions.
Content: 

Heading: Then Lenny and almost all my other high school friends went to
Content: 

Heading: Wisconsin University with 20,000 other students. Mike roUed up his over
Content: 

Heading: alls to show me the scar he received when he vaulted over a wall to
Content: 

Heading: "escape the pigs" during the riots at Wisconsin. He says he's out of the
Content: 

Heading: draft because of the injury. We all laughed because life is sometimes
Content: 

Heading: funny like that.
Content: 

Heading: I hadn't seen my friends from high school for a year, so we thought
Content: 

Heading: we'd have a lot to say to each other. But the way it worked out, 1
Content: 

Heading: walked into their gathering by myself, kicking over a half-filled bottle
Content: 

Heading: bottle of dollar wine. "You haven't changed," they said, so there was
Content: 

Heading: nothing new that I could tell them.
Content: 

Heading: Joe had switched to wire rims sometime during last year, and he
Content: 

Heading: was smoking a cigarette. I'd never seen him smoke one before, or
Content: 

Heading: maybe I had. No, I think not. He turned to m e when I sat down next to
Content: 

Heading: him, while the rest of the crowd talked about people that I didn't know.
Content: 

Heading: But Joe didn't say anything. "How are you?" I asked. "Pretty good,"
Content: 

Heading: he said after a moment of deliberation. "Good," I said. We looked at
Content: 

Heading: the wine bottles.
Content: 

Heading: Coltrane
Content: 

Heading: Joe is living with four other guys and three girls out on a farm.
Content: 

Heading: When I knew him he was just a step past collecting baseball cards.
Content: 

Heading: Jane and Kathy sat on the floor, legs crossed, calves stacked on
Content: 

Heading: each other like pancakes, butter pat hair melting down. I looked at
Content: 

Heading: them. Joe looked at the record player and said, "Coltrane," a magic
Content: 

Heading: word, the title of the book of my friends. I had to rely on one of my
Content: 

Heading: most trusted magic words: I said, "Oh."
Content: 

Heading: Looking for a red wane, I sat down next to Fat Andy. He still had
Content: 

Heading: gray dirt packed into the crease between his chins and his shoulders.
Content: 

Heading: He told me that his rock and roll group was cutting a record and that
Content: 

Heading: oh yes he had dropped out of school. Fat Andy had always been a good
Content: 

Heading: blues guitarist, playing a hundred dollar red Hagstrom guitar, the "on-
Content: 

Heading: off" labels peeling off.
Content: 

Heading: He told me that Marsha was married, but I didn't remember who
Content: 

Heading: Marsha was, until he reminded me that she was the star of our high
Content: 

Heading: school play. He also told me about Bill, a friend who goes to Harvard.
Content: 

Heading: In elementary school Bill thought that he was a dinosaur. Now he's
Content: 

Heading: going into psychological warfare.
Content: 

Heading: I asked Lenny how he was, expecting to find out about his grades,
Content: 

Heading: his courses, his sex life. He said, "Well, I'm living out on a farm now
Content: 

Heading: and it's beautiful. I'm finding out how beautiful people can be, how you
Content: 

Heading: can love people in a way that keeps on growing. We're out there all
Content: 

Heading: alone with 200 acres for our back yard, with docks and geese and goats.
Content: 

Heading: And a turtle named Smarks. We helped a neighbor slaughter a pig last
Content: 

Heading: week. I'm just out there reading and writing an awful lot. Writing a lot.
Content: 

Heading: And I'm in love with a girl out there. What a beautiful chick. I've never
Content: 

Heading: felt so wonderful or so strong. I feel like I'm ready to take on anything."
Content: 

Heading: He didn't stop once, or pause. A used-car salesman talk. But maybe
Content: 

Heading: not. Who am I to evaluate Lenny's life? But then again, how can I
Content: 

Heading: evaluate mine when it has been called into question by talks like
Content: 

Heading: Lenny's, without evaluating his? I gave up and realized that Lenny and
Content: 

Heading: I are not the same people.
Content: 

Heading: The day before I had gone back to my high school as the day
Content: 

Heading: emptied and the halls were clearing. I didn't know anyone except for
Content: 

Heading: a few teachers. And with them, how can I know how to stand when I
Content: 

Heading: speak, or how many curse words I'm allowed? The gravel voice of the
Content: 

Heading: assistant principal excused the students from work day #76, and I drove
Content: 

Heading: home behind the filled yellow busses.
Content: 

Heading: Lenny and Joe and Andy haven't gone back to our high school. When
Content: 

Heading: I left the party we had to shake hands instead of just waving.
Content:

Heading: THE BUCKNELLIAN PLATFORM
Content: To review any issue and take a stand we deem in the best interest of the
    University, to treat every issue with the responsibility that Is accorded US
    in a free society, to be constructively critical when necessary as well as
    lauda tory when appropriate, and to print the news with accuracy and
    integrity. Editorials appearing on this page reflect the consensus opinion
    of. the editorial board and that of the editors. Signed columns present the

Heading: views
Content: only of the authors. All letters should be adressed to the Editor, and must be
    received no later than Saturday noon for publication in the Tuesday edition
    and Wednes day noon for publication in the Friday edition. AU letters must
    be signed and typed double-spaced: however, names may withheld upon request.
    The Editor reserves the right to choose aU letters for publication, and to
    edit any letter chosen for reasons of space restrictions, grammatical change

Heading: To the Editor:
Content: 

Heading: Only today (January 29, 1971) did
Content: 

Heading: I see the December 11, 1970 issue
Content: 

Heading: MW
Content: 

Heading: of The Bucknellian, which carried
Content: 

Heading: a letter by Andrew Higgins at
Content: 

Heading: tempting to refute my column deal
Content: 

Heading: ing with national defense.
Content: 

Heading: Mr. Higgins claims I used false
Content: 

Heading: statistics, and quotes from the
Content: 

Heading: Scientific American in his attempt
Content: 

Heading: to prove that contention. There is
Content: 

Heading: actually no significant difference
Content: 

Heading: between my statistics and those Mr.
Content: 

Heading: Higgins quotes.
Content: 

Heading: My article said the U.S. has 1,000
Content: 

Heading: sm all ICBMS and 54 early model
Content: 

Heading: ICBMs (there was a printing error
Content: 

Heading: in The Buckneltian, not in the
Content: 

Heading: mimeographed text of my column
Content: 

Heading: that turned 1,000 into 100), totalling
Content: 

Heading: 1,054, the identical figure offered
Content: 

Heading: by Scientific American.
Content: 

Heading: As did Scientific American, I said
Content: 

Heading: the U.S. had 656 submarine based
Content: 

Heading: m issiles. I gave figures that would
Content: 

Heading: total 1100 ICBMs for the USSR,
Content: 

Heading: while Scientific American gives a
Content: 

Heading: figure of 250 more m issiles for
Content: 

Heading: them than that. Scientific American
Content: 

Heading: said the USSR had 205 sub-based
Content: 

Heading: m issiles, I said 280.
Content: 

Heading: The Scientific American article
Content: 

Heading: appeared in
Content: 

Heading: January
Content: 

Heading: 1970.
Content: 

Heading: My
Content: 

Heading: source was a U.S. News and World
Content: 

Heading: Report article of October 19, 1970.
Content: 

Heading: so I suggest that my more current
Content: 

Heading: statistics account for the difference
Content: 

Heading: there.
Content: 

Heading: Higgins neglects to include in his
Content: 

Heading: comparison the 300 sub launched
Content: 

Heading: cruise missiles of the Soviets that
Content: 

Heading: I mentioned in my article (these
Content: 

Heading: are m issiles a sub launches after
Content: 

Heading: surfacing), and gives the mislead
Content: 

Heading: ing statistic that the U.S. has 2,144
Content: 

Heading: bombers to Russia's 600. That latter
Content: 

Heading: statistic is accurate only if one
Content: 

Heading: counts medium range and tactical
Content: 

Heading: bombers, which I specifically did
Content: 

Heading: not mention in my article. Most of
Content: 

Heading: these bombers could not reach the
Content: 

Heading: Soviet Union unless stationed in
Content: 

Heading: Europe or Asia, and many of them
Content: 

Heading: are not armed with nuclear weap
Content: 

Heading: ons.
Content: 

Heading: In sum, the great differences Mr.
Content: 

Heading: Higgins would like the reader to
Content: 

Heading: believe exist between his figures
Content: 

Heading: and mine are really not so great,
Content: 

Heading: and my figures are the more cur
Content: 

Heading: rent and more directly relevant to
Content: 

Heading: nuclear strength.
Content: 

Heading: Mr. Higgins throws in MIRVs in
Content: 

Heading: a further attempt at refutation. He
Content: 

Heading: assumes that we will continue to
Content: 

Heading: deploy MIRVs despite significant
Content: 

Heading: opposition from liberals and the
Content: 

Heading: left. I hope he is correct, but even
Content: 

Heading: so, as he points out, the USSR
Content: 

Heading: also has MIRV capabilities.
Content: 

Heading: It should also be noted that war
Content: 

Heading: heads vary in strength, and the
Content: 

Heading: Soviets are far ahead of us in the
Content: 

Heading: deployment of large warheads. The
Content: 

Heading: megatonnage of such a Soviet war
Content: 

Heading: head has a destructive power equal
Content: 

Heading: to several of ours.
Content: 

Heading: Finally, Mr. Higgins describes
Content: 

Heading: ULMS, another new weapons sys
Content: 

Heading: tem, evidently to indicate that we
Content: 

Heading: will continue our strategic lead.
Content: 

Heading: What he neglects to mention is that
Content: 

Heading: ULMS is only in the first stages of
Content: 

Heading: development and a long way from
Content: 

Heading: actual Congressional approval for
Content: 

Heading: deployment. If and when it is ap
Content: 

Heading: proved I will feel much less con
Content: 

Heading: cerned about the state of our na
Content: 

Heading: tional defense, but I am more than
Content: 

Heading: a little afraid that those of Mr.
Content: 

Heading: Higgins like will be opposing, not
Content: 

Heading: supporting, deployment of ULMS.
Content: 

Heading: Jerry Norton
Content: 

Heading: Director of College Services
Content: 

Heading: school application process, let me
Content: 

Heading: explain. Most schools require that
Content: 

Heading: the student's Law School Admission
Content: 

Heading: Test (LSAT) and his transcript be
Content: 

Heading: handled by the Law School Data
Content: 

Heading: Assembly
Content: 

Heading: Service
Content: 

Heading: (LSDAS),
Content: 

Heading: a
Content: 

Heading: branch of the Educational Testing
Content: 

Heading: Services (ETS). Ostensibly LSDAS
Content: 

Heading: "analyzes" your
Content: 

Heading: transcript
Content: 

Heading: and
Content: 

Heading: sends their analysis along with
Content: 

Heading: your LSAT score to the law schools
Content: 

Heading: to which you are applying. All this
Content: 

Heading: is intended in the interests of ef
Content: 

Heading: ficiency, expediency, and standard
Content: 

Heading: ization.
Content: 

Heading: In October of last year I took the
Content: 

Heading: LSAT, arto on December 23rd my
Content: 

Heading: college transcript was
Content: 

Heading: sent to
Content: 

Heading: LSDAS. On February 4th I received
Content: 

Heading: a notice from one of the schools
Content: 

Heading: to which I had applied. The notice
Content: 

Heading: informed me that they had not re
Content: 

Heading: ceived my LSDAS materials. This
Content: 

Heading: was 6 weeks after the last of my
Content: 

Heading: materials had been sent to ETS. I
Content: 

Heading: called them immediately, demand
Content: 

Heading: ing to know the reasons behind the
Content: 

Heading: delay. I was told that a computer
Content: 

Heading: malfunction was hampering the
Content: 

Heading: assembly of the records of many
Content: 

Heading: students who had taken the LSAT
Content: 

Heading: in October. (The majority of law
Content: 

Heading: applicants take the test in October.)
Content: 

Heading: I
Content: 

Heading: was told that the problems
Content: 

Heading: "should be remedied within a
Content: 

Heading: week."
Content: 

Heading: There are implications far be
Content: 

Heading: yond the mere inconvenience which
Content: 

Heading: this may have caused myself and
Content: 

Heading: others. Law schools, unlike under
Content: 

Heading: graduate
Content: 

Heading: institutions,
Content: 

Heading: follow
Content: 

Heading: a
Content: 

Heading: policy whereby applications are re
Content: 

Heading: viewed periodically; invitations or
Content: 

Heading: rejections may be sent out at vir
Content: 

Heading: tually any time during the appli
Content: 

Heading: cant's senior year. The student
Content: 

Heading: whose application is received late
Content: 

Heading: is at a distinct disadvantage, for
Content: 

Heading: the chance of a higher caliber ap
Content: 

Heading: plication being received by the
Content: 

Heading: school increases as the deadline
Content: 

Heading: approaches.
Content: 

Heading: Even more questionable than the
Content: 

Heading: mere handling of the materials is

Heading: Happenings of Note

Heading: Tutors
Content: Project Upward Bound is cur rently forming a tutor-referral ser vice for
    students enrolled in its Upward Bound program. Volunteer tutors are needed
    in all academic areas, especially English, mathe matics, foreign languages
    and scien ces. Students will tutor one or two nights per week at the
    community center in Mount Carmel, Milton, Selinsgrove or Shamokin. Trans
    portation will be provided. Interested students should con tact Lawrence
    Bassett at the Up ward Bound Office, 2nd floor of Taylor Street House, or
    call 524- 0584.

Heading: ABS Offices
Content: Any student interested in running for an ABS Office should notify Craig Eby at
    1535 before Feb. 16, in order to have their name placed on the preliminary
    ballot. After the preliminary slate is an nounced, those students still de
    siring to run, must submit a peti tion with 50 names to the nominat ing
    committee by Feb. 22. The final slate will be announced Feb. 23 and the
    final election will be March 1. wmmmmmmmm

Heading: Concert
Content: The Paul Winter Consort will ap pear in Chapel Auditorium at Sus quehanna
    University tomorrow at 8:30 p.m. Students may purchase $2.00 tickets at the
    Bookstore with their I.D. Tickets at the door will be $3.00.

Heading: Chicago
Content: Those season ticketholders who cannot attend the 7:30 Chicago per formance
    because of legitimate job conflicts should write Andy Meyer, B-561, for
    ticket exchanges.

Heading: Coffee House
Content: The Class of 1972 will sponsor a coffeehouse Friday, February 12, between 9:00
    p.m. and 1:00 a.m. in Larison lounge.

Heading: Ice Skating
Content: The ice rink located in the prac tice field next to the stadium will be lit and
    in good shape for skat ing tonight from 8-12. Everyone is welcome tonight
    and at anytime until the rink thaws.

Heading: Chorale
Content: The University Chorale will give a concert in Davis Gym Sunday, February 14, at
    7:30 p.m. for the benefit of the Evangelical Com munity Hospital. Admission
    will be by donation. (Continued from Page 1) by telephone usually occurs
    some time after the conventions. Most groups' concerts are sche duled
    through agencies in New York, Philadelphia, Chicago, and Los Angeles. Meyer
    has negotiated with most groups from the phone in his room. Although the
    concert committee is offically part of ABS, it has no separate office. Meyer
    notes that negotiations and scheduling of acts usually take five months.
    First semester concerts must be booked in the summer; second semester
    bookings are set tled in the winter. At the final spring concert there will
    be a table at which students may ex press their preferences for next year's
    acts. Economically, the concert com mittee is usually able to "break even."
    Meyer expects to lose money on some concerts and make up the difference on
    the others. Approximately 85% of sales is season tickets. Meyer regards this
    advance volume selling as why the University's concert series has re mained
    so successful. Due to profits last year, the committee was able to stage a
    free concert with Jam Factory. M eyer also mentions that the

Heading: Demonstration at Post Office
Content: 

Heading: What you should know about diamonds
Content: 

Heading: when you know it's for keeps
Content: You've dreamed about your diamond engagement ring a thou sand times. But now
    that you know it's for keeps, it's time to stop dreaming and start learning
    about diamonds and their value. Because no two diamonds are exactly alike,
    jewelers have adopted exacting standards to de termine the relative value of
    each and every diamond in the world. These standards include a dia mond's
    size (carat weight), color, cut and clarity. Although it's important to know
    the facts about diamonds, you certainly don't have to be expert to choose a
    Keepsake Dia mond Ring . . . because Keepsake guarantees a diamond of fine
    white color, correct cut and perfect clar ity or replacement assured. The fa
    mous Keepsake certificate provides permanent registration, trade-in value
    and protection against loss of diamonds from the setting. (Continued from
    Page 1) hour and a half demonstration with mixed feelings as to their own mo
    tives for acting. A perhaps not un typical comment was the one of a marcher
    who said, " I'm not sure its accomplishing what its supposed to."  The
    gentleman next to him returned, "What is it supposed to do." The march had
    been agreed on at a mass meeting held Tuesday night in Vaughan Literature
    Audi torium. Prof. Jerome Rinyus de livered an opening speech outlining the
    intelligence operations of the U.S. in Vietnam. In conclusion, he asked that
    the least anyone could do in response to the Laos invasion was to " convince
    one other person that killing other men is wrong."

Heading: Legal Abortions Without Delay
Content: Rick Beardsley then attempted to guide the open discussion among the
    approximately three hundred attending the meeting. It was hoped that the
    group would develop an ap propriate course of action for the following day.
    For the next hour, various points were raised ranging from sugges tions to
    shovel sidewalks to a chal lenge for the "truly committed" to burn the draft
    files at the local board office. Frustration abounded, and Beard sley was
    led at one point to plead, " Lets just take a vote on some thing."  Karl
    Patten suggested the march which was carried out the next day. The following
    is the protest state ment of the marchers: We, individual members of the
    Buckneil community, protest the mounting inhumanity of our gov ernment. We
    are here today to express our outrage at the American-directed invasion of j
    Laos, which we regard as yet i another immoral and illegal ac-

Heading: I
Content: tion of our government in South east Asia. But we realize that

Heading: I
Content: Laos is essentially a foreign ver-

Heading: I
Content: sion of our domestic disregard for human life and liberty, a disregard which has
    exploded in violence and repression across the land. Standing here we affirm
    that life and liberty and ask that all men join us. COLOR: Fine white
    diamonds are quite rare and valued accordingly. Other shades in relative
    order of their worth are: blue, yellow, brown and black. CUT: The cut of a
    diamond--the facets placed on it by a trained cutter--brings out the gem's
    fire and brilliance. Anything less than correct cut reduces beauty, bril
    liance and value. CLARITY: Determined by the ab sence of small impurities. A
    per fect diamond has no impurities when examined under ten power
    magnification by a trained eye. CARAT: A diamond's size is measured in
    carats. As a diamond increases in size, its price will increase even more if
    the quality remains constant. But larger dia monds of inferior, quality may
    ac tually be worth less than smaller, perfect diamonds.

Content: uestion :

Heading: Y
Content: ou hear it said th a t crim e doesn't  pay, bu t som e people seem to get aw ay
    w ith a lot in this world. H ow com e?

Heading: A
Content: nswer : This question has bothered people for thousands of years. Long ago in
    the day. o f the Prophet Jeremiah we find him asking, "W herefore does the
    way of the wicked prosper?"  W e find the answer in the Bible also: it is be
    cause o f God's mercy that He does not strike the sinner down the moment he
    sins. He gives him every opportunity to change his ways. And He often leaves
    him in the full en joyment of his worldly prosperity, because it is not
    always in His plan to render judgment in this life. leadership of the
    concert commit tee has remained the same in the past few years. " A very
    small group is most effective in negotia tions of this sort,"  he asserts. "
    I look on the concert committee as a 'conelike' organization. Months before
    the concert only one or two work on a show; by concert time, nearly 80
    people may be involved in publicity, ticket sales, and ad vertising."
    Gebauer foresees a " much broad er"  concert committee next year. Director
    of public relations at WVBU, he will work with Steve / Selinger, former
    music director for WVBU, and Keith Coughey, as well as others. Upon
    graduation M eyer will utilize his experience with concert scheduling. As a
    professional " en tertainment specialist,"  he will at tempt to schedule
    acts for various colleges. He claims, " Colleges must realize that concerts
    are not merely activities, they are business."

Heading: Pa. Drops Aid
Content: (Continued from  Page 1) if the money isn't appropriated by May 1. The first one
    is that the school will need the money by then for operating expenses, which
    would seem to indicate the possibility that the University might have to bor
    row. Or, since it is unlikely that anyone in the Business & Finance Office
    would like paying off the in terest on such a loan, with the pre sent
    $300,000-plus deficit from last year still over their heads, the stu dents
    might just have to come up with the money themselves. Another disaster could
    be even more troublesome. What about the seniors who must have their bills
    paid in order to receive their di plomas? At the present time there are
    between 50 to 75 seniors who could be affected by the present dilemma, which
    seems unlikely to be resolved in the near future. Although, for the
    University, the problem has not, as yet, reached any serious proportions,
    the statis tics tell the extent to which the University could be affected:
    num ber of students receiving PHEAA aid--300: total number of awards--
    $116,000/sem . With any kind of real austerity program initiated by the
    legislature of Pennsylvania, a goodly number of students could find
    themselves searching around for an extra $400, or even worse, they might
    find such a task impossible.

Heading: AB S Meeting
Content: (Continued from Page 1) He supported bis motion's sugges tion of dorm autonomy
    because it allows students more say about the rules they live under." ] it
    was noted this ABS act does not necessarily mean President Charles Watts II
    will approve the motion and put it into effect, nor does it automatically
    institute open visitation. It merely provides for the separate dorms to
    determine their own hours. It was decided to extend the dead line for
    applications to the Environ mental and Advisory Committee until Wednesday,
    February 17. This important committee will concern the University as an
    ecological sys tem and all those interested in serving on it may pick up a
    peti tion in the office of the Dean of Student Affairs.

Heading: THE BUCKNELLIAN
Content: FEBRUARY 12, 1971 You may have heard of the farm er who plowed his field on
    Sunday, sowed it with seed on Sunday, cultivated and weeded it on Sunday,
    reaped it on Sunday, and even sold the grain on Sunday. He twitted his more
    godly neigh bor with the fact that his ac counting showed that his field had
    yielded more profit than his neighbor's. "Yes," said the neighbor, 'Taut God
    hasn't closed His account book yet." W e are to love God, not for the
    material prosperity He allows us to enjoy, but for Himself alone, for the
    joy that knowing and obeying Him brings to our hearts. When a rich man in
    the Bible died and went to hell, Abraham reminded him from paradise that in
    his lifetim e he had received his good things, yet had not loved God or his
    neighbor. Now he had no cause of complaint against God. When it comes to a
    choice o f laying up treasures in heaven or treasure on e^rth, only the
    short-sighted will choose the latter. The former will last for eternity. For
    free booklet, " T he

Heading: Improvements Needed
Content: 

Heading: Series of M edical Errors, Including an 'Em ergency'
Content: 

Heading: E xpose Serious Inadequacies at Ziegler Dispensary
Content: - _ .. -- II l 1 Li nlLtnGnn '* InnrftVl nf tima fnr occictnn By DAVID HAMMER
    Investigation suggests that the Ziegler Dispensary may be taking a turn for
    the worse. At least three cases of persons needing medical help from this
    university's dis pensary resulted in what could be termed " less than
    adequate"  as sistance. For example, freshman Ed Hafer experienced relative
    disillusion ment on the Saturday and Sunday of Homecoming Weekend last se m
    ester when he suffered from a broken jaw after being " mugged" in Lewisburg
    by non-university stu dents. Having been informed that Evangelical Community
    Hospital " would not take X-rays,"  Hafer was forced to seek assistance from
    Ziegler dispensary on the after noon following the incident. Hafer asked for
    the doctor and was told that he " would be in later."  Consequently, he
    returned that evening and informed the nurse on duty that he had come again
    to seek the doctor's help. While Hafer was waiting for him to appear, broken
    jaw and all, several people came in and out; unfortunately, one of the ones
    who left the dispensary was the doctor himself. Because Hafer did not know
    the doctor and because, evidently, the physician had not been told of
    Hafer's presence by the nurse, the freshman had to suffer yet another day
    until an appointment could be made with the dispensary, on Mon day.
    'Sprained Fracture' In another incident, Gene Bar tholomew (Hafer's
    roommate) suf fered what was later diagnosed as a " sprained fracture"  from
    playing basketball in mid-December of last year. The doctor on the afternoon
    shift at Ziegler Dispensary, after remarking that he ''really didn't think
    X-rays needed to be taken" (as Hafer recalls his words), sug gested that the
    best thing Bar tholomew could do would be to " walk on it." And, so, he did.
    All would have been fine had his in jury merely behn a sprain (and, without
    X-rays, such seemed the case); however, had X-rays been taken, Bartholomew
    would not have been walking on the fracture and, certainly, treatment would
    have commenced immediately. Dental Dilemma Yet another situation arises from
    a letter submitted to The Bucknell- ian in which Annett Lord recalls her
    experience with Ziegler Dis pensary on January 7 of this year. She had had
    wisdom teeth re moved at home and, although the stitches were still in, she
    was ad vised that she could return to school. At approximately 3 a.m., on
    January 7, she awoke to find her mouth bleeding and, finally, asked her
    friend, (Nadeen Van Tuyle) to call her home; Lord's dentist, from an account
    of the situation, described her condition as warranting " emergency treat
    ment." On these grounds, van Tuyle contacted Evangelical Community Hospital;
    the nurse on duty ex plained that van Tuyle should call the University
    dispensary, instead, despite the " emergency treatment" analysis and the
    fact that only three days earlier the hospital had initiated a program
    whereby an oral surgeon would be on call 24 hours a day. (Evidently, as
    Annette Lord suggests, only those " higher up"  in the hospital echelon knew
    of this action involving the oral surgeon continuously on call.) It happened
    that the Ziegler Dis pensary, in this instance, was less than helpful
    despite Miss Lord's continued bleeding. The nurse on duty would only supply
    names of dentists in the area and, more significantly to Miss Lord, freely
    advised that contacting area den tists " would not be much help" due to the
    fact that it was Sunday. Finally, out of what must be termed sheer
    desperation, Miss Lord was driven to Geisinger Medical Center by friends and
    was eventually taken care of--only after much blood had been lost due to the
    seeming--run around by both Evangelical Com munity Hospital and the Ziegler
    Dispensary early on a Monday morning. Several questions and suggestions
    arise in the minds of those in volved in these isolated, yet re lated,
    incidents. Annette Lord ad mitted that panic was a factor in her situation,
    and that the Ziegler nurse did not help to " instill con fidence" with the
    remark that pro bably no help could be found at such an early hour. Also,
    the nurse at Ziegler did " not,"  in Miss Lord's words, " seem to compre
    hend the emergency situation." Others interviewed, including Barb Jensen,
    John Yee, Betsy Hed rick and Joanne Martin (who were involved in a
    tobogganing accident this January behind Roberts Hall) suggested that, since
    a nurse can not supposedly leave the dispen sary, more personnel might be
    added should medical assistance be needed immediately elsewhere on campus.
    Questions Theoretically, if someone med ically-versed could have come down
    the hill to check them, their in juries could have been speedily diagnosed
    without their having to move around or wait for any great length of time for
    assistance. Ultimately, Annette Lord ques tions where the $150.00 in health
    fees eventually winds up; and, considering her related plight, such a
    question seems quite valid. Sure ly, as Miss Lord feels, she deserved a good
    deal more attention than she received considering the sum. Generally, a lack
    of confidence pervades the minds of these indi viduals concerning Ziegler
    Dispen sary; their experiences have not been good. And, their questions and
    suggestions are not idle ones, nor ones which necessarily must be asked only
    by those recently in volved in these and similar inci dents.

    Social Security, 1,678,815 people have the surname " Smith." According to
    the ancient Chinese lunar calendar, 1971 is the " year of the pig."

Heading: 'Groove Tube'

Heading: 'Catch-22' Flick Fails in Attempt
Content: 

Heading: Satirizes

Heading: j>>0
Content: 

Heading: Recreate Heller's War Novel
Content: By KARL BLAKE " Groove Tube," a new theatre form in which the only actor is a
    television set, will be here Wednes day, February 17, sponsored by the
    Bucknell Concert Committee. There will be continuous show ings at 3, 5, 7,
    9, and 11 p.m. Ad mission is $1.50. Created by Kenny Shapiro, a former
    television performer, " Gro ove Tube"  is a two-hour collection of satirical
    sketches, musical num bers and take-offs on television commercials, which
    the theatre audience views on three television monitors on the stage.
    Shapiro, with the help of friend Lane Sarasohn, wrote and directed the
    sketches and operated the cameras and recording equipment. He also acted in
    several of the pieces. When the show proved to be a success at the Channel
    One Theater in New York's East Village, he made another copy of the tape for
    circulation on college campuses. Shapiro uses satiric techniques of
    exaggeration and unexpected juxtapositions. Thus, a pornographic film is
    supplied with a running commentary by two television sportcasters, with skin
    flick and sportscasters both being satirized. Shapiro says, somewhat expan
    sively, of his videotape theatre: "This is my definitive comment on
    television, and on life." By LOU BUCCERI About fifteen years ago, Joseph
    Heller wrote a book called Catch-22. It was about life and death and war and
    a million other things which people have been writing about for centuries.
    The beauty of Heller's work was that it forced you to laugh uproariously
    while simultaneously experiencing a sickening feeling in the pit of your
    stomach. This com bination of emotions is the effect of what is known in
    some circles as 'Black Comedy.' In other circles this experience is known as
    'being alive.' Whatever it's called, Heller's effort in Catch-22 was
    outstanding. About a year and a half ago, Mike Nichols began directing a
    film based on Heller's book. Nichols is a well known, much honored director,
    with films such as The Graduate to his credit. He hired a crew of actors;
    among them Orson Welles, Jon Voight, Alan Arkin, Bob Newhart, Art Garfunkle
    and, as they say, a host of others. To give this worthy cast a noble set,
    Nichols rented a valley in one of the most desolate parts of Mexico. Since
    the book centers on a bomber squadron in World War H, Nichols gathered up
    bits and pieces to form a fleet of B-25's. He had the fleet restored to
    flying condition and flew them to his Mexican valley, landing them on the
    full scale air strip he had built there. At the same time, the well known
    writer and actor, Buck Henry, was putting the final touches on the screen
    play adaptation of Heller's book. Nichols' production costs ran into the
    millions of dollars. Pre premier publicity was heavy--everything from a
    cover story in Life magazine to an article in Playboy. All over the country,
    Heller freaks were impatiently waiting to see if Nichols' extravaganza would
    faithfully translate the book experience into a movie experience. Catch-22
    (the novel) had become a kind of Bible for some of us, and to be able to see
    and hear it, instead of just mind-picturing it, would have been fantastic.
    Unfortunately, Nichols didn't make it. Catch-22 is a bad movie. It isn't the
    acting, or the setting, or the photography that is bad; it's the script and
    the direction. Nichols and Henry turned Catch-22 into a scattered series of
    incoherent vignettes. Heller's book was by no means linear, but it was
    definitely coherent. Alan Arkin could have played the lead character,
    Captain Yossarian, credibly, but the script forces him to portray Yossarian
    as two separate people--first completely crazy, then, suddenly, completely
    sane. Heller's Yossarian is crazy, But it's his insanity that saves him. He
    reacts in sanely to an insane environment, since behaving in a way which the
    en vironment would accept, would mean death. In the book, the author's
    belief in the correctness of Yossarian's position is revealed by a gradual
    but forceful exposition of his situation. In the movie, that situation is
    thrown at us all at once, making it Im possible to understand what's going
    on, let alone why it's happening. To allow this compression to occur,
    Nichols eliminates some characters and exaggerates others, creating an
    atmosphere of Good vs. Evil com pletely alien to Heller's book. Nichols
    kills off characters he hasn't even introduced simply because their deaths
    are picturesque. He suddenly abondons characters he has just begun to
    develop, giving the feeling that Yossarian is wandering among cardboard
    figures. The character of Milo Minderbinder is first made central to the
    story line, but is then perverted into the role of a Static-Hitler figure.
    Heller's Milo was clever, enterprising, and sick, but by no means demonic.
    The movie boils Yossarian's battle for life down to an imagin ary fight
    against imaginary demons. Nichols' movie takes a complex book concerning a
    complex situation and crushes it, leaving a worthless cartoon of life. It
    may well be that no movie could faithfully reproduce the atmosphere of
    Heller's book. Certainly no movie that had to end after two and one-half
    hours. Catch-22 is long and involved. Each minute part is important to the
    whole. Un fortunately, minor actions and gestures are often lost amid a
    film's dia logue and camera work. Perhaps film can present the dilemma
    treated in Catcb-22. However, it must first evolve its own story-line, its
    own characters, and make use of its own peculiar methods. Nichols' attempt
    is a choppy, incoherent waste, impossible to understand without having read
    the book, and horribly inadequate after having read it.

Heading: Bucknell Concert Committee
Content: PINNED: Chris Sonderstrom to Carl Smith, SAE *72. ENGAGED: Debbie Dixon, '71
    (University of Pittsburgh) to Terry Hibbard, '71. Pat Keen, DDD '71 to Mark
    Broady, SAE '71. Steph Laudenbach, DZ '71 to Walt Molawak, KDR '71. Kathie
    Sheetz, DZ '71 to Carl Anthony. '72. Karen Speidel, BG '73 to Greg Olson, DU
    '70. MARRIED: lisa  Carpenter, '72 to Jeff Bush, '71. WANTED: College men
    and women for man agement positions in government. Must meet physical requi
    rements. Financial aid available for in college trainees, or applicants can
    enroll in special training course on graduation. Stateside a n d / o r  o v
    e r s e a s  t r a v e l guaranteed. Here's a government position with a
    real future for both men and women. An officer's job in the Air Force. A
    management level job in anybody's book. Certainly, there's no better way to
    get the experience and train ing needed for executive responsi bility. If
    you have two years of college remaining, you could find yourself earning an
    Air Force commission while you learn, through the Air Force ROTC two-year
    program. Along with college credits and a commission, you'll receive $50
    each month as a student. And upon grad uation, that management position we
    promised will be waiting for you. If an advanced degree is in your plans,
    you'll be happy to learn that the Air Force has a number of out standing
    programs to help you fur ther your education. If you're in your final year
    of col lege, you can get your commission through the Air Force Officer Train
    ing Program. It is open to all college grads, both men and women, who
    qualify. Check it out. You'll find that the Air Force is one career that
    offers something for everyone. Nearly 430 different jobs, ranging from aero
    nautical engineering to zoology, with almost everything else, includ ing
    flying, in between. But whatever your duties, you'll soon discover that the
    Air Force will let you move just as far and as fast as your tal ents can
    take you. So look ahead and let your col lege years pay off for you with a
    managerial position in the U.S. Air Force. Just send in this coupon or write
    to USAF Military Personnel Center, Dept. A, Randolph AFB, Texas 78148, and
    get your postgrad uate career off the ground.

Heading: Thinclads Place in Relay Events; Engineers Invading Davis
Content: By JEFF QUINZER Improvement is the goal all coaches strive for as a season
    progresses. The progress of the winter track team, and that of the two-mdie
    relay team in particular, would please the most demanding of coaches. In the
    recent Knights of Colum bus Track Meet at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 5,
    the relay team of Paul Hermly (2:02.2), John Lar- ner (1:58.9), Rich Francel
    (1:56.8), and Tom Hagerty (2:01.5), ran a 7:59.4 relay which bettered their
    times of the two previous weeks by 16 and 22 seconds respectively, and was
    their best effort of the year, good enough for a fifth place finish. The
    fine showing eliminated one problem for Coach Arthur Gulden: whether or not
    the team should travel to Baltimore the next morn ing for the All-Eastern
    Invitational. "We were debating whether to go or not,"  explained Gulden. "
    It was The decision to compete on Sat urday was obviously a good one, as the
    team responded with an 8:01.2 time and a second place fin ish in their
    section. They were topped only by the powerful Balti more Olympic Club, an
    AAU team of graduate runners. In the process, they downed Seton Hall,
    Catholic University, and Virginia State. Coach Gulden was obviously pleased
    about the second place fin ish. "We beat a good team in Seton Hall, who has
    run a 7:56, by 15 yards. That's an important com petitive aspect. When you
    run on a slow track like the one in Balti more, times don't mean a thing. It
    depends on who you beat." How did the squad react to run ning in such
    prestigious places as the Garden and Civic Center? " It was a fantastic
    feeling," re plied Francel. " Here we were, on

Heading: Fencing Found Fun
Content: By DAN MILLER It can be used to defend your honor as well as that of your lady.
    The techniques have been handed down since the days of Cyrano de Bergerac
    and the thrill of a deft parry and adroit reoste still courses in every
    noble man's veins. The sport is fencing, and it was initiated at BU the
    opening week in January as a one week workshop under the leadership of
    Professor Ken Kaminski of the Math Depart ment. Professor Kaminski, an
    alumnus of Rutgers University, competed in intercollegiate fencing while an
    undergraduate. He very willingly compiled to a request to instruct
    interested people in the rudiments of fencing as a part of the January
    Program. The turnout was unexpectedly large and enthusiastic and what was
    originally slated to be a one- week program was extended to daily workouts
    for the remainder of the month. With the end of January it was decided to
    attempt to combine the organized practices on a one-per- week basis during
    the semester. In addition efforts are being made to contact other schools to
    investigate the possibility of organ izing intercollegiate matches. While
    the fencers who are cur rently participating in the club are enthusiastic,
    the element of com petitive experience as lacking. Coach Kaminski is the
    only swords man who is familiar with the com petitive aspects of the sport
    Therefore, any fencers on the faculty or in the student body who are
    interested in returning to com petition are invited to attend the Wednesday
    night workouts. They are scheduled for 7:00 in Tustin Gym and the equipment
    is pro vided. decided that if the boys ran well in New York, we would go."
    the same level as the guys you always read about. They came over and talked
    to us and everything." John Lamer was also impressed. " It was a whole
    different atmos phere," he said. " Everything seemed different; just seeing
    those thousands of people in the stands was really scary." " I think it gave
    us more confi dence and a lot of experience," added Hermly. The following is
    a recap of the meets in January. Pittsburgh (Jan. 16): Lamer, Hagerty and
    Hermly finished first, third and fourth respectively in the 1,000. Fred
    Weber took a first in the 600 while Francel ran a 1:55.2 to place second in
    the invitational half-mile. Len Dillinger finished third in the high jump
    and fourth in the long jump. Philadelphia (Jan. 23): "The two- mile relay
    team had a bad day and finished fourth out of six teams," explained Gulden.
    Cornell Invitational (Jan. 30): Hermly (1:17.9) finished third in the jayvee
    600 while Lamer placed fifth in the mile with a 4:35, his best time ever.
    Francel, returning from a two-week injury, took fifth in the 1,000. The
    freshman medely relay of Bill Ledger wood, Rick Bullock, Randy Mattison and
    Bob Lucas finished third. Bullock was also first in the 600 and Mattison
    finish ed fourth in the high jump at 5-8. Coach Gulden is optimistic about
    the future. "We have showed im provement and will continue to im prove, as
    long as we keep work ing,"  he said. " We're now looking forward to the
    Delaware Invitational on the 26th and 27th,"  concluded Gulden. " Reaction
    to the team so far has been very favorable. I've had many compliments from
    opposing coaches and meet directors. We will be in vited to these meets
    again next year." By ALAN GROCHAL A spectacular 25 point perform ance for
    BU's Paul Kerr was off set by Gettysburg's balanced attack as the Bullet
    frosh romped BU 86- 67, Tuesday. Kerr, who fouled out late in the game,
    scored 19 points in the first half to bring the Bisons to within 2 points of
    the Bullets at intermis sion, 46-44. The Herd went ahead 48-47 early in the
    second half, but Gettysburg streaked ahead to a 14 point lead shortly
    afterward. Five Bullet players scored in double figures with Perry Clark
    leading the way with 24. Algin Garrett supported Kerr's offensive show with
    16 points of his own. The defeat dropped the Bisons record to 8-5 and
    shattered a four game winning streak. The Thundering Herd made

Heading: Herd Hits Winning Trail;
Content: 

Heading: Cagers Await MAC Foes
Content: 

Heading: Harvey Carter: Promising Center
Content: Harvey Warms Up. (photo by Bob Arnold) Throughout the disappointments and the
    joys of the 1970-1971 Bas ketball season BU fans have been thrilled by the
    outstanding play of Harvey Carter. Presently the team's leading scorer and
    rebound er, Carter is the nucleus of Buck- riell's promising sophomore team.
    Seldom has a quarter passed in Davis Gym when a roar from the crowd has not
    echoed as Harvey blocked an opponents shot. When asked how it feels to block
    such a shot, he said, "It's the best part of the game! You hate to see them
    score when you could have blocked it." This season has been somewhat
    disappointing to the BU center, as he believes the team " should have won
    some of the games they lost.' However, he is confident that the Bisons can
    even their record and attain at least a .500 mark for the year. He also
    feels the Bisons have an outside chance of gaining an MAC berth, but first
    they will have to win their remaining games. Le high is one team Carter
    really wants to beat, especially after Le high's victory in double-overtime
    over the Herd earlier this season. The toughest Bison foe, in Har vey's
    opinion, was Syracuse with their 6-11 center, who gave the team a real tough
    time. However, there is still the promising thought that Syracuse will play
    without their giant next year, while BU will return all but two players.
    Admittedly it was a rough mid dle of the season schedule for the Bluet but
    even though it got tougher to get up for the games as the losing streak
    lengthened, Carter notes that " No one wanted to quit, all the guys stayed
    with it." While quick to point out that this year's season is far from over,
    Harvey voiced his belief that the Bisons will be a team to reckon with in
    the future. He is really looking forward to playing with the freshmen who
    will be moving up next year"  as well as this year's sophomores. The frosh
    squad seem s to be " working well together and could help us next year."  He
    also remarked that a frosh victory always helped to psych the varsity squad
    for their game to follow. The big center feels that the team is constantly
    learning to play together, and in two years a lot can happen to a team. He
    credits Bucknell's victories to " five guys all playing together,"  rather
    than individual performances and backs this up by noting the evenly dis
    tributed scoring totals for the Bi son attack. Harvey has set high goals for
    himself and the team. He hopes to win MAC titles the next two years and to
    get to the NIT before he graduates from BU. To some, such a prediction is
    improbable, to others, an understatement, but to those who have watched,
    cheered and followed Bison basketball this year, these words must hold a
    promise for the future. Indeed the Big Blue will be a power to reckon with
    in the future led by such talented athletes as Harvey Carter. Harvey Carter
    receives congratulations from his teammates. The super sophomore leads the
    team in both rebounds and scoring. (photo by Bob Arnold)

Heading: A Female Bounce
Content: 

Heading: Basketball in
Content: 

Heading: Gym
Content: By ALAN GROCHAL BU's varsity cagers carry an 8-10 record into tonight's game
    against Lehigh. The Herd will be trying to avenge a 2 point loss in triple
    over time incurred earlier in the sea son. Lehigh features the leading re
    bounder in the MAC Western Sec tion in 6'7"  Greg Falkenbach. The Engineers
    also have guard John Waters who is averaging over 17 points a game. Last
    Tuesday the Bisons whipped Gettysburg 74-63 behind the strong scoring and
    rebounding of sopho more Harvey Carter to break a seven game losing streak.
    Carter, who scored 22 points, was also an intimidating figure on de fense
    with several blocked shots. He is currently averaging 14.1 points per game.
    Despite Carter's heroics, the Herd only led by 3 points at inter mission,
    35-32. They increased their advantage to at least 10 points throughout most
    of the second period. Gettysburg managed a drive however, late in the game,
    to pull to within 5 with a minute left. Switching to a spread-type of fense,
    the Bisons forced the Bullets to gamble and consequently scored 3 layups to
    ice the game. Dave Greenwood and Paul Biko scored 14 and 13 points
    respectively for the Herd. Chris Riley added 11, all in the second half.
    Harvey Carter pulled down 14 re bounds, while Dave Greenwood grabbed 11. The
    Bisons' team re bounding edge over the Bullets was significantly large,
    38-20. Gettysburg is now 2-16 and is win less against MAC opponents. Rick
    Kershaw with 21 and Jay Bucher with 13 led the Bullet scoring. BU has
    another important MAC game Saturday at Lafayette. The Bisons will have a
    difficult chore on the Leopards' home grounds in trying to reverse an
    earlier defeat. Lafayette is 13-6 on the season including a 92-74 win over
    Lehigh last Tuesday. The Leopards own one of the leading scorers in the
    nation in junior Tracy Tripucka. Tripucka is the leading point man in the
    Western Section of the MAC.

Heading: Keen Lecture Presents
Content: 

Heading: 'World of Possibilities'
Content: 

Heading: VOLUME LXXHI -- NO. 29
Content: 

Heading: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 16. 1971
Content: !U 1 i p . Dave Greenwood goes up for the basket. This type of driving basket
    ball was typical of the Bison's of fensive last Tuesday as they de feated
    Gettysburg 74-63 to halt a seven game losing streak. (photo by Bob Arnold)

Heading: an evening with
Content: 

Heading: ROBERTA
Content: 

Heading: FLACK
Content: 

Heading: Fill.FEB. 19- 8 10PM
Content: 

Heading: MAYOR CENTER
Content: K M  COLLEGE-LANCASTER^* $ 3 .5 0  F&M students

Heading: $4.50 gm.adm.
Content: Ticket Locations: CAMPUS HOUSE & SW ITCHBOARD STA N 'S RECO RD BAR LANCASTER,
    DISC-W ORLD -  Y O R K M A L L C EN TR A L TIC KET AGENCY, C O LO N IAL
    HOTEL, YORK, PA. For Further Information: (717) 393-3621 By ED MARSTON The
    Class of 1956 Lecture was de livered Monday evening by Dr. J. Ernest Keen,
    professor of psy chology. The lecture was entitled J Toward a Psychology of
    Passi- Dility." The lecture was well-attended, so much so that the overflow
    crowd caused the lecture to be moved from a classroom in -Coleman Hall to
    Olin Science Auditorium. Keen presented a radical new ap proach to
    conciousness, articulated in terms of a world of possibilities as opposed to
    a world of actual ities, and he talked about the im plications of such an
    approach for science and for human relations. He began by saying that
    science, and psychology in particular, is grounded in the belief that
    natural laws can be discovered by the rig orous application of scientific
    method to the question of truth or falsity. Therefore the scientist asks "
    how?"  and believes that gradual elimination of error will yield the essence
    of the system being in vestigated. In believing that there a singular,
    correct answer the scientist searches for " actualities." This approach,
    according to Keen, necessarily excludes another entire ly different way of
    looking at man and the world--as possibilities rather than actualities. He
    suggested that one look at an other person not to see him as he is, but "to
    see him as he could be or should be."  This involves a basic restructuring
    of consciousness a- round a revised theory of truth. The theory of
    possibilities recog nizes that the only thing that is true about the world
    is the ex istence of other possibilities. Form ative judgements become
    irrele vant when it is clear that the es sence of what a person or thing is
    lies in what he or it could become. For example, when the clinical
    psychologist deals with a mentally troubled person he can regard his
    patient's personal world as either a misperceived or insane world, or he can
    treat it instead as a pos sible world in which one might live. In the later
    case the therapist makes no moral judgment about the validity of his
    patient's ex perience and himself makes no claim to normalcy. The question
    then becomes not whether the experience of the pati ent is right or wrong,
    but whether he can live comfortably with his experience. If not, then
    treatment would consist of exploring other possible worlds. In speaking
    about the therapist's relationship to the patient Keen said, " To find him
    incomprehen sible is to confirm his actuality and deny his possibility."
    That is, if the patient is made to believe that he is only what he is seen
    to be, sick or insane, then has no basis on which to choose among different
    possible mental states. Keen went on to say that the goals of a science of
    possibilities would be to explore different ways (Continued on Page 3)

Heading: TCht
Content: 

Heading: JMmdltan
Content: 

Heading: BUCKNELL UNIVERSITY. LEWISBURG. PENNSYLVANIA
Content: 

Heading: Top Administrators Assess
Content: 

Heading: Yale Tuition Payment Plan
Content: By ERIC RIESS Several top administrators includ ing the Pijesident expressed
    doubts this week that a plan simi lar to Yale University's Pay-as-you- Earn
    program for deferred tuition payments could be instituted here. In a reply
    to a letter sent out by McGeorge Bundy, president of the Ford Foundation,
    one of the private groups which Yale has selected for funds to finance the
    program Presi dent Charles H. Watts II stated that the University would be
    happy to take part in any study which the foundation institutes but declined
    to openly back the proposal. The Yale PAYE plan approved in principal by the
    board of trustees of Yale University, February 5, calls for $25 to $30
    million to be loaned out to students over the

Heading: Wrestlers Move to Colgate
Content: Donald Danser, 142 pound sophomore, has been called, " our most con- cistent
    wrestler for the year,"  by Coach Schumacher. This Saturday the grapplers
    are out to extend their record as they travel to face the Red Raiders of
    Colgate. (photo by Bob Arnold) compose this year's squad. The girls have
    already taken their first step in intercollegiate competition as they took
    on the Susquehanna cagers at home this afternoon. . Coach Peck would offer
    no evalu ation of the team until after the game as she adopted a " wait and
    see"  philosophy. Girls on this year's squad and their tentative positions
    are: Seniors--Laura Demarest-Center, Ronnie Hilles and Sue Uger-Guards, and
    Nancy Worrall-Center. Junior Kathy Kellogg -is a For ward. Sophomores--Marge
    Deck-Center and Donna McNeal-Forward. Freshmen--Gina Ambrose-Guard, Ann
    Peterson-Guard, Sandy Selby and Barb Senkowski-Forwards, and Yvonne
    Aavaglia-Guard.
