Heading: Big Blue Laxmen Explode
Content: 

Heading: W ith  E xciting 9th Inning R ally
Content: By KEN DOAK A ninth inning home-run by Chris Riley gave the Bisons a 7-6 triumph
    over Dickinson Tuesday in a tre mendously exciting and unpredict able game.
    Dickinson jumped out to a 4-0 lead after three innings as they racked
    starter Jim Bolognese for 8 hits in that span. The Herd picked up a tally in
    the 3rd when Bemie Berninger walked, and Steve Eck lined a single that
    bounced past the rightfielder to bring home the runner. In the seventh
    inning, however, the BU bats came alive all at once. A Dickinson error, and
    singles by Eck and Jay Sabatino loaded the bases. John Rudolph, Riley, and
    Mike Marinchak then followed with three line shots to the outfield to jump
    the Herd into a 6-4 lead. The four runs in that inning sur passed the team
    production for any previous game. Bill Lane then replaced Rich Baines, who
    had pitched 4 scoreless innings. He breezed through the next five batters
    and seemingly had a victory wrapped up. However, nothing is ever certain
    with the Bisons, as the next two batters proved. Paul Wagner, with two
    strikes on him, belted one that did not stop rolling until it bounced off
    the Christy Mathewson Gateway, and he coasted around the bases. Lou Lo-
    quasto followed with a towering shot over the fence in left field, also on a
    2-strike pitch, and the score was 6-7. Rudolph added a bit of excite ment as
    he led off the bottom of the ninth with a double and was nailed trying to
    stretch it. However, Riley quickly drove a line-drive to deep est left-
    center and legged it all the way for the game-winner to help erase the
    pained look on Coach Thompson's face. Hopefully, the base hit barrage will
    bring the Bison batters out of their slump, and Rudolph (.359) and Gene
    Luccarelli (.333) may get some offensive help. BU travels to Gettysburg
    tomor row for a double-header, as the squad seeks to better their 4-10
    record. " i . . '..1' * * cy -V: . ? X-V-v -L : By ALAN GROCHAL Records were
    shattered as the BU laxmen defeated winless Dickinson, at home Wednesday,
    20-6. Co-captain Lou Kissling set a new mark with ten points in the game, on
    four goals and six assists. Junior Dan Nourse tied the single game record
    for goals with six. Finally, the team score of twenty goals set a new mark.
    The Herd led from the start as they mounted a 5-1 lead at the quarter. BU
    increased the margin to 12-2 at the half and 15-3 after three periods.
    Throughout the last period Coach Sid Jamieson substituted freely, but the
    Bisons still outscored Dick inson 5-3. Although Nourse tied the single game
    record for goals, he still felt that this was far from his best game. MK.yqe
    g " Actually I only had four goals against Dickinson's starters. I was
    forced to go back in when Bob Jennings hurt his shoulder. My last two goals
    were scored against their reserves."  he remarked. Randy Harris added three
    goals for the victors and Jim Navran had two. BU is now 4-3, but more impor
    tantly they have only one loss in league play. With several teams tied with
    the Bisons for first place>> the next two games, against Wash ington College
    and Delaware, shape up as must wins. Saturday the Herd will host Wash ington
    which perennially has one of the top ranked lacrosse teams in the nation.
    Washington's team this season is not as strong as past years, but they will
    still be tough. Delaware beat Lehigh, who in flicted BU's only league loss,
    in an early season game.

Heading: Tonu Zidansek:
Content: 

Heading: Hard Throwing Pitcher
Content: . .. ... -i T>> ___ : _ C nliitvin on/4 umrt tnu) By DAVID COULTER While the
    Bison baseball team has been struggling through its season, there have been
    some bright spots in the lineup. One of these is senior pitcher Tony
    Zidansek. As the Blue team has amassed a 4-10 record, Tony has managed to
    maintain a 0.95 ERA. To win you need good pitching, constant and timely
    hitting, a good defense, a good attitude and players who enjoy playing
    baseball,"  Tony explains. ''We haven't been able to put all of these
    together and since the season is so short we've been in trouble." However,
    the Bison hurler, look ing on the bright side, feels there is a mental
    advantage in the hitting drought. " The one positive thing is that I know
    that we aren't going to get the hitting and I have to concen trate fully on
    every batter. College pitchers primarily use three pitches, the fastball,
    the curve, and the change-up. Tony de pends primarily on his fast ball and
    curve, and ideally he would " want the batter to anticipate the fast ball
    and then throw him a curve and catch his timing off. However, it is more
    important where you throw than what you throw, control makes all the
    difference." In describing the role of and de mands on a pitcher, Tony said
    " As a pitcher you experience total in volvement, you have to play every
    pitch. There is the feeling that the game centers around your position more
    than any other. There is also an added sense of responsibility since one of
    your pitches can make the difference be tween winning and losing. . .But for
    the second before the pitch it seems that there exists, only you and the
    catcher's glove, you aren't really even conscious of the batter." He had
    praises for Coach Thomp son and his attitude, commenting, " Coach Thompson
    is still trying to make baseball a fun sport and not pressing the players,
    but letting them work things out themselves, even though we've been losing."
    As for the future, Tony believes the Bisons should be in a favorable
    position next season with this year's frosh hitting well and pitchers Bill
    Gaito, a sophomore, and Jim Bolog nese, a freshman, returning to take charge
    of the mound chores. The Bison hurler plans to enter Duquense Law School
    next fall after graduating with a degree in Busi ness Administration from
    BU. He would eventually like to head to ward a career in the field of cor
    porate law. Even though the Herd has failed to achieve an MAC contender's
    record, they are striving to pull out of their slump and work toward a .500
    season. Regardless of their total record, the Bisons have had some fine
    performances from Tony Zidansek and various members of the team. Hopefully
    they will be able to put everything together in the final half of the
    season.

Heading: BULLETIN
Content: 

Heading: BOARD
Content: By LORI VOUGHT The Bucknell Women's Sailing Team has had a very good season this
    Spring. On April 10, four mem bers sailed at Douglass and in New Brunswick,
    N.J., lead by Liz Hyde, former team captain, came in first. The following
    weekend, the team took part in the Tiger Bowl Regatta held at Princeton
    University. Com peting against six other schools, BU sailers trailed only
    the George town team. Last weekend the MAAWS (Mid dle Atlantic Association
    of Women Sailers) Spring Championships were held at West Point in N.Y.
    Bucknell finished a smashing third which now makes the team eligible to
    compete in the Nationals to be held June 10- 13 at the Coast Guard Academy.
    The team has three regattas sche duled for next fall to be held on September
    11, and October 16 and 23. By MARK McCONNAUGHHUY This past weekend the
    Sailing Club participated in a triangular meet at Cornell. The team, con
    sisting of Mark McConnaughhuy, Richard Hersey, James Pulver, Bob Palmer,
    Gary Norton, and Alan Bracci, finished third in the meet which the
    University of Rochester won by a slim margin of three points. Richard Hersey
    put in an out standing performance and was in contention for individual
    honors, until he capsized after being hit by another boat. Team Captain,
    Mark McConnau ghhuy, provided the highlight of the meet by falling out of
    his boat when the hiking strap he was using broke. He later commented on the
    loyalty of his crewmate, Jim Pulver, who capsized the boat ten seconds later
    instead of sailing on without him.

Heading: 'A Very Significant Thing';
Content: 

Heading: Faculty Votes to Open FAC
Content: 

Heading: VOLUME LX X m  -- NO. 47
Content: By JUNE CAFFREY At the faculty meeting last night a motion which changes the
    struc ture of the Faculty Advisory Com mittee was passed by a vote of 53-41.
    The motion, proposed by Stephen F. Becker, assistant professor of physics,
    provides that the 5 or 6 vacancies each year shall be filled by candidates
    at large (i. e. there would be no requirement concern ing department,
    division, or college affiliation). " This is a very significant motion the
    faculty just passed,"  Provost Wendell Smith commented. The new voting
    system will alleviate the departmentalization which was characteristic of
    the old system. " I have noticed intense depart mentalization of the faculty
    and feel that Professor Becker's motion will aid in breaking it up,"
    observed Richard Henry, chairman of the physics department. Gene Chenoweth,
    chairman of the political science department, spoke in favor of the motion
    and noted that, " The at-large approach is much better all around."  It
    allows for the possibility of minority as well as majority representation of
    the faculty. David Ray, coordinator of grad uate studies and professor of
    math ematics, reported on his committee which is investigating the use of
    the campus by outside agencies. The main purpose of the commit tee is to
    clarify the issues and de note the implications of this use for the
    University community. The committee's investigation will center around the
    Boyd Douglas issue. Ray said the committee will explore the question of
    whether cer tain individuals' academic freedom and personal rights had been
    en dangered. The final report will be issued at the December 1971 meeting.
    Mildred Martin, professor of English, proposed that the faculty create an
    International Education Committee. The motion passed after some discussion.
    The purpose of this committee will be to coordinate all activities relating
    to foreign study at the Uni versity. It will be composed of 13 members
    including three academic deans and one student. Herbert Eckberg, Dean of the
    College of Engineering, noted that, " Within the next few years, there will
    be an increasing need for co ordination of information concern ing among
    other things, the amount and sources of funds available for studying abroad
    and acquiriing foreign students at the University." The faculty voted to
    recess for one week. Topics for next week's meeting will include the
    physical education requirement and a reso lution that the relationship
    between professor and stulent be considered " special"  at the University.

Heading: "Cht
Content: 

Heading: JBocknellian
Content: 

Heading: BUCKNELL UNIVERSITY, LEWISBURG, PENNSYLVANIA
Content: 

Heading: TUESDAY, MAY 4. 1971
Content: 

Heading: Mayday Memorial Service
Content: 

Heading: Marks Strike Anniversary
Content: By RICHARD HUMPHREY A Mayday memorial service will be held Wednesday, May 5,
    from 1:00 p.m. until 2:30 p.m. on the Academic Quad. The service will be
    held to com memorate the lives of the State and Jackson State students which
    were lost in protest of the widening war in Indochina. This commemoration
    will be real- ized through the joint efforts of the Association of Bucknell
    Students and the Bucknell Students for Peace. The Peoples Coalition is
    calling for a nationwide moratorium on business as usual May 5. Betsy
    Sandel, chairman of the Mayday campus committee, stated, " It is hoped that
    there will be no 'business as usual' this Wednesday."

Heading: Selection Controversy Continues
Content: 

Heading: JC's Uncertain about Their R ole
Content: By DON THOMPSON (Editor's Note: This is the first of a two-part report
    concerning the controversy involving the Office of University Residence
    Halls.) Following the announcement of

Heading: 'Vision of Christ' Deemed
Content: 

Heading: Medieval Mystery Play, 1971
Content: By MICHAEL PAYNE Vision of Christ is a work of poetic revelation in which, as in
    its fourteenth-century source, the in timacy of religious and imaginative
    ecstacy is offered to be shared as a communal experience. The dy namics of
    the work range from the personal realm of man's sin, his fear of death and
    damnation, and his hope to imitate in fact Christ's resurrection to the
    communal realm of grace, love, and peace. These two realms merge in the "
    mirroring mind" of the Poet, whose consciousness is fragmented into all of
    the separate identities in the poetic drama. The center of the work, then,
    is the Poet, whose are much less perceptive than a medieval audience, for
    the relation ship between the audience and a play appears to have undergone
    a complete inversion since the four teenth century. It has been said of
    medieval drama that " while the performance lasted, audience and actors
    shared the same ritual world, a world more real than the one which existed
    outside its frame." Similarily, in the Prologue to Vision of Christ the Poet
    tells us, " For you tillers and toilers I pro vide with rare Truth." The "
    rare Truth"  of the Vision comes to us through a series of transformations.
    The first medieval metaphors for his vision; this pro- the names of the
    residence halls personnel for next year, the con troversy over the
    performance and counselor selection methods of the Office of University
    Residence Halls has increased. Initially, there seems to be a glar ing lack
    of communication between the counselors and the residence directors. In the
    freshman dorms, counselors' meetings are either un productive or non-
    existent. Supposedly, the problems that are making freshmen uncomfortable
    are very seldom discussed and, consequently, morale is low. Further, several
    staff members from Marts Hall used to visit the counselors last year, but
    those visits have been terminated. There is at least one reported in cident
    of a counselor being down graded by a head resident in front of his hall
    group. As for responsibility, the coun selor in the past was expected to be
    a social coordinator, but that as pect of the job has been down played.
    Freshman counselors also did not participate in this year's Freshman
    Orientation program and, thus, were unable to answer many ques tions. A t
    the end of this year, the fresh men were asked to evaluate their counselor.
    As unreliable as it may be, this seems to be the only kind of evaluation
    that is formally done. Finally, several counselors have the feeling that
    they are supposed to be policemen, but they have re jected this role.
    Unfortunately, however, there have been several instances of stu dents being
    summoned to Marts Hall after their counselors confi dentially reported
    infractions, which damage the relationship between counselor and student.
    The names are supposedly going on file, in case the students needed help
    later. There are several other changes, but they all involve non-communica
    tion and a lack of confidence be tween student personnel and resi dence hall
    administrators. The next section, to appear in the Friday issue of The
    BucknelUan, will deal with the methods of counselor selection. Concerned
    students and faculty are urged to boycott classes for the entire day. At
    their meeting last week, ABS endorsed the memorial service, as " . . .the
    death of these students at Kent State has become symbolic of the number of
    students elsewhere." ABS also requests that all mem bers of the University
    community attend the service and that " . . .for these 90 minutes all
    academic and non-academic business cease out of respect for those who have
    died." The service, moderated by Chap lain James Gardner, will include a
    service of remarks concerning Kent State and the broader aspects of the war
    by members of the Uni versity community. As May 5th will mark the culmin
    ation of the Spring Offensive, speakers will also discuss other aspects of
    the Offensive, such as poverty, racism, and repression. Provost Wendell
    Smith will de liver a statement issued by Presi dent Charles Watts. Also
    speaking will be: Father Ber nard Petrina, Newman chaplain; Dennis Baumwoll,
    assistant profes sor of English; Zoia Horn, read re ference librarian; Gene
    Cheno weth, professor of political science; Bob Nachshin, president of ABS;
    and David Young, spokesman for the Association of Blacks for Pro gress. An
    open forum will be held fol lowing the speakers' remarks. In case of rain,
    the memorial service will be held in Rooke Chapel.

Content: By GINA SMITH A Sunday morning fire destroyed a biology laboratory and office
    and caused extensive smoke damage on the second floor of Taylor Hall.
    Approximately 200 mice and twen ty or thirty birds died in the blaze. The
    remainder of the building's animals, including hamsters, guinea

Heading: Mexican-American
Content: 

Heading: Joins Psych Staff
Content: A scene from John Wheatcroft's of the fourteenth century poem, Saturday night.
    'Vision of Christ,"  a modern adaptation 'Piers Plowman,"  which premiered
    here vision takes the ancient form of psychomachia, which allows for the
    projection of parts of his mind into a series of dramatic characters whose
    interaction constitutes the working of his mind as it creates and renders
    his vision. The aesthetic risks involved in of fering such a poetic drama "
    on the order of a mystery play, 1970-71" are tremendous. The creators of
    Piers Plowman and the medieval mystery plays could assume much more about
    their audiences than can be assumed about a modern audience. In our
    receptiveness to the ex periences of myth and ritual, we cess gives us one
    of the most mag nificent lines in the poem: " For Christ was a knight,
    courageous, a King's son." The second transformation recasts the medieval
    experiences in modern terms, but here the transformation is no longer
    primarily visionary; now it is the modem idiom in the verse -- ''Then
    sighing sad Satan spoke to his gang"  -- and even more obviously the modem
    tonali ties and rhythms in the music which bring the traditional into
    conjunc tion with the contemporary. The third transformation, of course, is
    what gives us the per- (Continued on Page 3) By NANCY GRDEN Enrique J.
    Abordo has received the faculty position of assistant pro fessor of
    psychology, effective this September. He will be teaching two sections of
    general psychology, as well as a course in abnormal psychology. " Dr. Abordo
    plans to reorganize the general course so that they in clude field
    experience,"  stated Dr. Douglas Candland, chairman of the psychology
    department. " It is hoped that students will learn about psychology by
    seeing what a psy chologist does." Abordo received his A.B. from Loyola
    University of Los Angeles in 1962 and his M.A. from San Diego State College
    in 1964. He re ceived his Ph.D. from the Uni versity of California last
    December. His most recent faculty position has been assistant professor of
    psychology at Reed College. " Although Dr. Abordo is more than familiar with
    the Mexican- American communities in southern California,"  Dr. Candland
    stated, "he is coming to the University be cause he feels that it offers him
    the best opportunity for professional development, and we are pleased to
    have him here for that reason." Dr. Abordo hopes to do research in the
    fields of child psychology and primate learning, especially at the child
    study mobile unit center, which will be opening in the fall next to the
    psychology lab. " Dr. Abordo is interested in the field of problem solving
    and concept formation in children and the Great Apes,"  Dr. Candland
    continued. " His current interest is with how blind children solve problems
    be cause one of their sensory systems is removed from perception." " Dr.
    Abordo did his work for his master's and doctoral degrees on how human
    beings and primates solve novel problems, and his pro cedures for study have
    led other researchers to reorganize their ap proach to this area." pigs, and
    rabbits, were removed to safety. Senior biology major Ken Dang- man lost an
    entire set of lecture notes, research, and materials for his honors thesis
    in the fire. Tech nical assistant Thomas Maxon also lost much of his
    research work. Biology professor Jack Harclerode related, " There was
    extensive smoke damage in all of the labs and offices. Electrical power was
    lost temporarily on all floors of the building. Smoke and water damage
    resulted in the smudging of nearly all the glassware in the building." The
    fire alarm rang at 8:30 a.m. Sunday, but officials feel that the fire had
    been burning for at least an hour before that. At the time of the alarm, the
    night watchman had already left, and reportedly, no one was in the building.
    Fire officials found a burned-out circuit breaker on the second floor.
    However, they felt that until there was a more thorough investigation, the
    fire could not be attributed to any specific electrical cause. Two general
    biology labs and two organismal physiology classes were cancelled on Monday.
    However, Harclerode expressed his convic tion that the biology program would
    be operating on schedule today. " The physical plant people and the
    Lewisburg firemen have been exceedingly cooperative,"  he stated. " Twenty
    or more people from the physical plant worked in the build ing all day
    Monday. A number of people have also volunteered their services." University
    officials have not yet estimated the cost of the damage. f

Heading: Vision of Christ'
Content: To the Editor: In your April 23rd edition of The Bucknellian, there appeared a
    front page article about Professor Jerome Rinkus' views on the war in the
    Republic of Vietnam and the mili tary in general. We cannot allow such an
    article to pass without com ment. In Professor Rinkus' letter to the "
    Vietnam Veterans Against War" he signs his name as a " Retired Captain,
    USAR."  The word " re tired"  as used is incorrect. It is correct when used
    by members of the Armed Forces who have spent the major part of their lives
    (20 to 30 years.>> in the defense of their country. Begrudgingly serving
    one's obligation in the armed forces, as Professor Rinkus says he did, from
    ROTC cadet to Captain, in no way entitles anyone to use this title. " Former
    Captain,"  " One-time Cap tain," or if now in the US Army Reserve, "
    Captain, USAR"  would

Heading: =GUEST COLUMN
Content: 

Heading: Where's Our Commitment?
Content: _______________ By MICHAEL HOLOSZYC- There has been a lot of clamor on this
    campus aiwublthe .People's Peace Treaty this spring. The terms of it were
    rejected by the student body although they were accepted by the faculty and
    admmistration. Such results are enough to startle anyone. Are Bucknell
    students so re actionary that the faculty must take the initiative to act
    Pr?Sr(r)s(r)'ve ^ ' And are we soon coming to the point where the faculty
    will lead action for change while the students remain either apathetic or
    essentially conservative? Indeed, to endorse the People's Peace Treaty may
    be considered a radical act. It is an act of non-violent civil disobedience,
    since the Logan Act prohibits citizens to negotiate with a foreign coun ry.
    Vietnam the American students who negotiated the treaty returned from
    Vietnam this winter, J. Edgar Hoover announced that he had uncovered a plo
    to negotiate a peace treaty with the Vietnamese. Whether Bucknell students
    voted against the treaty nothing about it but heard " it wasn't good or
    unrealistic, or thev were deeply committed against endorsing such a
    disrespectful treaty, is not important now. As a group, we have declared
    ourselves; it is no up to each of us individuals to act. Sneaking to each of
    you as individuals then, there are certain points I would like to bring out.
    The treaty was negotiated by student groups of the United States, North
    Vietnam, and South Vietnam. It s main n - nortance is that the students have
    negoiated an honorable and immediate of the war while the U.S. government
    through their expert ne gotiations of peace in Paris have failed miserably.
    Nixon is concerned about having the American prisoners released from North
    Vietnam, but as yet has not been able to release them. The People's Peace
    Treaty provides for such release. Ainencans worry about the " bloodbath" to
    occur upon Americans leaving Vietnarn. The Treaty guarantees " the safety
    and political freedom of persons t H H i  S * with either side in the war."
    America's obligation in the treaty is to set a timetable for an immediate,
    total withdrawal, end the imposition of the Thieu government in Vietnam to
    insure seif-determmation and re lease of political prisoners, and finally,
    respect the mdepende , p and neutrality of Laos and Cambodia. The People's
    Peace Treaty establishes the way for peace in Vietnam now (" Vietnamese
    agree to participate in an immediate cease , Americans will pledge to
    withdraw now. Nixon has failed to bring peace tcTvietnam'as he promised, and
    it is now up to the American people to bring our government to accept the
    terms of the treaty. Tomorrow is a nationwide Moratorium in commemoration of
    the killings at Kent State and Jackson State Colleges last year. A year ago,
    you the Quad yelling about the injustices perpetuated by oiir government Bu
    y e l this year for most of you, the People's Peace Treaty was to radical,
    or whatever, to be supported. For those who still feel a commitment to end
    the war, I urge you to write to People's Peace Treaty, Room 900, 1029
    Vermont Avenue N.W Washington, D.C. 20005 and tell them you endorse the
    principles of the treaty It will probably be the first political letter
    you've written since your hysteria last May.

Heading: ]Redneck Country
Content: be acceptable. Professor Rinkus describes the " close cooperation of the educa
    tional system with the military." There are currently 11 students at
    Bucknell on ROTC scholarships who are directly thankful for the close
    cooperation as are many others in ROTC. For one reason, it has saved them
    and their parents a total of $27,927.50 thiis school year alone and perhaps
    has provided them with a unique opportunity to attend this fine institution.
    We would ask Pro fessor Rinkus if he would prefer the military to be led by
    un-educated individuals, or by well-educated young men such as those commis
    sioned from Bucknell. We would suggest that if Profes sor Rinkus would have
    left the " growing American community in Saigon"  (with its " bar maids,
    house maids and prostitutes" ) and served for extended periods in the field
    where the war is being fought, his low opinion of what Americans are doing
    in Vietnam might be com pletely different. In conclusion we would like to
    state that we are proud of our 1 Silver Star, 3 Bronze Star Medals for
    Valor, 13 Bronze Star Medals for Merit, 6 Air Medals, 11 Army Commendation
    Medals, 2 Purple Hearts, 1 Good Conduct Medals, 3 Vietnamese Crosses of
    Gallantry, 1 Vietnamese Honor Medal, and 2 Combat Infantry Badges,
    collective ly achieved. We are thankful to the American and Vietnamese
    people for so honoring us for we shall cherish these medals for the rest of
    our lives. Officers and Enlisted Men of the Military Science Program

Heading: JACK SCHMIDT -- Editor-In-Chief
Content: 

Heading: SUSAN PRESTON -- Executive Editor
Content: 

Heading: JOHN DICKERSON -- Business Manager
Content: By RICK VANCE Meeting the father is half the game when you're dating a hometown
    honey. Unfortunately it is the poorer half of my game, especially when my
    date is an unusually slow dresser. As I sat opposite one particular father,
    gamely attempting to match his stare (or rather, glare) I was hoping that
    his wife would join our little group. I must confess that I do very well
    with mothers, because unlike fathers, they don't get political. Mothers
    simply ask you if you're enjoying college, to which you reply, " Yes very
    much." Then they comment on how handsome you look, to which you reply with
    blushing modesty, " Thank you, you're looking very good yourself. I find it
    hard to believe you're old enough to be (name of 8 Most fathers are another
    thing, however. I usually soar through the section on trivia (" Oh yessir,
    the Yankees are my favorite team also. ) with flying colors, but I find it
    wise to restrict my participation in the political dialogue (or shall I say,
    soliloquy) that ensues to a few discreet Questions and frequent nodding
    combined with a profound wrinkling of my brow, an indication of thought.
    Take the following encounter, for pxamDiG , . . " Nixon's a good President,"
    the father said. I was tempted to ask his definition of " good"  but decided
    it would be worthless without his defini tions of " President" and " Nixon."
    " Of course I feel very strongly that he should begin to bomb more heavily."
    I resisted the impulse to com ment that our illustrious President had
    already " bombed enough. The trouble with this country," he continued, " is
    that we patronize those damn hippies. We should ship the whole bunch of 'em
    over to Vietnam. (Continued on Page 3)

Heading: THE BUCKNELLIAN
Content: MAY 4, 1971 To the Editor: Bucknell students voted down the " People's Peace
    Treaty."  Even the treaty's supporters said it was poorly written and "
    objectionable. We think Bucknell students should now make some statement of
    what they do support in relation to South East Asia. To this end the Ad Hoc
    Com mittee to Stop the Treaty submits the following Peace Proposal 1) There
    will be an immediate and unconditional cease-fire through- deg Ut 2)^ All
    people held as prisoners of war by the North or South Viet namese, the Viet
    Cong, the Americans, or any other force operating in South Vietnam will be
    released immediately and unconditionally. 3) All military forces not native
    to South Vietnam will withdraw from South Vietnam on a published timetable
    of withdrawal. 4) An election will be held in South Vietnam with all
    poetical views represented. All ballots will be secret to safeguard against
    future re- PresS)0I1Thef fjre the prisoner release, the withdrawal, and toe
    election will be guaranteed by the governments involved and will be en
    forced by international inspection. We urge all students who consider
    themselves antiwar and who voted against toe treaty to publicly support this
    proposal. We further urge the ABS, as our official spokesmai to endorse this
    proposal. The Ad Hoc Committee to Stop the Treaty To the Editor: Your focus
    coulmn of Friday, April 23 (Focus: Counselors) was interesting,
    entertaining, and turned my stomach. . . The system is wrong, that's true.
    And hard to live with, that's ob vious. It does appear that toe de cisions
    affecting so many people for longer than a year depend almost solely upon a
    single hour-long in terview with only one of the persons involved in toe
    selections, and it might seem that it's up to each individual candidate to "
    measure up" or forget it. It's also probable that it does matter " who you
    know" in terms of references from present counselors. These are faults of
    the system. You, however, go one step further. You refer to yes-men, liars
    and apple-polishers. You're point ing to the new counselors and play ing a
    nasty little name-calling game. Whether you intended it or not, your
    generalizations got a little too specific, . . Sincerely, Patty Grier

Heading: P.S.
Content: >>' If you're so hyper about the sys tem now, why didn't you speak up before the
    selections were made? And what are you going to do to solve the problem now?

Heading: Now, Dean!
Content: To the Editor: Although the Beach Boys might not be typical of the " heavy"  su
    pergroups and Mike Love's t-shirt may not be the latest fashion, their music
    and performance this past weekend were superior in nature... Dean Landew was
    into D.Q. and Pepsi in 65; some of us didn't make that scene until
    Woodstock, when a lot of " freaks"  were getting high on nothing more than
    Pepsi and toe Airplane. Anyway, who gives a damn whether Dean flashes on
    coke or Pepsi. Those old songs brought back a lot of great memories to many
    and, anyway, would Dean object to the Beatles doing Norwegian Wood or the
    Stones doing Satisfaction in Concert? Needless to say, we are grateful that
    The Bucknellian has such " hip" reporters who give (Continued on Page 3) * f
    (Continued from Page I) lormance itself; it is here that toe vision becomes
    dramatic and the revelation is shared. In each of these three transforma
    tions the Vision judges us and finds us weak, our vision impaired, and our
    community in fragments. The audience at toe premier perform ance either did
    not know the story of the Passion or its members were mostly Protestants who
    insisted on interpreting the gospel for them selves; the sound of the
    turning of pages in toe program notes sug gested that for many the only
    vision was of faintly visible print. In a Myth-play, authority and judgement
    come from the stage, and consider ing how little rehearsal time the
    performers had with the complete text, the authority of the perform ance was
    remarkable. There are surely countless visions of this work which in each
    case open up the gap between dream and realization: the author's vision of
    what they created and of what they saw performed, the perform er's of the
    effects they wished to achieve and of what they were able to achieve, the
    audience's of what they were being challenged to ex perience and of what
    they were capable of experiencing. But such an awareness of our mutual in
    adequacies is central to the poem. In the Prologue, the Poet is con scious
    of toe weight of his belly on his soul, but he is nevertheless aware that
    his " lewd letters"  cre ate the possibility " that all tie from my time
    some profit shall take."

Heading: Redneck Country
Content: (Continued from Page 2) I offered one of my rare comments, " I doubt if they'd
    make very good fighters," and smiled inwardly at toe neutrality of my
    statement. " No, but they'd make damn good targets,"  he shouted. My nervous
    smile accompanied the roar of his laughter. He looked at me very strangely,
    no doubt suspecting that his joke (I hope it was a joke) was over my head.
    Then he switched the topic to a jumble of race and prison reforms. " And
    those rioters. They oughta shoot the whole bunch of 'em ." His eyes shouted
    a faded red, white, and blue, the colors, incidentally, of the milennia of
    flags decorating his yard. " Hell, they can leave anytime they want, right?"
    " Oh, absolutely right,"  I replied with a cleverly concealed barb at his
    political orientation. " Damn right. Christ, if those judges weren't so
    liberal, we could throw all those jerks in prison." " We?"  He eyed me with
    distrust. I was beginning to wish I had a crewcut. " Yeah,"  he said, " it's
    about time the people start doing something." I agreed with this latter
    statement, although most likely not with the im plication the gentleman had
    in mind. Fortunately as toe man was telling me with a straight face that I
    should ENLIST in the airforce rather than the other branches because air
    power is " more effective,"  his daughter came bouncing into the room, and
    we left. Whew! j

Heading: Scoblick
Content: A member of the Harrisburg 6, Tony Scoblick, is presently carrying on a hunger
    strike, and is consum ing nothing but liquids. He started the fast Monday
    afternoon in front of the Federal building in Harris burg. An informed
    source has stated that he is protesting the psycholo gical methods being
    used by the federal government against every body involved in the trial. The
    specific actions which he is protesting is the attempt on the part of the
    government to make friends testify against each other. Or as Scoblick has
    said, " They are bothering my friends."

Heading: 125TH ANNIVERSARY ISSUE
Content: 

Heading: FRIDAY, APRIL 30, 1971
Content: 

Heading: THE RUCKNELLIAN
Content: 

Heading: Sf,
Content: 

Heading: Assists!
Content: 

Heading: Laxmen Edge Washington, 54;
Content: 

Heading: Battle with Delaware Saturday
Content: 

Heading: Racketeers Rally over Raiders;
Content: 

Heading: Engage Nittany Lions Tomorrow
Content: By ALAN GROCHAL By shutting out Washington Col lege in the second half, the Herd
    gained a 5-4 victory in lacrosse Saturday before a large Parents Day crowd.
    A goal by Dan Nourse with less than five minutes remaining in the third
    period broke a 4-4 tie and proved to be the winning score. For Nourse, who
    leads the team with 17 goals, it was his second score of the day. Earlier
    his goal had given the Bisons a short-lived 4-3 advantage. Coach Sid
    Jamieson felt that the key to the BU victory was a more disciplined offense
    than Washington. "Our offense is set up so that we play for the good shot
    whereas most teams take 50 shots a game, our total is usually between 30 and
    40." he noted. Due to the victory, the Bisons now maintain their position in
    a tie for the MAC lead. BU is now 5-1 in league play and 5-3 overall. The
    laxmen's next game, this Saturday, at Delaware, shapes up as another big
    contest. Delaware is one of the teams tied with the Herd for first place in
    the MAC, and Jamieson considers them the rough est opponent remaining on the
    sche dule. " Delaware has an extremely ag gressive team. They double-team
    often so there should be plenty of physical contact in the game."  He said.
    Balance seems to be the key to the laxmen's success thus far. Against
    Washington, all of the goals were assisted, again pointing up great teamwork
    on the part of the Bisons. " The fact that we do have such a balanced team
    means that our op ponents cannot just stop one man to beat us. They will
    have to stop a number of players to win." Dan Nourse goes for the score. The
    talented junior is the team's leading scorer with seven teen goals, (photo
    by Eric Riess) By MARK KNODERER The Bison netters overcame a game Colgate
    team, 5-4, Saturday aftemoot at home to gamer their ninth straight victory
    of the season and twenty-fourth straight over a two year period. On Friday
    after noon the team had defeated the Syracuse Orangemen, 8-1 at home.
    Colgate coach Joe Abramson used an extensive switch of his lineup to pull
    off the near miss, a tactic which was quickly dubbed the " Abramson Stack"
    offense by the Bisons. The morals of tennis state that you should always
    play your best man at the number one position, and so on, but this unwritten
    rule is not always followed. Abramson claimed injuries and personal prob
    lems forced the drastic changes, but the story does not fit. For instance:
    Geoff Steadman played sixth singles and first doubles. Steve Schindler,
    normally the third singles player, played first singles and third doubles.
    Jack Neems played at the second singles position, but did not play doubles.
    Dick Kadesch, the second singles player, was taking medical exams during the
    singles, but returned to play second doubles. Fortunately the upper half of
    the Bison ladder refused to be sha ken by the shenanigans. Steve Baird, Alex
    Anderson, and Jim Lackritz all won in singles, and Baird and Anderson won at
    first doubles. The bottom half of the ladder floundered a bit, but made a re
    spectable showing with the crucial win by frosh Bruce Kevan at sixth
    singles, and taking the second and third doubles into three sets. Ke-

Heading: Track Records
Content: van's opponent, Randy Adam, was the number one ranked junior (18 and under)
    player in New England. All singles matches were over in two sets except
    third singles. There, Lackritz won what coach Reynolds called the " crucial"
    point of the Junior Steve Baird had no trouble at all this week in
    maintaining his win streak, (photo by Bob Arnold)

Content: match by winning the third set, 6-3. This gave the Bisons a 4-2 lead, which was
    much more acceptable than a 3-3 deadlock. Against Syracuse, only the sore
    shoulder of Bob Christianson pre vented the Bisons from a shut out.

Heading: Golfers Parry MAC Foes;
Content: 

Heading: Bison Glovemen Split Pair
Content: By JIM NORTHRIDGE The linksmen picked up two big victories on Friday as they de
    feated MAC rivals Rider 5-2 and Lafayette 6-1 at home. Freshman George
    Ferantelli had low score as he completed the course in 72. From his number
    one position, captain Mark Reddy shot a 73. A pair of sophomores, Dan Stetz
    and Greg Mordas, along with junior A1 Shiftier were big double winners for
    the linksmen. The golfers are traveling to Le high today to face the
    Engineers and the GGettysburg Bullets in a tri-meet. The linksmen will then
    participate in the MAC s at Rider next Monday. By KEN DOAK The Bison
    diamondmen settled for a split with their hosts, Gettysburg, on Saturday,
    though Coach Tommy Thompson said " we should have won two."  One bad inning
    cost them a sweep and brought their record to 5-11. In the opener, Tony
    Zidansek con tinued his excellent pitching as he hurled a three-hitter to
    lead BU to a 3-1 victory. Bernie Berninger led off the game with a home-run
    to give Bucknell a lead. However, with two outs in the third, a walk and a
    double by the Bullets knotted the score. The Bisons finally won it in the
    sixth when John Rudolph belted a clutch home-run, Chris Riley fol lowed with
    a walk, and Gene Luc- carelli later scored him wiith a double to make the
    score 3-1. In the second game, the Herd built up a 4-1 lead and then watch
    ed it disappear during a six-run Gettysburg fifth inning. BU got on the
    scoreboard in the second frame when Berninger singled and later scored on a
    Mike Marinchak sacrifice fly. They got two more runs in the third when Steve
    Eek and Riley de livered base hits. Rudolph and Mar inchak then drew walks,
    and a passed ball brought home another score. Then came the disasterous
    fifth, as the Bullets bunched 4 hits and 3 walks to win 7-4. The Bisons will
    meet Susquehanna at home Thursday with Zidansek on the mound.

Heading: Set at Quantico
Content: The cindermen traveled to the Quantico Relays over the weekend. Tom Hagerty
    established a Bucknell record in the three-mile with a time of 15:13.5. At
    Quantico, Doug Nauman broke his own record in the javelin with a toss of
    222' 11" . The mile relay team ran a 3:23.3 for its best time of the season.
    Members of the quartet were Glenn McLaughlin (51.3), Paul Hermle (51.9),
    John Lamer (51.0), and Rick Francel 49.1).

Heading: '125: Just the Beginning'
Content: 

Heading: A LETTER FROM THE EDITOR
Content: 

Heading: One advantage which history affords is the
Content: 

Heading: opportunity for reviewing, concluding and, conse
Content: 

Heading: quently, projecting. Bucknell University has! had
Content: 

Heading: 125 years of history, and its past is, indeed, a
Content: 

Heading: means of distinguishing the roots of contemporary
Content: 

Heading: trends and the direction of University PS(tm)wth in
Content: 

Heading: the future. In this commemorative 125th an
Content: 

Heading: niversary magazine supplement sponsored by The
Content: 

Heading: Bucknellian, some of Bucknell's past, present and
Content: 

Heading: prospects are described.
Content: 

Heading: Any kind of publication --  or writing, for
Content: 

Heading: that matter --  demands selection when content
Content: 

Heading: is decided upon and, in a magazine which initially
Content: 

Heading: attempts an overview of the years 1846-1971,
Content: 

Heading: selection obviously becomes a crucial factor. One
Content: 

Heading: can only hope that enough "flavor" of the years
Content: 

Heading: will filter through the words and pictures that
Content: 

Heading: were eventually chosen for this issue.
Content: 

Heading: Contributing writers like seniors Robert Wen-
Content: 

Heading: del, Don Thompson, Dan Miller and Eric Riess,
Content: 

Heading: junior Nicki Drew, sophomores June Heistand and
Content: 

Heading: Nancy Grden and freshman Dean Landew make
Content: 

Heading: the selection process work in this magazine because
Content: 

Heading: each in penning a particular aspect of Bucknell
Content: 

Heading: University's evolution,
Content: 

Heading: develops an essay
Content: 

Heading: in
Content: 

Heading: dividually characterizing various things like the
Content: 

Heading: school's growth, personalities, issues or (what
Content: 

Heading: seem now as) trivialities.
Content: 

Heading: The photographs too, submitted by Riess and
Content: 

Heading: Bob Arnold, capture amusing or pertinent " spots
Content: 

Heading: of time" in Bucknell's past and present.
Content: 

Heading: And, while selection admittedly limits the
Content: 

Heading: degree of overall comprehensiveness, it neverthe
Content: 

Heading: less offers a chance for the "best" and most in
Content: 

Heading: teresting of the years.
Content: 

Heading: This supplement to The Bucknellian is broken
Content: 

Heading: into three sections which, though divided, do blend
Content: 

Heading: themselves one-into-another as time does itself
Content: 

Heading: so naturally. "The past" consists of a series of
Content: 

Heading: features on subjects ranging from early admis
Content: 

Heading: sions requirements to a portrayal of Lewisburg
Content: 

Heading: " way back w h e n "the present" is an interview
Content: 

Heading: with four contemporary Bucknellians: two ad
Content: 

Heading: ministrators and two students; "the prospects
Content: 

Heading: records comments from leading administrators as
Content: 

Heading: to the future of this University s activity.
Content: 

Heading: While this publication is necessarily only a
Content: 

Heading: " scratching of the surface," it invites the reader
Content: 

Heading: to enjoy the retrospection and projection it otters
Content: 

Heading: --  and to see that " 125" is, clearly, "just the be
Content: 

Heading: ginning" for Bucknell University.
Content: 

Heading: --  DAVID HAMMER
Content: 

Heading: 1846 - -
Content: 

Heading: - -1971
Content: 

Heading: US
Content: 

Heading: the past
Content: 

Heading: The Golden Years
Content: By ROBERT WENDEL Focusing on the last thirty years, Buck- nell has undergone
    some relatively drastic changes which are clearly reflected in past issues
    of the student-controlled Buck nellian. And, while many students may never
    admit it, most of these changes have occurred under the administration of
    Presi dent Charles Watts. For example, one of the " big stories" of the past
    appeared in a 1939-40 edition -- and seems ironic today: " $1000 Awards Held
    By Three." It continues to read " Three freshmen arrived on campus secure in
    the knowledge that their academic mindedness had assisted them in winning
    the three competitive scholarships of $1000 each given annually by the
    University." This three thousand dollars in awards is a far cry from the
    present assistance pro gram which now reckons near a half mil lion dollars
    annually. Besides the obvious change in the assist ance program, curricula
    have also changed over the years. On the same page as the $10^0 feature, an
    almost inconspicu ous article appears which concerns Dr. Lewis E. Theiss.
    The article itself merely concerns a wedding, but the curious part is that
    Dr. Theiss was, at that time, " the head of the Bucknell Department of Journ
    alism." Journalism?

Heading: TRADITIONALLY SPEAKING
Content: One fact becomes perfectly clear in surveying past issues of the student news
    paper: Bucknell was truly " steeped" in tradition. Every year, one of the
    most important stories concerned Freshman Rules, and 1939 was no exception.
    One headline read, " New Style Dink is Now Custom on B.U. Campus;"  it is a
    sad re minder of days gone by in which freshman " hazing" occurred on a
    University-wide level. The story continues: " The 'mourning garb' of the
    lowly frosh (dinks, black ties and black socks > has been the tradition oi
    traditions at Bucknell for many years. All freshmen wear the traditional
    garb until the Senior Tribunal decides when dinks may be put in mothballs,
    or until the Frosh have smeared the faces of their more elevated Sophomore
    brothers with the gore of bat tie." From this article, two things become
    self-evident. One is that the school, in general, understood and practiced
    their traditions seriously; also, the Bucknellian played a major role in
    defending those traditions. Probably the single most revealing thing about
    BucknelTs past which may be de termined from the Bucknellian series is that
    a tremendous emphasis was placed on sports activity. Football stories more
    often than not were considered as front page news; sports reporting amounted
    to nearly half of the news copy for any given issue, too. It was not unusual
    to see an article concerning an upcoming pep-rally or an intra-mural "
    slugfest" on page one. Along with its emphasis on sports, Buck nell was a
    deeply religious institution, and a dramatic change in the University over
    the years has been its slow transition from a strongly sectarian school to a
    non-sec tarian one. (Gone forever are the days when attendance at chapel was
    compul sory. )

Heading: STEADY SHIFT
Content: One of the major reasons for this re versal in orientation has been the shift
    from its being a strictly local college to a university with a national
    reputation and relatively diverse student body. Where in the " golden years"
    past the school was composed mostly of peaceful farmers and a good number of
    Quakers, the character of the school now is defined by an influx of New
    York, Philadelphia and New Jersey residents -- many of whom are Jewish. And
    with this influx of more highly academic-oriented students came a more
    liberal faculty, presidents and, of course, students. Although the trend
    seems obvious in retrospect, it was anything but sudden. By 1953, a major
    difference in emphasis by the school newspaper could be felt in the obvious
    omissions of both sports and religious activities from the front page. Gone
    as well was the extensive " Society" section which 'prior to this point in
    time' had scrutinized what seem now as the most trivial events of the Greek
    calendar. Con currently with this pattern, it seems that the Greek system
    itself was beginning to take a " back seat" to more important issues on
    campus -- although the in overall activities was still very significant in
    the 1950's. But individuals were thinking along fluence of fraternities and
    sororities on the nationally-oriented lines, despite the con tinued
    influence of the Greek social world -- as evidenced in a column entitled "
    Color, Religious and Racial Discrimination at Bucknell" in the Oct. 6, 1950
    issue of The Bucknellian. In this article, the writer was well-ahead of his
    time when he stated " We Tike to believe' as Americans living in a land of
    the free under Democratic morals and principles that we are truly Demo
    cratic. Unfortunately for Bucknell, what we should Tike to believe' and what
    is the 'truth' are two relatively incompatible points." The column, on the
    whole, refers spe cifically to the fraternities -- and to man kind, in
    general. However, despite such individual stands, the majority of students
    would have sided at this time with the Editor's comment following the
    article: " Columnist Unger's views do not necessarily represent those of the
    paper. It is hoped that someone will answer his fraternity condemnation."
    Buck nell simply was not ready for the college " Liberal;" everyone seemed
    too interested in drinking and playing sports.

Heading: NEW IMAGE
Content: A major change in the Bucknellian oc curred in 1960, reflecting a new campus
    concern and a new Bucknell image. National issues arose throughout the
    paper, and not merely in single editorials. The big concern at that time was
    the Nixon- Kennedy presidential campaign, and the newspaper carried at least
    two articles a week addressing it. The series of articles was climaxed by a
    campus-wide, mock election to see who the " average" Bucknell student
    favored in the upcoming election. The results: al though the campus favored
    Nixon 2:1, what is impressive is that " almost half of those who voted for
    Kennedy voted dif

Heading: Compliments of
Content: 

Heading: 1
Content: 

Heading: MAEmmm
Content: Wml(r) . _________ , ;V - ferently than their family, whereas only live percent
    did so in voting for Nixon." It seems that the Bucknell student was, more or
    less, beginning to demonstrate a liberal trend, and it was this trend which
    sparked serious inquiries on campus re garding students rights, concerns and
    free doms. The important student questions were being asked in the 1960's. A
    perusal of the editorial page of the newspaper in 1960 uncovers the
    following self-explanatory titles: " Discrimination;" " Women's Stu dent
    Government: What for?;"  " SFC -- Yawn?" : " Wake U p!" And these questions
    set the stage for changes which occurred over the next ten years:
    elimination of compulsory chapel; elimination of SFC and its subsequent
    replacement by ABS; re duction from five courses per semester to four; and
    elimination of compulsory ROTC. It can only be hoped that objective criti
    cism of the University will continue in the future, as has been the trend
    over the past ten years; for, clearly, if the students ac complish as much
    in the next ten years as was achieved in the decade past, Bucknell might
    just start to approach what may be known as "the Golden Years."

Heading: IEWISBURG:
Content: 

Heading: Expanding Town
Content: By NICKI DREW The activity of Lewisburg revolved, in 1846, around its waterways.
    The Susquehanna River was not adequate for the town's growing commerce and,
    in 1833, the citizens were therefore granted a cross-cut canal which was
    responsible (by the time the University was founded) for much of Lewisburg's
    commerce, industry and recreation. Indeed, much of Lewisburg's industry de
    pended on water. The resulting ship-build ing business, flour mill, woolen
    mill and saw mill relied on the streams and the canal, naturally, for power.
    As the mills grew, so did the town -- and with that growth came other, small
    busi nesses. Donehower's Store (1877) and Gundy's Hat Shop are two obvious
    ex amples. Others, including a nail factory, brick yard and chair factory
    (which has since become a general furniture outlet) also helped make
    Lewisburg a center for industry in this area.

Heading: CULTURAL APPETITE
Content: Besides the small-industrial growth, Lewisburg's cultural appetite was satisfied
    by its own Opera House which resided in the area behind (what is now) the
    post office. According to a longtime Lewisburg resident, Robert Donehower,
    the House seated from twelve to fifteen hundred patrons; it featured such
    personages as Henrietta Crozman, DeWolf Hopper and Eva Tanguay (do they ring
    a bell?^ and shows including Mistress Nell, " High Henry's Minstrels" and
    the Follies. When it was destroyed by a fire over fifty years ago -- and
    never replaced -- perhaps one could say that Lewisburg's cultural life went
    up in smoke. Other " institutions" were dominant in Lewisburg's past, too.
    The Railroad was an important part of the town -- and a significant means of
    transportation for many students attending the steadily-ex panding
    University. Market Street: 'One and only' ( photo by Allan H. Jodrey) | %

Heading: RELATIONSHIP CHANGE
Content: The University expanded concomitantly with Lewisburg's growth; indeed, the " Uni
    versity has always been closely tied with the life of the town" as John
    Zeller, Vice President of Administration and Finance explains. In fact, most
    Lewisburg children more often than not attended the University when they
    graduated from high school in the distant past. However, the past twenty
    years has led to a change in the relationship between residents of the town
    and college students themselves. In the past, the students neces sarily
    interacted closely with the town: most of the fraternities had houses down
    town; those who were not Greek lived in town boarding-houses; because there
    was no chapel on campus, many students were involved with local church
    activities; and the bookstores and mail service were located in Lewisburg.
    Now, interaction need not occur to such an extent because of the increased
    facilities on campus. But as Zeller describes, there has al ways ' seemed to
    be an elemental gap be tween students and town residents in every college
    town -- no matter how much inter action superficially exists: indeed, the "
    townspeople have always thought that the students were crazy, and the
    students have always thought that the townspeople were hicks -- and they're
    both wrong. The construction of the Federal Peni tentiary in 1932, another
    large Lewisburg- based institution, caused so much joy to the citizens that
    it was opened with a gala celebration.

Heading: By JUNE HEISTAND
Content: 

Heading: ALMA MATER
Content: 

Heading: Samuel Sears Merriman, who graduated from
Content: 

Heading: Bucknell in 1886, composed the school's alma
Content: 

Heading: mater in 1897 when that year's graduating class
Content: 

Heading: requested " Dear Bucknell" for a songbook they
Content: 

Heading: were publishing.
Content: 

Heading: "OLD MAIN'S' DESIGN
Content: 

Heading: The plans for " Old Main" (now Roberts Hall)
Content: 

Heading: were a gift to the newly-founded University by
Content: 

Heading: Thomas U. Walter, designer of the House and
Content: 

Heading: Senate wings of the Capitol in Washington, D.C.
Content: 

Heading: The original designs for the building provided for
Content: 

Heading: centrally-located classrooms and student rooms
Content: 

Heading: in each wing.
Content: 

Heading: A LOT OF 'BULL'
Content: 

Heading: Bucknell teams had no nickname sixty-five
Content: 

Heading: years ago. To remedy that situation, the late
Content: 

Heading: William C. Bartol, professor of both mathematics
Content: 

Heading: and astronomy, and coach of the baseball team,
Content: 

Heading: suggested that the designation " Bisons" be adopt
Content: 

Heading: ed for
Content: 

Heading: geographical
Content: 

Heading: reasons.
Content: 

Heading: The
Content: 

Heading: University
Content: 

Heading: campus lies at the eastern end of the Buffalo
Content: 

Heading: Valley, one of the last " stomping grounds" for
Content: 

Heading: the American bison. In fact, the last buffalo in
Content: 

Heading: this area was shot in 1801, two miles from
Content: 

Heading: Memorial Stadium.
Content: 

Heading: THE ORANGE AND BLUE
Content: 

Heading: In 1887, increasingly aware that most col
Content: 

Heading: leges were identifying themselves with colors,
Content: 

Heading: the students of Bucknell voted that orange and
Content: 

Heading: blue become the colors of their University. Ten
Content: 

Heading: years after, the first issue of a weekly newspaper
Content: 

Heading: was published, named the
Content: 

Heading: Orange and Blue --
Content: 

Heading: student vote later changed it to
Content: 

Heading: The Bucknellian.
Content: 

Heading: ALUMNI RELATIONS
Content: 

Heading: Through one of its alumni, Bucknell has left
Content: 

Heading: its mark on the state of Alaska. Charles E. Bun
Content: 

Heading: nell, who received Bachelor's, Master's and Honor
Content: 

Heading: ary degrees from Bucknell, was the founder and
Content: 

Heading: first president of the University of Alaska; until
Content: 

Heading: his retirement in 1949, he was considered the fore
Content: 

Heading: most educator in the territory.
Content: 

Heading: Around the world: Bucknell 'University has
Content: 

Heading: become known in Argentina via a contribution to
Content: 

Heading: international education. In 1963, the University
Content: 

Heading: signed a contract with the Agency for Interna
Content: 

Heading: tional Development of the State Department.
Content: 

Heading: Under the direction of Dean Herbert Eckberg,
Content: 

Heading: the College of Engineering assisted the University
Content: 

Heading: of Cordoba, Argentina, to improve its undergrad
Content: 

Heading: uate engineering program.
Content: 

Heading: LARSON AND BUCKNELL
Content: 

Heading: Jens Frederick Larson, architect for the soon-
Content: 

Heading: to-be-completed University Center, was first em
Content: 

Heading: ployed by Bucknell in 1932 when the Trustees
Content: 

Heading: approved a plan to re-organize the campus in an
Content: 

Heading: effort to make it as " architectually beautiful as
Content: 

Heading: possible." Larson devoted a full year to the de
Content: 

Heading: velopment of a general plan for the University --
Content: 

Heading: and to the construction of a model-in-miniature of
Content: 

Heading: the future campus. The first completed unit of
Content: 

Heading: the new plan was the Vaughan Literature Build
Content: 

Heading: ing, which was financed with the insurance money
Content: 

Heading: collected from the then-recent fire in " Old Main."
Content: 

Heading: FIRST AND FOREMOST
Content: 

Heading: Bucknell has had some real '"firsts." Among
Content: 

Heading: them: the new college Bookstore of 1958 was one
Content: 

Heading: of the first self-service stores of its kind in the
Content: 

Heading: country. Also, when students moved into "Old
Content: 

Heading: Main," they found themselves residing in a build
Content: 

Heading: ing which, in 1850, was the nation's largest Uni
Content: 

Heading: versity edifice. In 1935, the Bucknell Bisons de
Content: 

Heading: feated the University of Miami in the first
Content: 

Heading: Orange Bowl game. The score: 26-0.
Content: 

Heading: ONLY ONE MORE TO GO
Content: 

Heading: In 1962, the University commenced a ten-year
Content: 

Heading: development campaign to provide Bucknell with
Content: 

Heading: increased capital for endowments, three new build
Content: 

Heading: ings (a chapel, women's residence hall and campus
Content: 

Heading: center), the renovation of Harris Hall, a Science
Content: 

Heading: Research Center as an annex to Dana Engineer
Content:

Heading: Student Heroes
Content: 

Heading: By DAN MILLER
Content: 

Heading: Many years ago, in a little town tucked
Content: 

Heading: away in central Pennsylvania, there was
Content: 

Heading: a center of higher education called Bucknell
Content: 

Heading: University. Much of the time the students
Content: 

Heading: worried about exams, compulsory chapel,
Content: 

Heading: classes and a smoking room for women.
Content: 

Heading: But for entertainment they avidly followed
Content: 

Heading: the exploits of their heroes: the student-
Content: 

Heading: athletes.
Content: 

Heading: In an ever increasing variety of ways,
Content: 

Heading: the student-athletes pitted sinew and cun
Content: 

Heading: ning against gladiators from other insti
Content: 

Heading: tutions. The result of this continual struggle
Content:

Content: 

Heading: stories and myths about the individuals
Content: 

Heading: ers, and history notes his outstanding per
Content: 

Heading: formances in the NFL by his spot in the

Content:

Content:

Content:

Content: 

Heading: that year. Meyers gained 1069 yards and
Content: 

Heading: Talmage ground out 1025. At the time, it
Content:

Content: 

Heading: history to have two halfbacks with over
Content: 

Heading: 1000 yards to their credit. Both runners
Content:

Content:

Content:

Content:

Content: 

Heading: the Bisons.

Heading: waterpolo team that ranked third in the
Content: cific requirements tor any science or matn knowledge, even if the student were
    enter ing the "scientific course." The 1900-01 University Catalogue outlines
    the information which a student would be expected to know for the entrance
    examin ation which was given to the freshman class the day it arrived on
    campus. Students were expected to be competent in "writing from dictation,
    English gram mar. . .and no candidate will be accepted in English whose work
    is notably defective in spelling, punctuation, idiom or division into
    paragraphs."

Heading: GENERAL KNOWLEDGE
Content: The student was also expected to have a general knowledge of books such as Ivan-

Heading: hoe, The Vicar of Wakefield, Silas Mamer
Content: and others. He was supposed to have know ledge about the metric system,
    quadratic equations, the histories of Greece, Rome and the United States and
    geography. He likewise was required to be able to do free hand drawing, and
    to "commit to memory as much English poetry as possible." The admissions
    situation at the University changed considerably with the advent of World
    War H, however. Before the war, enrollment had been approximately 1200
    students <800 men and 400 women) -- the same 2:1 ratio as exists presently.
    With the war, though, the University population was almost entirely female.
    "Men's dorms were used for women, and even some of the fraternity houses
    like Kappa Sigma, Delta Upsilon and Phi Gamma Delta were used as living
    quarters for women," explained Heller. "The University was obliged to take
    more women to keep it functioning, despite he previous 2:1 ratio in favor of
    the men."

Heading: POST-WAR BOOM
Content: After the war, the 2:1 ratio became the norm again. "Veterans were returning to
    '.he University to complete their college education where they had left off
    before the war began: others were taking ad vantage of the GI Bill: still
    others were just then approaching college age," Zeller indicated. "The
    enrollment nearly doubled and. in 1949. there were 642 graduates -- the
    largest graduating class for the Uni versity to that date." "After this
    post-war boom in college en rollment. a small slack in enrollment num bers
    was felt, due mostly to the accompany ing economic slump of the U.S. after
    the war," as Fitz Walling, director of admis sions. explained. "At this
    time, there were two men in the admissions department, and they had to
    commence recruiting again as a result of the slump. Throughout the early and
    middle fifties, however, admis sions picked up. Zeller indicated that "the
    boom of stu dent enrollments in colleges and universi ties across the
    country during the fifties is still expanding, but it is likely to level off
    in the next ten or fifteen years." Reasons for this include the facts that
    "the number of births since the 'baby boom' in the fifties has decreased and
    the cost of a college education is climbing steadily." "A lot depends on
    what happens eco nomically in the U.S. -- the outcome will determine whether
    students will be able to afford attendance at private universi ties." "In
    fact, if costs continue to rise, we may get to the point where we would
    operate as we did in the thirties: that is, actively recruiting students to
    attend the Uni versity." By NANCY GRDEN "Before World War II, students could
    actually walk in on the day of registration and be admitted to the
    University right on the spot," reminisced John Zeller, Vice President of
    Administration & Finance, as he reflected on the history of the admissions
    process at the University. During the period between the founding of the
    University in 1846 and the end of World War II, there was actually no stan
    dard admissions process: anyone who wanted to enroll -- and could afford it
    -- was admitted. The admissions staff itself consisted of one man who had
    the job of recruiting students and publicizing the University's name.
    Intercollegiate sports were, perhaps, the primary means of promoting the Uni
    versity. "This technique was used by most colleges, and is, still widely
    practiced to day," remarked Zeller. "If you can de velop a good team, then
    your name will be more widely known. This was one of the factors which
    justified intercollegiate sports." The University also scheduled its Glee
    Club, orchestra and other student organi zations on annual tours in towns
    and high schools with the future hope of publicizing the University's
    reputation. The Baptist Church played an integral role in recruiting
    students for the Uni versity before and during World War II, even though it
    neither supported nor con trolled the school. Admissions requirements
    themselves were considerably less stringent before World War II, as
    indicated earlier. For example, in the University Catalogue for the aca
    demic year 1851-52, the "required age for admission is fifteen. The student
    must also prove himself conversant with English Grammar, Arithmetic,
    Geography, the La tin and Greek grammars, the prose part of the Greek
    Reader, two books of Caesar's Commentaries and four books of Virgil's
    Aeneid. It is also recommended that the student be acquainted with Algebra
    through simple equations.

Heading: SCIENTIFIC COURSE'
Content: "To enter the scientific course, the stu dent must prove himself conversant with
    the above English studies, and some ele mentary history of the United
    States. He must also be able to write respectable English compositions."
    There are no spe East in 1969.

Heading: THE BIG LEAGUES
Content: In the springtime, the Herd turns to the diamond where some of the most impres
    sive exploits have been recorded. Fore most among these are the performances
    of Christy Mathewson. "The Big Six" is considered one of the premier
    pitchers in the history of baseball -- earning a spot in the Baseball Hall
    of Fame in Cooperstown. In the early days of the sport, profes sional scouts
    spent a good deal of heir time in the pleasant Buffalo Valle; In 1910 the
    entire starting nine was gi.cn a chance to play in the Majors. There have
    been Bisons disguised as Pirates, Giants and Orioles. All together, more
    than 20 former BU players have advanced to the major leagues. The efforts of
    the Herd on the diamond are numerous as they are in any other sport. From
    the days when "Belting Bill" Lane was known as Bloomsburg Public Enemy No. 1
    for the way he played against them, to that afternoon in 1969 when Randy
    Ruger hit a homer with two on and two out in the last inning to give the
    Herd an MAC Championship, the triumphs are impressive. (Ruger's home run
    earned the diamondmen a bid to play in the NCAA tournament which was
    declined in favor of "academic responsibilities.") In between these events a
    pitcher named Don Richards was whiffing batters all over the MAC. In his
    three year varsity career Richards struck out 354 men. He also won one no-
    hitter by the score of 6-4. The adventures of the Herd will con tinue in the
    present and future as talented competitors rally forth to do battle on the
    gridiron and diamond. And, as long as they continue, they will add to the
    cultural environment of Bucknell and contribute to the growing body of
    stories and legends about the little school hidden away in the Susquehanna
    Valley.

Heading: Mathewson: Having left

Heading: CURRICULA:

Heading: 'Dramatic' Shifts
Content: By DON THOMPSON From its roots in the Academy and Fe- male Institute <whose
    purpose was to pre M re women for the cheerful discharge of the duties of
    life" ), Bucknell University has

Heading: come
Content: to offer a relatively diverse and com prehensive curriculum. The first catalog
    of the University of Lewisburg described forty-four courses which were,
    consequently offered to fifty six students by four professors. The uni
    versity at Lewisburg became " Bucknell University" in 1886 and, a few years
    later, President David Jayne Hill began to in troduce elective courses.
    Departments with " names and numbers anneared in 1879, but were not fully es
    tablished until 1888. The twelve departments included English Language and
    Literature, Greek Language and Literature, Modern Languages, Medieval and
    Modern History, PhvsicsSS and Chemistry, Math and As- fronomy, Organic
    Science, Economics and Politics and Mental and Moral Sciences.

Heading: A new
Content: course which President John Howard Harris called the " eclectic course was added
    in 1891. It was a utilitarian one that led to no degree, and was limited to
    no definite period of study. But it would permit " seekers of knowledge" to
    pursue anv subject at their convenience. Monday and Thursday morning
    lectures were another aspect of the curriculum around this time, and they
    concentrate on subjects which students did not specmc-

Heading: X
Content: study for recitation to their professors, (The Thursday morning lectures
    followed chapel services which, in 1874. commenced at 7:15 a.m. every
    working day.) , With the " dawn of a new century," there came a dramatic
    shift in the educational curriculum. Bucknell then offered sixty regular cu
    rses (with seventy-mne elec tives) taught by eighteen professors At this
    time, courses in law were added, a Department of Medicine lasted for a short
    Urne and the program in professional education was expanded. The first four
    year program in engine ering was established for Civil Engineers hv SS1902
    to be followed by Bachelor of Science programs for Electriical Engine; ertag
    ' 1905deg and Chemical and Mechanical Engineering <1909). The two-semester
    system, and the aband onment of Latin and Greek as requirements for an Arts
    degree, arrived in 1919.

Heading: NEW PROPOSALS
Content: Under President Emory W. Hunt in 1925, the faculty included fifty-nine teachers
    h! college had thirty distinct departments o f  studyf and three hundred
    sixty-four courses were listed -  and described -  m ^ U n iv e rs ity
    catalog Also, today 8 quality rredit svstem had its beginning in 1925.
    Several proposals worthy of mention the SaT  raonfkthe C oS -ex cep t
    Engile- orgamzation of the* Colleg P Division - f X i t t e d L t r  The
    Lower Division

Content: was to be composed of " prescribed work" including survey courses, along with a
    reading knowledge of a foreign language. As the proposal indicated, one
    would have to pass a comprehensive examination in order to gain entrance
    into the Upper <or " more specialized" ) Division. Also in 1932, the twenty-
    seven depart ments were divided into five groups: Language, Social Sciences,
    Natural Sci ences, Philosophy and Arts, and Engine ering.

Heading: EDUCATION PIONEERS
Content: At the end of such a productive year, President Homer P. Rainey remarked that "
    Bucknell is pioneering in educational de velopments. Change effected by the
    fore going steps are among the most compre hensive since the founding of the
    University. The educational world will watch with keen interest the
    unfolding of the future work of students at Bucknell." And, ironically, a
    Junior College was established in Wilkes-Barre by 1933 as an " integral
    part" of Bucknell, only to fold because it became what was then termed a "
    financial burden." The University Course, a forerunner oi the one that
    exists now, intended to clarify the inter-relations of areas and aspects ot
    divergent studies; it began in 1917 under the direction of Dr. W. Preston
    Warren, professor of philosophy. In 1953, Dean William H. Coleman ex plained
    that " it is essential periodically that an institution of higher learning
    take stock of its academiic resources, not simply for the sake of change,
    but to insure that it is functioning at maximum efficiency." As a result of
    this remark, the following objectives were approved for the University in
    1956: "Bucknell is committed in the Christian tradition to provide the means
    and opportunity for the intellectual de velopment of students of quality
    preparation and character to the end that they may become mature and
    responsible members of society. " Bucknell endeavors to impart to the
    student the principles of inherited know ledge and culture, and to bring the
    stu dent to an awareness of his own talents. As a center of independent
    thought, Buck nell is dedicated to the cause of free and responsible inquiry
    and to the seeking of truth wherever it may be found. By 1959, Business
    Administration had been improved upon and enlarged, an Honors Program had
    been established and the curriculum leading to a B.A. degree had been
    revised. Over the last ten years, several features have been added,
    including the Graduate Program, Off-Campus Study, Junior Year Abroad. Summer
    Institutes and a liberal ization of curricular, in general. Even though the
    curriculum has changed and developed immensely, a review of the rs te r  of
    1944 Bucknell faculty gives one a sense of familiarity with times past; for
    one recognizes, among others, the names

Heading: the present
