Heading: The following interview seeks to understand contemporary
Content: 

Heading: Bucknell from the viewpoints of four campus representatives:
Content: 

Heading: two students and two Administrators.
Content: 

Heading: ,
Content: 

Heading: Michael Holoszvc is a sophomore, enrolled in the Bachelor
Content: 

Heading: of Arts and Bachetor of Science in Civil Engineering program;
Content: 

Heading: Lois Ranck graduates this year with a Bachelor of Science de
Content: 

Heading: gree in Secondary Education. Leon Pacala is Dean of the College
Content: 

Heading: of Arts and Sciences and Professor of Religion; John F. Zeller
Content: 

Heading: HI, Vice President of Administration and Finance, completes the
Content: 

Heading: foursome.
Content: 

Heading: While their opinions cannot conclusively define Bucknell
Content: 

Heading: or anv aspect of it -- the four do present, to a fair extent, an
Content: 

Heading: overview of this school as an institution today. The interview
Content: 

Heading: opens with a discussion of a recently-controversial subject: the
Content: 

Heading: relative value of distributional requirements in the AB program.
Content: By DAVID HAMMER BUCKNELLIAN: Distributional require ments are "designed to
    offer, on the one hand, opportunities in general education and, on the
    other, opportunities for inten sive and specialized study" ("Bucknell
    University Bulletin." 1971-73, p. 88), but many students feel handicapped by
    them in, say, the AB program. In view of the debate on the subject, can
    distributional requirements be justified in your minds? HOLOSZYC: I look at
    the present dis tributional program as a lot better than it was two years
    ago. One thing that does deserve mention, though, is the physical education
    requirement. I strongly feel that this present requirement isn't necessary
    in that phys. ed. is almost exclusively Holoszye: 'A lot better' (photo by
    Steve Billig) centered on merely recreational activities -- and that is the
    kind of activity that a student can develop himself. RANCK: Despite my
    enjoyment of phys. ed., I agree that one does take it all through high
    school and, by the time the student comes to college, he should be able to
    decide whether or not he wants to de velop himself in this particular area.
    PACALA: Apart from the phys. ed. re quirement, and to get back to your
    original question, I'm more aware now of an in terest on the part of at
    least a group of students in emphasizing the general educa tion dimension of
    their undergraduate pro gram. From a faculty standpoint, too, there s been
    an increasing interest on the part of 'younger) faculty to move out of the
    singularly-departmentally defined curricu lum into more inter-departmental
    curricu lum. As evidence of this, the faculty of the College of Arts and
    Sciences approved last fall, for the first time in recent history, an inter-
    departmental major. BUCKNELLIAN: Granting that the changes in both
    distributional requirements (indirectly) and curriculum are affected by the
    school budget, how did last year's deficit curtail or restrict poposed or up
    coming programs? ZELLER: I don't know that you can say the deficit has
    affected the curriculum at this point in time any more than financial
    pressures have always affected the cur riculum: I don't know of anything
    that has been cut out this year <or that we're cutt ing out next year)
    because of the financial pinch. PACALA: There have been one or two
    appointments which have not been made (which will be reflected in a
    lessening of a number of courses offered in some de partments). BUCKNELLIAN:
    Along these lines, there has been some talk among the faculty that the
    construction of the soon-to-be-completed University Center took unnecessary
    bites out of salaries; they say that the money pouring into that building
    could have been more wisely distributed. Can these claims be reconciled with
    the structure? ZELLER: The decision to build that fa cility was not a "snap"
    one. The Uni versity Center goes back at least fifteen years. In fact, it
    was one of the recom mendations made by a faculty Committee ten years ago.
    While we are campaining for funds now -- and will continue to do so,
    borrowing money to pay the bills as the building goes up -- I have every
    reason to believe that, within the next five years, we'U raise the money to
    pay off that build ing. Consequently, the money which is in the current
    budget to pay interest on that debt will go back into faculty salaries and |
    the normal educational expenses.

Heading: Zeller: Raising Money
Content: (photo by Bob Arnold) i The new cafeteria service, bookstore and snack bar
    facilities, among other things, do not make the building a new dimension on
    campus but, rather, an im provement upon the present, "falling apart"
    facilities). In addition, we need to have this central place for
    "extracurricular life" which we need to recognize as some thing which may be
    equally as important in the education of the undergraduate as what goes on
    in the classroom, library and laboratory. We must have a place where
    students can interact: we hope the Center will be that place. RANCK: It's
    refreshing to realize that Administration is concerned with more than just
    the feelings of the faculty -- that the Administration is concerned with a
    sense of unity in the students. Of course, that the University Center will
    provide this remains to be seen. But the point of social >> interaction is
    well-taken. HOLOSZYC: I have to disagree with all three of you as to the
    need of the Student Center at this point. Despite its advantages, we're
    putting all the priorities of Bucknell into that building right now. As Dr.
    Zeller points out, too, there's really nothing new in the structure.
    BUCKNELLIAN: The University Center is, obviously, a physical change on this
    campus -- but there have been less tan- j ] gible alterations such as the
    institution of freshman seminars last semester. How is that program working?
    PACALA: A preliminary report by the Freshman Seminar Committee concludes
    that the faculty has <<with little exception) expressed tremendous
    frustration in teach ing it because the courses cut across dis ciplines and
    are not of the standard, intro ductory nature. And yet, without exception,
    they have enthusiastically endorsed it be cause of its significance.
    Evaluation by students involved was also overwhelmingly favorable. HOLOSZYC:
    Freshman seminars are a fantastic idea in that they set up a new mode of
    learning -- sometring apart from traditional classes and traditional depart
    mental guidelines, where the student is able to inquire in his own
    direction. BUCKNELLIAN: Although freshman seminars were not in existence
    when you applied to Bucknell, there were aspects of the University which
    must have initially impressed you. What were some of these first
    impressions? HOLOSZYC: My first !impression was that it was a very
    conservative school, and an isolated one; its strengths were in the
    Sciences. But those initial impressions have changed quite a bit in my view.
    RANCK: Initial impressions -- I'd have to think back to when I was nine or
    ten years old since I've lived here for so long, and come from a Bucknell
    family. But, having taken Bucknell for granted,

Heading: I
Content: couldn't find any other college that was so beautiful and academically strong
    after looking at other colleges -- I really appreciated this school after
    comparison. BUCKNELLIAN: What are your general impressions toward students
    here? Can they all be cast in one mold as seems the trend toward almost
    everything nowadays? ZELLER: We do primarily have students from a suburban
    background as opposed to center-city areas. PACALA: We don't find a lot of
    the "wide-eyed-innocent" types here. Persons who attend Bucknell are (armed)
    with a sophisticated, not uncynical view of institu tions and social
    relations. It's not an easy kind of student body to teach from one respect,
    at least, in that they're not ready to take as "Gospel" every utterance even
    by a silver-tongued Dean. It's a kind of "OK-turn it off-show me that it's
    worth considering" tough-minded- ness that, in some instances, can be re
    silient and in others, can sort of turn off the academic process unless you
    gear into it in any ways that might be compell ing for that particular
    individual. ZELLER: There's always been a kind of practicality about the
    Bucknell student body. It's been a "show me" kind of thing. PACALA: Let me
    amplify that a bit, at least from my perspective. That practi cality has
    different dimensions. It can range from refusal to simply live at ab stract
    levels of analysis, in terms of the academic process -- and that's good --
    to (and this is less productive in an academic atmosphere) a commercial, or
    market, concept of education -- and that's tough to contend with. ZELLER:
    Students here have been moti vated to pick a place like Bucknell be cause
    they see it as the model of what college life ought to be. Now "what college
    life ought to be" has changed over the years. The "country-club-on-the-
    Susquehan- na," big party, big fraternity school that we may have been right
    after the war is not what Bucknell is today. Today, there's a different
    model of what college life ought to be, but our students see Bucknell as
    offering whatever that model is. HOLOSZYC: Going back to a few of the
    statements that were made, I do tend to feel that Bucknell is diverse in
    certain dimensions more so than I originally thought. But stereotypes have
    been made of every single group on campus, un- Ranck: Stereotypes (photo by
    Eric Riess) fortunately, and there is an obvious lack of certain groups here
    -- Blacks, for in stance, along with other minorities. RANCK: There
    definitely are stereotypes, even if it's only along fraternity or sorority
    lines. BUCKNELLIAN: Speaking of diversifi cation of students at Bucknell,
    and its geographical location which some feel to be vastly significant, do
    you consider the University isolated in its approach to the "outside world?"
    Is Bucknell a "Story book Land" in miniature? PACALA: There is a way of life
    here which is somewhat unrealistic, which can't be shared or duplicated or
    contained else where. HOLOSZYC: The sad thing about Buck nell is that you
    can sit back in your academic atmosphere -- both faculty and students -- and
    completely forget about the outside world. It shouldn't be like that; if you
    want to know what's going on outside, you have to look for it entirely on
    your own. For example, a lot of people here don't have any conception of
    what urban ghetto life is, or could be, like. ZELLER: I'd have to agree that
    we suffer from a lack of proximity to some of the major urban areas, with
    both their problems and assets. But we have to note

Heading: that
Content: poverty doesn't exist only in the city

Heading: and that, if a student is interested
Content: in

Heading: Pacala: No 'wide-eyed'
Content: types (photo by Bob Arnold) finding out about how the other halt lives, we've
    got plenty of rural poverty surround ing us. RANCK: Bucknell provides the
    January Program which frees the student to con nect himself with ghetto,
    minority and drug problems. If you're interested enough, there are faculty
    members who will surely sponsor almost any investigation on the student's
    part. I realize that a month is not a lifetime but, at least, it's an intro
    duction. PACALA: In the final analysis, the issue of isolation has got to be
    judged according to the readiness of students at the end of their college
    experience to assume re sponsible roles, whatever they may be. BUCKNELLIAN:
    Perhaps students don't engage in excessive political or social in quiry, but
    their problems may be lessened because of the degree of communication on the
    campus. Have you found the Ad ministration to be an open one? RANCK: They
    have been to me. I've come in contact with Admissions and Resi dence Hall
    housing personnel. Almost any Administrator is more than willing to com
    municate with you -- perhaps that's unique at Bucknell. HOLOSZYC: That's one
    of the great assets of this University. The faculty is a teaching faculty --
    they're not tied up with their research. Personally, I've never had any
    trouble contacting a faculty member. I think I can say the same thing for
    the remainder of the Administration, too. BUCKNELLIAN: Are student organiza
    tions receptive to new members Do you find an openness on their part as
    well? HOLOSZYC: I do. The size of this in stitution is the most important
    factor in that respect. Actually, no student organiza tion can afford to be
    closed because the campus is so small. In fact, student organi zations seem
    always to be trying to recruit students, which is to their credit. RANCK:
    Most people who want to get involved in an organization -- who show interest
    -- don't have any trouble. BUCKNELLIAN: That touches on the question of
    apathy on this campus. There is a general trend of thought here that
    Bucknell students are apathetic toward al most everything. Is such a
    conception more myth than reality? ZELLER: There's some of both (myth and
    reality) involved here. Sure, there arc a lot of students who show very
    little in terest in public or campus issues. But I find it difficult to
    label those students as entirely apathetic; some are otherwise deeply
    involved in what they're doing aca demically. When you think of student
    apathy, you picture students who spend all their time drinking beer or
    playing bridge -- and there aren't too many students like that at Bucknell
    anymore. HOLOSZYC: Apathy is very real at Bucknell. Students are very
    academically- oriented here; they really do get involved with their studying
    -- most take it very seriously. As a result, between that and the revolving
    social life, students are pres sured into not taking initiative in other
    fields. , . RANCK: I wouldn't state the apathetic problem quite so strongly.
    Last year, dur ing the strike, I was overwhelmed by the amount of
    participation. Granted, we didn't have 2600 students up on the quad for each
    meeting which was called, but there seemed to be more participating than one
    would have ordinarily expected. The pressure of academics is real enough,
    thought: students are very time-conscious because of the series of paper and
    test deadlines presented by the college environ ment. PACALA: I hear a
    definition of apathy in the context of faculty discussion, and they're
    usually referring to a style of life which is devoid of the spontaneity, en
    thusiasm and pursuit of intellectual issues that, often times, faculty would
    like to see a good deal more of. BUCKNELL1AN: One way of lessening apathy of
    all kinds here is to develop what has been termed a "sense of community."
    The newly-instituted coed housing proposals were predicted as one means of
    achieving this goal. Is coed housing such a viable means? RANCH: In my mind,
    the changes are excellent. Perhaps Swartz Hall lends itself many diverse
    departments as possible -- Bucknell does a pretty good job for its size.
    Students should be encouraged to explore areas they never knew about -- to
    develop a sense of community and identification. Finally, a University
    should be a place where interrelations between people can be broadly
    developed, so that an under standing of others' motives and minds can all be
    placed in a proper system. A lot, in effect, is left up to the individual
    stu dent, and rightly so. RANCH: There should exist a sense of openness,
    growth, individual improvement and identity so that, through interaction and
    education in University life, one may, consequently, get to know himself.
    Buck- nell's trying -- and that's a start. ZELLER: I would like Bucknell, as
    an undergraduate college, to be the kind of Bucknell's Student Strike:
    Springtime of our lives a little bit more to coed dorms than other
    dormitories on account of the complex created by the central lounge and
    cafeteria in the building. HOLOSZYC: There is a lot of interaction in New
    Dorm -- all lounges are shared as they are in Swartz. It's an amazing im
    provement over last year. We really don't have the "sense of community" that
    we could have, though. Perhaps more contact leading to a "one ness" will
    result in the future with addi tional changes such as the extension of
    visitation hours. BUCKNELLIAN: In all these questions and comments, perhaps
    one pervading focus has been to reflect on what this Uni versity is -- and
    what it should be. In deed, how does Bucknell measure up to the conceptual
    ideal of college in your minds? HOLOSZYC: The concept of a University is
    going to be a different one for different people. There are certain people
    attending this school for purely vocational training; there are certain
    people here who desire a general, philosophical background of what education
    means -- those are probably the two extremes, and there's a whole strata of
    people in-between. A University could be all of these things, with the
    emphasis on at least exposing all aspects to the student. Certainly, a
    University should have as place that asks a lot of questions of its students
    -- questions that the students can never answer And I don't want to miss any
    of them. A student ought to be chal lenged intellectually, emotionally,
    religious ly. I want a student to go out of here dedi cated to using his
    life in a way that will advance mankind in some appropriate way; I don't
    want him to go out of here with a purely selfish motive. I don't want a
    student to leave saying "Well, that's finished;" I want him to leave saying,
    rather, "Boy, I've barely begun." From

    is this which I want him to do. PACALA: A good college is reflected by its

    which an undergraduate college lives is that of self-understanding.

Heading: LEWISBURG, PENNA.
Content: 

Heading: the prospects
Content: 

Heading: Compiled by ERIC RIESS
Content: 

Heading: What are the prospects for Bucknell? This supplement asked
Content: 

Heading: noted faculty members and administrators to convey their
Content: 

Heading: thoughts on the future of higher education, in general, and Buck
Content: 

Heading: nell, in particular. From their comments, six were selected,
Content: 

Heading: edited and hereby presented not necessarily as a representative
Content: 

Heading: sample but. instead, as a series of provocative and relatively in
Content: 

Heading: dicative thoughts.
Content: THOMAS J. R1SCH Dean of Men The present model of higher education is based upon
    one of training for a vocation. People were to become informed in college
    and trained to do something which would enable them to become successful in
    life, with success being measured as contri bution to the production of
    goods and ad ding to the affluence of society. This orientation is changing.
    In addition, it is coupled with the phenomenal growth in information
    available and the necessity to be able to continue to learn and to adapt,
    rather than to have been once trained and then do that for the rest of your
    life.

Heading: 'TO LEARN TO DO'
Content: Thus the old definition of education, be ing one of training "to do'' has to be
    replac ed with the definition of education, be- "training to learn to do."
    What I am say ing is that a person has to be capable of constant learning,
    constant adaptation and constant adjustment to the new demands Thus
    education has to be a continuous process and not one that ends when the
    college career is over. Thus, what happens when the usual college career is
    experi enced must be different, and the opportuni ties to continue to learn
    after the so-called college career is over need to be expanded. In addition,
    the various numbers of peopte presently--and in the future--participating in
    higher education will necessitate dif ferent kinds of organization. All
    kinds oi opportunities beyond high school must be made available in all
    kinds of ways. The concept of four years of college in one spot after four
    years of high school will not meet the needs outlined above.

Heading: POWER STRUCTURE
Content: In addition, the methods of offering high er education will need serious
    scrutiny. Tho efficiency of the present operation is atroc ious. and our
    ability to avoid establishing methods of evaluation have been fantastic. We
    must become more efficient and must integrate into the educational system
    the methodology that technology has available |l for the communication of
    information -- for instant feedback, for developing flex ible and competent
    personnel. But the organization and power structure of higher education is
    well entrenched and fearfully inflexible. Serious times of strife will be
    experienced before the holders of power, primarily the faculties and
    academic professions, give up their power and al low basic change to be
    experienced. For Bucknell in particular, we will have to narrow our purpose
    and goals. The diversity in the type of institution that is possible in
    higher education in the future is fantastic, and we will have to be a
    special kind in that diversity. No one place of our size and our potential
    re sources can claim to be all things for all men, or even very many things
    for very many men.

Heading: 'SPECIFIC PURPOSE'
Content: Right now a specific purpose will have to be formulated. By necessity it will
    have to be a flexible purpose and definition so that it can keep pace with
    the changing times. A couple of years out of step could be disastrous. In
    addition, we will have to do what ever we decide our purpose to be very well
    in order to justify why a person should spend the kind of money it will take
    to support Bucknell to gain the kind of education that we propose. We cannot
    com pete with a large state supported institu tion, and we cannot compete
    with the com munity college concept. We will have to develop ways in which
    we can utilize the uniqueness of our environment and setting and physical
    features to provide a type ot education that it would be difficult to find
    any place else. In order for that type of education to be satisfying to
    those who come, we will have to do an excellent job in conveying to the
    public exactly what we propose to do, so that those people who want that
    will know exactly where to come. All of this will have to operate in a
    community atmos phere setting. Our present tricotomy of faculty, ad
    ministration and students, and our special interest groups and adversary
    roles, make it impossible for us to be efficient enough to adapt as quickly
    and as effectively as we will need to. This calls for a change in the people
    involved, and I am at a loss to suggest how that might take place.

Heading: DOUGLAS CANDLAND
Content: Chairman, Dept of Psychology Consideration of the future of higher edu cation
    leads me to initially consider the history of American higher education. In
    the first place, the history of Ameri can higher education is unique, for it
    is the only system developed specifically for mass education. Second, until
    recently what has been called higher education in America has been higher
    technological education. Only within the last decades has the con cept that
    education is good because of its own inherent virtues become commonplace.

Heading: STUDENT UNREST
Content: Present student unrest is largely attri buted to the fact that American Society
    judges education in terms of what it pro vides for the society rather than
    what it produces in the way of contentment and reflection for the
    individual. Students clear ly want a different kind of education from what
    we offer. In short, considering the demand, there is too much liberal educa
    tion. The experiment of providing sound liberal arts education for all has
    failed, much to my unhappiness, primarily be cause most students do not want
    it. It is, in their words, "irrelevant." Historically, the idea that liberal
    arts education is good in itself is an aberration of a decade or two.
    American society re mains basically anti-intellectual, in the sense that it
    approves of education only so long as such education is technically pro
    ductive. Perhaps faculty have failed to deliver the message that wisdom
    leads to the reflective and creative life; perhaps faculty were wrong in
    assuming that a technological society would accept the pre- In any case, the
    idea that the liberal arts education is the best for all individuals has,
    like prohibition, failed as a Noble Experi ment.

Heading: IMMEDIATE FUTURE
Content: What is the immediate future of Ameri can education? If my assumptions are cor
    rect, I predict that America will continue to offer basically technological
    education under one guise or another. Few institutions can afford to
    continue to offer education

Heading: A 'Model' University: Bucknell

    it will survive and even be the model of the university of the future. We
    may be saved by the fact that we could not afford to make the mistakes of
    many Ivy Schools. To be optimistic, we may be able to provide that peculiar
    Ameri can combination of education in liberal arts and technology which will
    be highly prized in the future.

Heading: WENDELL I. SMITH
Content: Provost What are Bucknell's prospects? There is absolutely no doubt that
    education at Buck nell will change more profoundly in the next decade than
    it has in the two and one-half decades since the end of World War II. During
    the next decade, under the ueadership of all of its component groups (with
    the administration serving in the role of catalyst and facilitator), it is
    like ly that many of the following will occur:

Heading: General and specific goals will be estab
Content: 

Heading: lished (including the goals of all academic
Content: 

Heading: and administrative departments); the goals
Content: 

Heading: will be reviewed annually; and all pro
Content: 

Heading: grams, both administrative and academic,

Heading: will have to be demonstrated to be clearly
Content: 

Heading: related to goals. Further, the cost and the
Content: 

Heading: effectiveness of all programs will be de

Content:

Content: 

Heading: professionals.

Heading: CThe Bank with
Content: 

Heading: Revolving Clock)
Content: or selfstudy, etc. These will not be the majority pattern, however. The
    influence of the department and the department major on the undergraduate
    level will be less pronounced, but it will not disappear, and most students
    will con tinue to major in one department. Higher education will continue to
    be basically vocational in its objective. This is not to say that
    undergraduate education will be any more professional than it is now, or
    that students will concentrate on what we normally think of as "vocational"
    subjects. Nonetheless, students will still come to college primarily to
    prepare them selves for some kind of useful career. Most students will still
    think of their college education as preparing them for positions of greater
    economic reward than they might achieve without a college education. More
    students than at the present time, however, will see the economic benefit as
    secondary to the importance of preparing for the kind of service which will
    benefit so ciety. In other words, they will look for ward more to the
    contribution they can make to the earnings they will achieve.

Heading: 'NOT ENOUGH MONEY'
Content: Tuitions will continue to rise, though less dramatically than they have in the
    past five years. The rate of increase of professional salaries will level
    off as society discovers that the new math has not cancelled the o'd
    mathematics of compound interest -- i.e.. an 8'i increase in salaries will
    result in a doubling of salaries in only nine years. This cannot be
    sustained indefinitely. The democratization of our institutions, including
    colleges, will continue with stu dents, faculty, alumni and trustees all
    playing roles in the governance of col leges and universities. Each will
    eventually learn that none has exclusive jurisdiction in any area, and that
    all have interests that must be recognized and given voice. Administrators
    will be seen as coordinators

Heading: The student-faculty ratio will be increased to 15 or 16, but this will not be
Content: 

Heading: viewed as a reduction in quality when it is viewed in a context in which stu

Heading: dent/faculty relationships change markedly.

Heading: 1971
Content: --

Heading: t s s a a a a a s a B B i s
Content: 

Heading: Any forecast of Bucknell's future will _ re
Content: 

Heading: veal the present distance between our aspirations
Content: 

Heading: and our capacities, but it should also show how
Content: 

Heading: far we have come. Fifteen years ago our endow
Content: 

Heading: ment at market value was $4,726,288, average
Content: 

Heading: faculty compensation was approximately $4,500,
Content: 

Heading: and we had available for student financial aid
Content: President Charles H. Watts, II

Heading: $158,034. Our plant was valued at $7,659,835.
Content: 

Heading: Today the endowment is $22,300,870, average fac
Content: 

Heading: ulty compensation is $12,542, financial aid is at
Content: 

Heading: $1,338,669, and the plant is valued at $22,417,379.
Content: 

Heading: These are crude and external measures of a
Content: 

Heading: very considerable increase in what might be called
Content: 

Heading: our scholarly worth -- the combined intellectual
Content: 

Heading: and creative efforts of faculty and students. These
Content: 

Heading: efforts cannot be grasped, but they can be felt,
Content: 

Heading: and as they go so goes the real usefulness of the
Content: 

Heading: University. Our prime and not new obligation for
Content: 

Heading: tomorrow must continue to be their enhancement.
Content: 

Heading: It has always been hard to further scholarship
Content: 

Heading: and learning, not least because the effects of both
Content: 

Heading: take so long to be proved worthwhile. It will be
Content: 

Heading: especially hard to do so in the immediate future,
Content: 

Heading: thanks to the fundamental changes our culture is
Content: 

Heading: undergoing.
Content: 

Heading: Societal progress depends now upon the de
Content: 

Heading: velopment and right application of knowledge,
Content: 

Heading: new and old and -- as always -- upon wide ac
Content: 

Heading: ceptance of value systems which are humane. It
Content: 

Heading: now appears that both of these requisites are more
Content: 

Heading: nearly products of colleges and universities than
Content: 

Heading: they have been before, which means that what
Content: 

Heading: Bucknell does tomorrow will heve greater national
Content: 

Heading: consequence.
Content: 

Heading: No one yet knows quite what this increased
Content: 

Heading: relevance for institutions lige Bucknell will mean.
Content: 

Heading: As social demands upon us grow, we>> could lose all
Content: 

Heading: sense of direction by trying to be all things to all
Content: 

Heading: men. As our problems of finance become more
Content: 

Heading: severe, we could find ourselves only a minor unit
Content: 

Heading: in a publicly funded national system of higher
Content: 

Heading: education, our autonomy sharply reduced. As
Content: 

Heading: knowledge increases and curricular porliferate, we
Content: 

Heading: could become a confused educational supermarket.
Content: 

Heading: And unless we learn more rapidly about the nature
Content: 

Heading: of learning, we could betray our graduates, for
Content: 

Heading: they will be among the first generations who must
Content: 

Heading: for survival continue to learn.
Content: 

Heading: Even this brief litany is harsh, but it does
Content: 

Heading: point to some extraodinary opportunities. If what
Content: 

Heading: we do really is useful, we will find the needed sup
Content: 

Heading: port. If we can sharpen our sense of institutional
Content: 

Heading: purpose we will be able to make curricular sense of
Content: 

Heading: the flood of new knowledge. If we are bold enough
Content: 

Heading: in our pedagogy, we can leave with our students a
Content: 

Heading: taste for learning which will sustain them for a
Content: 

Heading: long time.
Content: 

Heading: We are coming upon a time of change in
Content: 

Heading: educational purpose and method which will reveal
Content: 

Heading: the great growth of the country's colleges and
Content: 

Heading: universities in the past fifteen years for what it
Content: 

Heading: is, an extraordinary but incomplete and imperfect
Content: 

Heading: beginning. We've been operating at forced draft
Content: 

Heading: for quite a time now, and the reaction -- fatigue,
Content: 

Heading: anger over both excesses and inadequacies, frus
Content: 

Heading: tration in the face of constant change -- has set
Content: 

Heading: in. Some of us would like to stop the whole affair
Content: 

Heading: and get off. Others want to throw out all we have
Content: 

Heading: imperfectly built. Neither alternative is possible
Content: 

Heading: nor makes sense. We will have to work harder now
Content: 

Heading: for change, and we will have to make more certain
Content: 

Heading: that each change is valid. Yesterday was easy.
Content: 

Heading: I can see a couple of things as nearly certain
Content: 

Heading: for us in the future.
Content: 

Heading: We will reconcile, or at least keep in proper
Content: 

Heading: tension, tht two presently competing movements
Content: 

Heading: in higher education, the one oriented narrowly to
Content: 

Heading: the production and dissemination of knowledge,
Content: 

Heading: the other oriented to the development and sensi
Content: 

Heading: tizing of each student as a whole and separate
Content: 

Heading: person. If they prove irreconcilable, we are done.
Content: 

Heading: What all of us want is a life of worthwhile labor;
Content: 

Heading: what frustrates us about our society is that it
Content: 

Heading: seemed to offer so few opportunities for it. The
Content: 

Heading: only way to live such a life in our day is to know
Content: 

Heading: enough -- mere unaided virtue is insufficient.
Content: 

Heading: We will at long last make human sense of
Content: 

Heading: our campuses. We don't now; really know what to
Content: 

Heading: do with them, which is in part why we anguish
Content: 

Heading: so in our search for a true academic community.
Content: 

Heading: Ideally all that we do -- in class and out -- should
Content: 

Heading: reinforce our central intellectual purposes. Clearly
Content: 

Heading: it doesn't now, so we debate about dormitory hours
Content: 

Heading: on the one hand and the inflexibility of classroom
Content: 

Heading: methods on the other. To use a presently un
Content: 

Heading: popular word, universities are artificial constructs,
Content: 

Heading: as they should be, designed to do a limited number
Content: 

Heading: of things. They are not microcosms of anything.
Content: 

Heading: We will learn how to run them better, keeping
Content: 

Heading: responsibility and capacity together and sharing
Content: 

Heading: more than we do now in their governance.
Content:

Heading: Women's Honorary Picks
Content: 

Heading: Stevenson as Secretary
Content: 

Heading: Pessimism Prevailed
Content: Miss Mary Jane Stevenson, dean of women, has been named to the newly-created
    position of executive secretary of Alpha Lambda Delta, national scholastic
    honor society for freshman women. She will assume her new post on July 1,
    but will continue to serve the University on a part-time basis as assistant
    to the dean of student affairs, according to an announce ment by President
    Charles

Heading: H.
Content: Watts. " We congratulate Miss Stevenson upon being selected for this im portant
    position for which she is so eminently qualified by virtue of her
    professional achievements and special talents," said President Watts. " We
    are especially pleased that her new assignment will permit her to continue
    her valuable service to Bucknell's students." As executive secretary of
    Alpha Lambda Delta, Miss Stevenson will maintain at her home an office which
    will serve as national head-

Heading: Publication Date
Content: The final issue of THE BUCK- NELLIAN for this semester will be published next
    Thursday. quarters for the society's 165 chap ters across the country. As
    assistant to the dean of stu dent affairs, Miss Setvenson will continue to
    represent the needs and concerns of women to the Uni versity community and
    will also continue her service as adviser to the Associated Women Students
    and to the Panhellenic Council, Dunlop said. She currently serves as chair
    man for Spring Weekend and will continue that work also. Miss Stevenson has
    served as dean of women here since 1947. A graduate of Westminister College,
    she received her master's degree in student personnel work from Ohio
    University. She served as as sistant dean of women at the Pen nsylvania
    State University and dean of women at Albright College and at Westminister,
    prior to joining the administration here.

Heading: Mars Memorial Service
Content: By NICKI DREW " It is the men of peace who are dying to share it with the
    world." These words, spoken by Chaplain James Gardner, boomed across the
    quadrangle Wedenesday afternoon to a scattering of several hundred students
    gathered together to com memorate the deaths of the stu dents at Kent and
    Jackson State last May. After a brief message from Rev erend Gardner and
    Father Bernard Petrina, the spiritual portion of the Memorial Service was
    concluded with the Lord's Prayer, and a series of speakers, representing
    faculty, administration, and students, step ped forward to express their
    thoughts and feelings in regard to

Heading: Question Responsibility
Content: 

Heading: Profs Analyze Department Chairman Roles
Content: By STEVE KNIGHT What authority and responsi bilities should a department chair
    man have? Several University de partment chairmen discussed their views on
    the subject in an inter view with the Bucknellian. Dr. Douglas Sturm,
    chairman of the religion department, presented the idea of modifying the
    role of the department chairman last week at the meeting of the American
    Association of University Profes sors. Dr. Sturm emphasized the im portance
    of the department chair man as the only formal channel be tween University
    administration and faculty. He also pointed out the import ance of a
    chairman's decisions on such matters as salary level and tenure for an
    individual faculty member.

Heading: Contention Shrouds
Content: 

Heading: 'Cancelled' Meeting
Content: By JANET RUSSO In keeping with the philosophy of " no business as usual"  on May
    5, Bob Nachshin, ABS President, de cided against holding a regular Wednesday
    night meeting. He over ruled the steering committee's vote of 3 to 1 (Russ
    Pais absent) to con duct a meeting. Chuck Resnick, ABS treasurer, was going
    to run the meeting as of Tuesday night. However, upon ex amining Article I
    of the Constitu tion early Wednesday morning, it was realized that only the
    president has been given the power " to call and preside over meetings,"  or
    the vice president in his absence. At noon Wednesday the secretaries were
    instructed to notify all mem bers that there would be no meet ing that
    evening. These proceedings were unknown to the nine representatives who did
    arrive for the meeting, and who questioned the legality of such pro
    ceedings. They felt there was suf ficient reason to conduct a meeting and
    discuss the agenda as it was outlined. They, therefore conducted the
    meeting. Resnick's motion concerning the re-allocation of the student fee of
    $30 was accepted and will be pre sented as a referendum next Thurs day. A
    revised proposal on the im plementation of the visitation policy from the
    student affairs commit tee's recommendations, was then presented by Neil
    Hendershot, LUR member, and was passed. The final action was the appointment
    of one sophomore student to the traffic committee. Upon consulting Nachshin
    later, he declared that the jneeting and any decisions made were unconsti
    tutional due to the fact that neither he nor Pais had called the meeting nor
    were present. Added to the legal problem is the fact that a quorum of the
    Congress was not present. An inconsistency is brought forth in this
    statement however, because last week's meet ing was considered official,
    despite the fact that a quorum did not exist. It is believed that proposals
    and amendments will be made at next week's meeting, in order to clarify
    existing policy. In place of the current setup, Dr. Sturm believes there
    should be a method by which faculty members can review a chairman's
    decisions. He also feels that some organiza tion should be responsible for
    evalu ating the individual chairman. As a possible solution to the " pri
    vileged"  position which department chairmen now enjoy, Dr. Sturm would be
    in favor of a faculty re viewing committee to judge the performance of each
    chairman. In contrast, Dr. David Ray, chair man of the mathematics depart
    ment, emphasizes that all of a chairman's decisions are under con stant
    review by both fellow faculty members and the University ad ministration.
    Dr. Ray cited the fact that in most departments, chairmen are elected by the
    other members of their department, and can, there fore, be removed by a
    concensus vote. He also emphasized the general procedure in which a
    chairman's decisions are subject to the ap proval of the dean of the
    respective college and the provost as a limit ing factor upon the chairman's
    au tonomy. Dr. Ray stated that he would not be in favor of a faculty
    reviewing committee to replace the current setup. Dr. Harry Garvin, chairman
    of the English department, is also aware of the many limitations upon a
    chairman's autonomy. Dr. Garvin notes that within his own department,
    committees have been formed to handle some of the administrative matters
    which were formerly reserved exclusively for the chairman. By BILL WHITNEY
    Director of Admissions, Fritz Walling, stated recently that the admissions
    committee " is shooting for a freshman class"  of approxi mately 725
    students next semester. At this time acceptance deposits are still being
    received so that few details or statistics (class ranks or average SAT
    scores) are yet avail able. Walling stated that he is hoping for more than
    725 acceptances be cause he expects what he terms "considerable summer
    erosion." He noted that "all private schools had fewer applications"  than
    usual this year (they were down almost 10 per cent here) and consequently
    the University, like other private institutions, " made proportionally more
    offers"  than before. Therefore, Walling expects there will be "
    considerable movement" during the summer months, as the Although he comments
    that, " I am open to the possibility of change,"  he remains cautious about
    the possible implications of a new system and would have to study a new
    proposal carefully before mak ing a decision. Dr. Robert Slonaker, chairman
    of the chemical engineering depart ment, expressed concern about the
    decisions of a faculty reviewing committee perhaps hindering the everyday
    duties of a chairman. Dr. Slonaker observed that, " People tend to forget
    that a de partment chairman is just another faculty member who has been en-
    ( Continued on Page 4) the situation in this country a year after the
    shootings in Ohio and Mississippi. Representing President Watts was Provost
    Wendell Smith who, after expressing disappointment in the poor turn-out at
    the Service, read a statement from the president. Although he referred to
    the ever present evidence of " man's old in capacity to find peace within
    him self,"  Watts expressed the opti mism of the speech he gave last May
    during the strike to an all campus gathering on the quad. There has been a "
    change in the American priorities," he said, and " that change has been
    sharpened and hastened by those who are young." A series of less optimistic
    speech es followed. Dennis Baumwoll, as sistant professor of English, admit
    ted to feeling a " sense of futility about it all."  Looking back at last
    year's protestation, Baumwoll ad mits to believing at one time that the
    tragic shooting of the six stu dents was a turning point in the " madness."
    Although there have been signs of triumph and enthusiasm, " we have ravaged
    Cambodia, devastated Laos, and reduced our troops while we increase the
    bombing"  in Viet nam. " One wonders what has chang- (Continued on Page 4)

Heading: Peeler Represents University
Content: 

Heading: At National AAUP Conference
Content: 

Heading: Director Walling 'Shoots'
Content: 

Heading: For 725 New Freshmen
Content: more prestigious schools accept ap plicants from their waiting lists, and some
    students planning to attend this University will move elsewhere. The
    admissions committee is hop ing for approximately 450 to 475 ac ceptances
    from men and 250 to 275 from women to achieve the goal of 725 in September.
    Walling noted, however, that there " shouldn't be any decrease in quality"
    in the Class of '75. The freshman class is expected to be " similar in
    quality to last year's class"  because it is smaller. With regard to the
    present hous ing problem, he stated that the ad missions committee " defined
    the freshman class"  for next year with curriculum and housing in mind. The
    committee is " sensitive to the housing situation"  but does not ex pect as
    large a problem as pro duced by the present " abnormally large"  Freshman
    class. By BILL DECKER Collective bargaining, status of women, anti-nepotism,
    academic freedom, the situation in South-east Asia, and the economic
    situation in America were topics of discussion at the fifty-seventh annual
    meeting of the American Association of Uni versity Professors. Dr. John A.
    Peeler, assistant pro fessor of political science, attended the meeting as
    delegate from the University. The delegates, meeting in Phila delphia in
    April, passed resolutions including the use of the National Labor Relations
    Board in bargain ing for faculty interests, the right of censure in
    discrimination against women, and the objection to nepo tism when hiring
    faculty. Also included were resolutions providing for the rights of non-ten-
    ured faculty, governmental en croachments on freedom, objection to American
    involvement in Viet nam, and the acknowledgement of the poor state of the
    American economy. Commenting on the AAUP's in fluence, Dr. Peeler said, "
    It's major sanctioning power it the threat of censure for violating academic
    free dom. In most cases this is enough to cause the administration to change
    ways." A main concern about the use of the National Labor Relations Board is
    that though they have jurisdic tion in colleges, their primary work has been
    in industrial relations. Dif ferences between the academic world and labor
    can arise. " The faculty believes they have the right to decide,"  Dr.
    Peeler added in exemplifying a difficulty that might arise between the fac
    ulty and the NLRB. Also condemned were policies con cerning nepotism, hiring
    faculty and staff members on the basis of family relations. The resolution
    stated that nepotism was "wholly unrelated to academic qualifica- tions and
    limit them unfairly in their opportunity to practice their profession." The
    delegates asked for protection of the non-tenured faculty. A sys tematic set
    of standards for evalu ating faculty members drawn up by a faculty committee
    was needed. Immediate withdrawal of troops from South-east Asia was passed
    with a small minority opposing. In viewing the poor economic situation of
    America, delegates observed that compensation for faculty members in the
    country as a whole was about six-percent, less than one-percent over the
    country's inflation role of five-percent.

Heading: iBsnrance Available
Content: 

Heading: To Dorm Residents
Content: An insurance policy covering per sonal property loss for students living in
    residence halls is being of fered for next semester by the National Student
    Services, Inc. Losses of personal property over $25.00 and up to $1500.00
    due to theft, fire, vandalism, and from damage due to water, wind, smoke, or
    explosion are covered in the pro gram. Personal items such as articles of
    clothing, electronic equipment, furniture, musical instruments, and hobby
    equipment are covered by the program; items such as checks, currency,
    tickets for commercial transportation, autos, bikes, contact lenses,
    artificial teeth, and other items are not covered in the pro gram. The
    policy is unique in that it is the only such program offered to three
    million students. Because of the high number of students, cover age can be
    offered for $7.70 each year. " The University is not encourag- (Continued on
    Page 4) mmm . . '

Heading: Body-in-Its-Milieu '
Content: 

Heading: "Physical education is conceived as
Content: 

Heading: the exploration in theory and practice
Content: 

Heading: of the character and import of 'play'
Content: 

Heading: where play is defined as the capacity of
Content: 

Heading: the body or self to react to, to interact
Content: 

Heading: with, to imaginatively vary, to respond
Content: 

Heading: to and be responsible for the structure
Content: 

Heading: of "body-in-its-milieu" of which it is a
Content: 

Heading: part."
Content: 

Heading: At Monday's faculty meeting, John
Content: 

Heading: Kirkland, assistant professor of history,
Content: 

Heading: will present a motion calling for a re-
Content: 

Heading: evaluation of the physical education pro
Content: 

Heading: gram and the implementation of a one-
Content: 

Heading: year requirement. Reaction has ranged
Content: 

Heading: from enthusiastic support to inquiries
Content: 

Heading: as to the motion's comical nature. De
Content: 

Heading: spite a few important problems with its
Content: 

Heading: implementation, it would be unfortunate
Content: 

Heading: if the faculty dealt with the motion as
Content: 

Heading: if it were some sort of a joke.
Content: 

Heading: The real worth of the motion lies
Content: 

Heading: in its outline of " the working rationale
Content: 

Heading: in physical education" which is cited
Content: 

Heading: above. This is also the part that is ridi
Content: 

Heading: culed as phenomenological rhetoric. Read
Content: 

Heading: the motion again if you feel this way.
Content: 

Heading: The study of man, and the actions of
Content: 

Heading: man, as an imaginative, innovative, and
Content: 

Heading: interacting self has long been neglected.
Content:

Content: 

Heading: opportunity for this study of the unit
Content: 

Heading: self. The possibilities are infinite, from
Content: 

Heading: sensitivity sessions to hikes in the
Content: 

Heading: country to creative dance to tennis.

Heading: ception - misperception, competition - co

Heading: operation, conformity-creativity, soli

Heading: tude-socialization may be instructively
Content:

Content:

Heading: uation." Does Mr. Kirkland have that

Heading: much faith in the present phys ed staff

Heading: and its adaptability to the study of
Content: 

Heading: "body-in-its-milieu" ? It appears naive
Content: 

Heading: to ask coaches of intercollegiate sports
Content: 

Heading: who act as part-time gym teachers to
Content: 

Heading: shift gears into the world of " self-in-a
Content: 

Heading: situation." Coaches who spend much of
Content: 

Heading: their time lobbying for additional funds
Content: 

Heading: for "their boys" may have some trouble
Content: 

Heading: with a program which appears to de
Content: 

Heading: mand one's entire time.
Content: 

Heading: The motion itself calls for an evalua
Content: 

Heading: tion of the progress of the program, but
Content: 

Heading: specifies no time for the evaluation and
Content: 

Heading: in what manner it is to be made. This
Content: 

Heading: must be specified.
Content: 

Heading: We cannot agree with the proposed
Content: 

Heading: one year requirement, which appears to
Content: 

Heading: be a contradiction of the definition of
Content: 

Heading: physical education. The motion argues
Content: 

Heading: that the requirement is necessary "in
Content: 

Heading: order to meet the conditions necessary
Content: 

Heading: for an experimental design." It asks for
Content: 

Heading: a guaranteed number of (inevitably)
Content: 

Heading: freshman guinea pigs. No study of the
Content: 

Heading: self can be conducted in an atmosphere
Content: 

Heading: where some of the participants are pre
Content: 

Heading: sent only because of some bureaucratic
Content: 

Heading: edict, and not their own free will. If Mr.
Content: 

Heading: Kirkland has so much confidence in the
Content: 

Heading: worth of the program, he also ought to
Content: 

Heading: have the confidence in finding constitu
Content: 

Heading: ency of students interested in taking the
Content: 

Heading: course. In fact, it is unclear in the motion
Content: 

Heading: if the program is to run for one year or
Content: 

Heading: if a series of one-year requirements is re
Content: 

Heading: quested.
Content: 

Heading: The Kirkland motion deserves care
Content: 

Heading: ful consideration. It ought to be passed,
Content: 

Heading: but without the requested requirement.
Content: 

Heading: The implementation of the program
Content: 

Heading: might lead to a healthier self and a
Content: 

Heading: breach of the Davis Gym fortress.

Heading: Jazz Responsibility
Content: To the Editor: In view of the overwhelming turn out at the West Chester State
    Jazz Band-Inner Tube concert on Sunday, May 2, 1 feel compelled to publicly
    express my gratitude to the con scientious " news editors" of The BucknelUan
    for their beyond-the-call -of-duty advertising of the event. You people have
    done your (very little) bit for Culture by desperately avoiding any type of
    thorough dis semination of the news and have vastly contributed to the
    awareness of Bucknell students and the litter of junk mail and posters on
    campus, not to mention the morale of the kids who give their time and
    talents to make things happen around here. . .

Heading: FEEDBACK: Counselors Reply
Content: To the Editor: In the past few issues of The Bucknellian, various articles ap
    peared which criticize the selection process of Junior Counselors and the
    JC's role in the freshmen dorm itory. The undersigned Junior Coun selors of
    Trax Hall do acknowledge the presence of certain problems re garding the
    realm of the counselor. We do, however, believe that some previous attacks
    on the JC deter mination, orientation, and role cognizance have been based
    largely on personal feelings. The criticisms often discredit, misinterpret,
    and misrepresent the merits of the administrative selec tion policy and the
    orientation and role behavior of the counselor. Until the presentation of
    Don Thompson's article, " JC's Uncertain about Their Role"  Trax Hall
    counselors' senti ment was indifferent. No reply was deemed necessary. The
    emotional undertones and biases were blatant. But now we feel compelled and
    warranted to denounce an article written out of ignorance, be it partial or
    total. . . The assertion that there is a " glaring lack of communication be-
    tween the counselors and the resi dent directors"  is inapplicable to Trax
    Hall. The JCs have developed a rapport with the freshmen. They have
    established a similar relation ship with Resident Director Steve Turner. . .
    The keenest source of communica tion has been through his hall counselors.
    We feel our individual conferences with Steve or the week ly meetings
    attended by Steve and all the counselors have satisfied the goals and solved
    the problems which arose, in spite of Mr. Thompson's belief that counselors'
    meetings are " either unproductive or non-existent." On several occasions we
    have in vited members of the administra tion and student government to at
    tend our meetings and clarify policies or advise us on specific problems.
    One particularly vital asset that we have in this dorm is the com munication
    between and among counselors. An incapable or unin terested Head Resident
    could dis rupt such communication as well as cause numerous other problems.
    Our Head Resident has been a

Heading: OFFICIAL STUDENT NEWSPAPER SERVING THE BUCKNELL COMMUNITY
Content: Established 1897. Published twice weekly during the coUege year. Member of
    Associated Collegiate Press. Annual subscription, $7.00, payable in advance.
    Entered as second class matter on September 21. 1922, at the post office at
    Lewisurg, Pa. under the act of March 3, 1879.

Heading: THE BUCKNELLIAN PLATFORM
Content: To review any issue and take a stand we deem in the best interest of the
    University, to treat every issue with the responsibility that is accorded us
    in a free society, to be constructively critical when necessary as well as
    lauda tory when appropriate, and to print the news with accuracy and
    integrity. Editorials appearing on this page reflect the consensttt opinion
    of the editorial board. Signed columns present the views only of the
    authors. The Editor reserves the right to choose all letters for
    publication, and to edit any letter chosen for reasons of space
    restrictions, grammatical change and offensive language. Office: Focht
    Printing Co., 229 Market Street, Consultant: Brad Tufts. 524-1221 523-4221

Heading: THE BUCKNELLIAN
Content: MAY 7, 1971 major link in this communication as well as relating our concerns
    through administrative channels. He has, at times, been the coun selor's
    counselor. . . If our hall is not functioning pro perly, we follow our own
    beliefs and perceptions in order to regulate the problem. We do not brandish
    rules wildly nor blindly. It is fool ish to profess that we feel we " are
    supposed to be policemen." The freshmen in our halls know we are not
    authoritarian figures, even though we posses the potential to exercise
    authority. The administration have greatly expanded JC roles over the last
    two years. There is now substantial flexibility. Rules have been sub
    stituted by reason. Peaceful co existence, academic excellence, and an
    expanding maturity are the goals. . . Even though the most important aspect
    of being a good counselor is to be oneself, we feel that the counselor
    orientation has at times proved invaluable. We do not always learn what to
    do in certain instances, but mostly what to ex pect. . . Counselor
    orientation has already begun this spring and will resume 2 days before the
    new freshmen ar rive. It has entailed reading books on counseling advice and
    drug use and a basic acquaintance with the University branches, officials,
    and their functions. Throughout the year we have dis cussed and proposed
    revisions and additions to the entire counseling program. Th feollowing new
    additionally stressed topics were submitted: 1. explicit knowledge of the
    Uni versity judicial system and punishment specifications 2. more
    interaction of new coun selors with past junior coun selors 3. better
    understanding of Coun seling Services a. more emergency and ab normal
    counseling training from Dr. Wilder, clinical psychologist of the Counsel
    ing Service 4. more drug training

Heading: 6
Content: . 7. 5. closer working and understand ing of the SIS (Student Infor mation
    Service; drugs, birth control and abortion, hotline) increased awareness of
    extra curricular activities acquaintance with Student Gov ernment
    representatives and procedures Some of the suggestions already have been
    incorporated into the training program. Others are still under
    consideration, but we feel they will be approved. . . Don Thompson observed
    that there is " non-communication and a lack of confidence between student
    personnel and residence hall ad ministrators."  This is valid to a certain
    extent, only if he is refer ring to the channels between resi dent hall
    counselors and Freshmen Residence Hall officials and of University
    administrators. Some of the problem will be al leviated by more contact and
    learn ing from past JCs. Improved counselor orientation will also aid. But
    there must be increased inter action feedback, and confidence directly
    between the counselors and the particular administrative of fice. . . The
    administration should revise the counselor selection process. There should
    be more emphasis on peer evaluations, not just from present University
    counselors. Rec ommendations from professors are a possible source. But the
    interview schedule should be greatly expand ed. Present freshmen evaluations
    of their counselor can be a valid in dication of effectiveness and should be
    retained as a judgement cri terion for reapplying counselors. . . Hopefully
    the readers will realize that this letter was written not only in rebuttal,
    but also out of concern and desire for improvement. Our involvement provides
    an excellent vantage point from where we clear ly see the shortcomings of
    the JC system. However, we are dismayed at the rash judgements and dearth of
    constructive suggestions from others. Sincerely, The Junior Counselors of
    Trax Hall Effective journalism hinges as much on a sense of responsibility
    as it does on writing talent, and that responsibility to students and the
    things they are doing should never be pre-empted for the sake of off- campus
    advertisers or needlessly lengthy feature stories. Sincerely, Kathy Hacker
    Gary M. Raynor Gerry Hoffman

Heading: M eaningless M edals
Content: To the Editor: The recent FEEDBACK letter by the ROTC faculty cannot go un
    challenged. I would like to know how many a. " gooks,"  b. human beings (cho
    ose one) had to die for you to col lect your 43 medals? How many innocent
    women and children were killed or maimed? How many vil lages destroyed? I do
    not presume to speak for Prof. Rinkus, but I would guess that being " in the
    field where the war is being fought"  would have only served to make him
    sicker about what we are doing. I suggest you gentlemen review again the
    actions recently in Washington where vet erans who fought our war turned in
    their valueless pieces of tin and ribbon in order to live with them selves.
    Peace, Paul Pickard

Heading: Vietnam  V ets
Content: To the Editor: As a former veteran I have be come increasingly concerned about
    the brutalizing effect of the war on those compelled to fight it. I would
    urge all young men to reflect care fully and question seriously whether they
    can continue to support the Indo-China war by cooperating with the draft.
    For those who have friends or relatives presently serv ing in the armed
    forces I would urge them to explore the possibility of obtaining a discharge
    by seek ing information from the Vietnam Veterans Against the War, Room 735,
    156 Fifth Ave., New York, N.Y. 10010 . As a former intelligence officer I
    have also become concerned with the attack on our civil libertiies and the
    right to privacy resulting from military surveillance of civilians. I would
    urge any veteran of any rank who may have served in army in telligence and
    is familiar with spe cific incidents of military surveil lance of civilians
    to provide that in formation to Senator Ervin's In vestigative Committee on
    Consti tutional Rights. Anyone prepared to divulge such information should
    contact me or preferably Mr. Ralph Stein, a former intelligence officer and
    chief investigator for Senator Ervin, at his Subcommittee on Constitutional
    Rights, Old Senate Office Building, Washington, D.C. Jerome J. Rinkus
    Captain USAR (Retired)

Heading: FACULTY STUDY"
Content: 

Heading: University Discrimination
Content: ______ By JEAN WILLIAMS and SUSAN LOUGHLIN _ Last April and May, the Women's
    Equity Action League and the National Organiation for Women filed complaints
    of sexual discrimination in hiring against 150 colleges and universities.
    Subsequent investigations forced more than 2,000 schools to open their
    personnel records to inspec tion by Federal agents. If Bucknell were
    investigated, would sexual dis crimination in faculty employment be
    revealed? First, note the percentage of faculty members who are women:
    13.5%. And the number of female chair'men' of academic departments: 1 - the
    head of the women's phys. ed. department. In what rank are most women
    faculty members? Of the three lower ranks, (Assistants, Lecturers, and
    Instructors), 16 of 49, or 32.6%, are women. However, there is consider able
    thinning out of the women's ranks when the three higher posts (Pro fessor,
    Associate Professor, and Assistant Professor) are considered: 13 of 198, or
    6.6%, are female. Why? Aren't women capable of filling these higher
    positions? The lack of motivational models for the girl has become a matter
    of concern to educators, some of whom have strongly urged that the uni
    versity give more thought to providing models for undergrad women by
    employing more women faculty members in prestige positions to demon strate
    that such fields are open to qualified women. The absence of women in
    faculty posts and positions of authority cannot help but affect negatively
    the students' general attitudes toward women's capabilities, as well as the
    women students' achievement motivation and future occupa tional goals. Why
    aren't more women hired here? The conditions of work are not ideal: lack of
    other women faculty with whom to associate, lack of day care facilities for
    women faculty with children, unstated policy on ma ternity leave, relegation
    of women to secondary positions, lack of active recruitment of women,
    unwritten and ambigious policies prohibiting sim ultaneous employment of
    husband and wife, and wage discrimination. Women faculty are paid
    considerably less than males for the same work. For example, the median
    salary for male and female professors combined is $16,639. However, the
    median salary for women professors alone is only $14,780. Associate
    professors? Median of all: $12,974; median of women, $11,325, and so on. . .
    How are such consistent wage discrepancies explained? That's the key to the
    problem. They are not explained at all. There is no policy re garding hiring
    of women, or recognizing the needs of women faculty as a legitimate minority
    group at Bucknell. It is doubly hard to combat pre judicial attitudes that
    are not brought out in the open and given body and definite policy. It is
    imperative that official recognition be given the needs of women as a
    minority group within the university, and that policies be formulated and
    implemented that are directed toward rectifying present inequities and
    disadvanteges experienced by women in hiring practices, wages, and decisions
    of promotion and tenure. Refusal to recognize the existence of
    discriminatory practices should not be tolerated by educated persons.

Heading: Infirmary Ignores Girls' Needs,

Heading: Refuses to Provide Gynecologist
Content: We all know that when we com pare Bucknell with state schools or when we compare
    the University today with the Bucknell of yester day, women have it
    comparatively better, and we should all be grate ful, (we are told).
    University pub lications exude great airs of belief in equality and
    individuality, but somehow the general attitude to ward women implied by the
    prac tices of the University seems to put this in question. How does
    Bucknell see the Bucknell woman? Ah, yes, things have changed - women are
    allowed to live off campus, make their own meal ar rangements, and set their
    own cur fews. The trend is in our favor, I admit, but Bucknell hardly treats
    women as capable of making de cisions irf their own best interests. Why are
    women still locked in their halls at night when men are not? (Sure, we know,
    mad rapists would ravage the Bucknell beauties . . .) Why must women under
    twenty-one bring a signed slip to prove that their parents approve of their
    living off campus, when this is not re quired of male students? (The land
    lord usually requires this signature to make a lease legally binding, but
    why the University?) Why do freshmen women have hours when freshmen men do
    not? There are, of course, reasons for these decis ions which sound fairly "
    reason able"  and some of them even make sense. The questions here are
    raised to question the actual intent of these regulations. More serious
    questions which need to be asked, however, lie in the failure of the
    University to meet some very real needs of her women students, particularly
    those needs in the medical realm. The University does not have a
    gynecologist, nor will the infirmary provide gynecological services. Why
    not? (1) " We don't have dental surgeons or sight specialists either - we
    cannot provide such specialized services."  If there were 800 partial ly
    blind students here, would we hire a sight specialist? Think about it -
    approximately a third of the student body is being denied an es- This page
    is the result of the collective effort of interested wo men at this
    University. We want to open peoples' eyes to the women's situation here, we
    wish to encourage dialogue on the subject, and we hope that the groundwork
    for future research which is sorely needed has been layed. This is only the
    beginn ing. Women of the World Unite! sential medical service. Anyway, I
    would maintain that treating the eyes or the teeth is hardly analo gous to
    treating women. (2) " We cannot afford to hire a gynecolo gist." Maybe not,
    but why can't the infirmary doctors provide gyne cological services that
    general prac- tioners usually provide their pa tients? (3) " The infirmary
    is de signed to meet common medical needs of her students and provide
    emergency aid; we cannot be a

Heading: Women in Academe -# AAUP Considers Situation
Content: By MARYANN BRANDT (Condensed from " The Second Sex in Academe"  by Ann Suther
    land Harris in the AAUP Bulletin, Sept., 1970. Research into the prob lem of
    discrimination against wo men in higher education is handi capped at present
    by the scarcity of studies of individual colleges and universities. This
    article is based on up-to-date statistics available from the University of
    Chicago.) Several remarks by men famous in the academic world reveal all too
    clearly how women are re garded in Academe. When former President Nathan
    Pusey of Har vard realized that the draft was going to reduce the number of
    men applying to Harvard's graduate school, his reaction was, " She shall be
    left with the blind, the lame, and the women."  Sometimes there ap pears in
    serious publications what appears to be a reasonable objec tion to giving
    women the same op portunities as men, that is, that women are enrolling in
    graduate schools without having seriously considered the obligation they are
    assuming by requesting that such expenditures be made for them. That women
    who go to graduate school do make a serious commit ment is proved by studies
    that have taken into account the degree of education of working women. The
    amount of education a woman has received is a more important factor with
    respect to her decision to work than either marriage or children. For
    example, Helen Astin found that of 2000 women doctorates sur veyed ten years
    after completion of their Ph.D.'s, 91% were working, 81% of them full time.
    Responses to a questionnaire pub lished by the AAUW (American As sociation
    of University Women) in its January 1970 Journal showed that the majority of
    over 3,000 men who replied believed " that women's first responsibility is
    to be the feminine companion of men and a # mother, that women have less
    need to achieve in the working world, that they have adequate opportunity to
    develop their potential, that the job turnover rate and sick-leave rate of
    women is higher than that of men, and that women have dif ficulty dealing
    with males in sub ordinate positions. It should be quite obvious, however,
    that those women who wish to become professors, lawyers, and doctors can
    hardly have less need to achieve in the working world than men, for they
    will need far more determination than men to reach the same status and enjoy
    the same opportunities. The sick-leave rate and turn-over rates for women
    are, according to latest figures from the Women's Bureau of the Department
    of Labor, slightly lower than those of men. The way men treat women in em
    ployment situations and in higher education is a simple one: the high er the
    job or education level, the fewer women are tolerated. Overt discrimination
    against wo men in graduate school is exempli fied by the following
    quotations, gathered from various institutions last year. We expect women
    who come here to be competent, good students, bat we don't expect them to be
    brilliant or original. Women are intrinsically inferior. Any woman who has
    got this far has to be a kook. There are al ready too many women in this De
    partment. (To a young widow who had a five-year-old child and who needed a
    fellowship to continue at grad uate school) You're very attractive. You'll
    get married again. We have to give fellowships to people who really need
    them. Comments such as these are ob-
